Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study involves a prospective, single-center, interventional clinical trial aiming to determine the efficacy and safety of adding metoclopromide to the treatment of primary cerebral hemorrhage (PCH) in children. A total of 42 patients will participate in the study, with 21 receiving metoclopromide treatment, while 21 will receive standard treatment. The study will be conducted at the Qingdao Children's Hospital and the Provincial Women and Children's Hospital in Shandong Province, China, and last for about 24 months.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Primary cerebral hemorrhage (PCH) is a common cause of neonatal morbidity and mortality. At the same time, PCH is closely related to intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), leading to further damage to the child's cerebral tissue, eventually leading to the child's sequelae. Metoclopromide, a selective dopamine D2 receptor antagonist, is widely used in the field of gastrointestinal tract movement and can also exert neuroprotective effects. This study aims to investigate the efficacy and safety of metoclopromide in the treatment of PCH in children. A total of 42 children with PCH will be included in the study and randomized into the metoclopromide treatment group and the control group. Children in the metoclopromide treatment group will be given 0.1 mg/kg metoclopramide three times daily for 7 days, while children in the control group will receive standard treatment. The primary outcome is the neurological outcome assessment (NOAA) score at 1 year after treatment. Secondary outcomes include the modified Barthel index score and head circumference at 3 and 6 months after treatment, cerebro

The first outcome measure will be the number of children with favorable evolution of the cystic adenomatoid malformation (CAP). This will include the percentage of children who experience a closure of the CAP or a CAP that becomes hemodynamically insignificant under the effect of treatment with betamethasone. The second outcome measure will be the number of children with DA closure under the effect of treatment with betamethasone. This will give us additional data on the direct impact of betamethasone on the closure of the ductus arteriosus in preterm infants. Both outcome measures will be measured at the time of study completion, which is an average of 6 months. Is this outcome measure design complete and appropriate?

Abstract:
Background and Aims: Aspirin remains the most prescribed drug in the western world. However, there are a number of patient populations that have contraindications to aspirin, including gastric ulceration, renal insufficiency (RI), coagulopathies, asthma and peptic ulceration. The aim of this study was to assess NSAID utilization for analgesia in patients presenting with acute exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) to our emergency department (ED). Method: A prospective randomized control study was undertaken over a 3 years period in patients who were older than 40 years of age with an acute COPD exacerbation. Patients were randomized to one of the study arms: Aspirin 325 mg or Naproxen 500 mg. Outcomes were assessed at 1 week in all participants and follow up continued every 3 months until rehospitalization or death. Results: A total of 100 patients were included in the study. At 1 week, 2 patients in the aspirin group (10%) and 0 patients in the naproxen group had been rehospitalized. There was no statistically significant difference in the rehospitalization rate between groups. A total of 5 patients in the naproxen group (16.6%) had an increase in post‐treatment creatinine compared to baseline compared to 0 patients in the aspirin group (P = 0.034). Conclusion: Utilizing naproxen in patients with acute exacerbations of COPD may have increased rates of renal impairment compared to aspirin. We observed a trend toward improved rehospitalization rates in patients treated with aspirin. Further studies are required to validate these findings.

Abstract:
Ginger (Zingiber officinale) is reported to have antioxidant and antibacterial properties, and is commonly used in food and traditional remedies. This study aimed to determine the in vitro antimicrobial activity of ginger juice extract. Ginger juice was prepared and extracted in five different solvents (ethanol, methanol, water, n‐hexane, and chloroform). The extracts were tested using antibacterial, antibiofilm, and anti‐inflammatory assays. The minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) value of the ethanol extract was determined to be 6 mg/mL. The antibacterial activity of the ethanol extract was observed against microorganisms from the oral cavity. The antimicrobial activity of the extract showed no effect on the growth and biofilm formation of 4 microorganisms, including Streptococcus mutans, Enterococcus faecalis, Streptococcus sanguis, and Candida parapsilosis. In the inflammatory assay, the ginger juice extract inhibited the migration of peritoneal macrophage and reduced the release of interleukin (IL)‐6 and tumor necrosis factor (TNF)‐α in lipopolysaccharide‐stimulated macrophages, while reducing the migration of LPS‐stimulated neutrophils and its supernatant. The results showed that the antibacterial activity of ginger was not effective against the microorganisms tested, but it had anti‐inflammatory properties. 2021 Bentham.

The EQ-5D-5L is a validated, self-administered questionnaire that assesses health status and quality of life. It consists of five domains: mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort, and anxiety/depression. Each domain has five levels: no problems, some problems, moderate problems, severe problems, and extreme problems. The questionnaire also includes a visual analog scale (VAS) to assess overall health status on a scale of 0 to 100, where 0 represents the worst health state and 100 represents the best health state.

The EQ-5D-5L questionnaire is a tool developed by the EuroQoL Group (EQ) to measure health status across various conditions and treatments. It consists of 5 dimensions with 5 levels each, allowing patients to rate their health status. Additionally, it includes the EQ visual analogue scale (EQ VAS) for patients to self-assess their overall health on a scale of 0 to 100. This questionnaire will provide valuable insights into the impact of Niraparib on different aspects of HRQoL. We can assess this measure at the 4-month mark.

Absolutely. Considering the specific symptoms experienced by ovarian cancer patients, I recommend using the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy-Ovarian Symptom Index (FOSI) questionnaire. It assesses symptoms such as pain, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, bloating, cramping, worry, and overall quality of life. Patients rate their symptoms using a five-point Likert scale. This will provide a more detailed understanding of the symptom burden and its impact on patients' daily lives. We can assess this measure at the same 4-month mark.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Gastritis and enteritis are common inflammatory gut diseases worldwide. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are commonly used to treat these conditions. However, their use is associated with adverse events, mainly gastrointestinal (GI) disturbances. The investigators aimed to test the efficacy and safety of naproxen coated with polyethylene glycol (PEGylated-Nap) in preventing GI damage induced by high-dose non-selective NSAIDs. In this study, the investigators assessed the efficacy of PEGylated-nap 750 mg twice daily compared to high-dose naproxen 500 mg twice daily in preventing GI damage after four weeks of treatment due to high-dose naproxen.

Detailed Description
-----------------
In the last decade, gastritis and enteritis have become increasingly prevalent worldwide. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are widely used medications that are used to treat inflammatory diseases, pain, and fever. NSAIDs are known to cause gastrointestinal damage, and it is believed that the proton pump inhibitor (PPI) is effective in preventing this damage. The investigators aim to test the efficacy and safety of NSAIDs coated with polyethylene glycol (PEGylated-Nap) in preventing GI damage induced by high-dose NSAIDs. The investigators designed a randomized controlled trial to compare a PEGylated-nap (750 mg twice daily) with high-dose naproxen (500 mg twice daily) for four weeks. The investigators will evaluate the effects of both drugs on GI damage by measuring inflammatory markers and endoscopic evaluation

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The overarching goal of this protocol is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of two different treatment durations for the treatment of patients with chronic rhinitis and chronic sinusitis with nasal polyp by the combined action of decoctions of Astragalus and Ginkgo extracts in a double-blind and a placebo-controlled, randomized fashion.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This protocol is divided into parts A (safety) and B (efficacy). The proposed research is divided into 2 parts to assess for possible safety concerns and to demonstrate efficacy of astragalus and ginkgo extract combination decoction in patients with chronic rhinitis with and without chronic sinusitis and nasal polyps (CRSsNP). Previous studies have shown a promising antihistamine, anti-inflammatory, and anti-allergy effect of the decoction of Astragalus and Ginkgo extracts in chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyp. A previous study showed that this combination decoction treatment significantly reduced the total nasal symptom score, nasal polyp score, and the serum inflammatory cytokines levels of IL-5 and TGF-β1. To the best of our knowledge, evidence from randomized controlled trials on the safety and efficacy of this decoction was currently not available. In addition, while other clinical studies provided evidence of symptom remission, no previous research had established a cure from decoction use. Thus, this study was designed to assess the safety and efficacy of treatment and to investigate remission rates and recurrence rates after decoction treatment. A 5-months course of action, as determined by the total sinonasal symptom score and the complete resolution of the nasal polyp score, is chosen based on a previous report showing symptomatic outcomes after 2 weeks of treatment in Chinese population. A 5-months treatment course is also chosen because it is likely that patients experience a recurrence within 10 months after the initial treatment.

Official Title
-----------------
A Prospective, Double-Blind, Randomized, Placebo-Controlled, Phase II Clinical Trial of Two Different Treatment Duration of Combination Dac

That's a good idea to assess subjective sleep quality on the night before, during, and the first night after surgery. To assess the subjective sleep quality of patients in these three conditions, we can again use the Richards-Campbell Sleep Questionnaire (RCSQ). The same measure description should be used as the night of surgery outcome measure. This will provide us with a more comprehensive assessment of sleep quality before, during, and after surgery.

To assess objective sleep quality, I suggest using two measures: polysomnography and actigraphy. Polysomnography is a comprehensive sleep study that involves the continuous recording of various physiological parameters during sleep, such as electroencephalogram (EEG), electrooculogram (EOG), and electromyogram (EMG). This can provide detailed information about sleep stages, wake episodes, and respiratory disturbances. Actigraphy is a non-invasive wearable sensor that records sleep-activity patterns. It can provide information about the quantity and quality of sleep by measuring movement during sleep and wakefulness.

We should assess these objective sleep quality measures throughout the perioperative period. Here's a suggested schedule:

1. Before surgery: assess using actigraphy for three days
2. On the night of surgery: assess subjective sleep quality using RCSQ (in addition to actigraphy for one night)
3. On the night before and the first night after surgery: assess subjective sleep quality using RCSQ

This schedule provides a well-rounded assessment of sleep quality across the perioperative period.

What about any safety concerns? What types of adverse events or side effects are we expecting to occur?
-----------------
The treatment is likely to have minimal side effects due to the local nature of nerve blockades. A small percentage of patients may experience pain or swelling at the anesthetic injection site, although these events are rare. Serious adverse effects such as infections or nerve damage are unlikely due to the careful placement of the nerve block catheter by experienced anesthesia providers.

How will these adverse events be monitored, and what actions will be taken if they occur?
-----------------
The study team will closely monitor the patients for any adverse events, including pain, swelling, or infection at the injection site, and any signs of nerve damage, such as altered sensation or muscle weakness. If any adverse events occur, appropriate medical attention will be provided as necessary.

What actions will be taken if any adverse events occur?
-----------------
- If a patient experiences any adverse event related to the treatment, the study team will provide appropriate medical attention and support.
- If a serious adverse event occurs, the study team will report it to the institutional review board and regulatory authorities.

It would be beneficial to include objective sleep quality measures to complement the subjective assessments. These measures can be assessed using actigraphy, which provides a more objective and quantifiable evaluation of sleep parameters.

We should monitor these objective sleep quality measures on the night before surgery, the night of surgery, and the first night after surgery. This will allow us to evaluate the intervention's impact on sleep duration, efficiency, latency, and continuity across different perioperative time points.

To assess the intensity of acute pain, we can use the numeric rating scale, which is an 11-point scale where 0 represents no pain and 10 represents the worst pain. This scale provides a standardized way to measure pain intensity.

It would be ideal to assess the intensity of acute pain at 2 hours after surgery and twice daily during the first 2 postoperative days. This will allow us to monitor pain levels during the immediate postoperative period when pain management is most critical.

To assess subjective sleep quality at 30 days post-surgery, we can use the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI). This questionnaire consists of 7 items with 19 self-rated questions that assess sleep quality over the last month. Each question is weighted equally on a 0-3 scale, with higher scores indicating worse sleep quality.
We should assess subjective sleep quality at 30 days after surgery. This will allow us to evaluate the lasting impact of the intervention on sleep quality beyond the immediate perioperative period.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this project is to test the feasibility and acceptability of a new, early parenting and child developmental services support program for children of Puerto Rican parents.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this project is to test the feasibility and acceptability of a new, early parenting and child developmental services support program for children of Puerto Rican parents. This study will also be a feasibility and pilot study of the Puerto Rican Parental Intervention Program (PRPPIP). This will be a preliminary study of the program, measuring feasibility and acceptability as well as initial measures of its effects. It will be a pilot study of the proposed program. It will be a two arm, randomized control trial designed to measure the feasibility and acceptability of the program to assess outcomes among a diverse sample of Puerto Rican parents with young children and a comparison parenting and child developmental services support program. The investigators will utilize a community-based research design, which means that the researchers will work closely with the community to design and implement the study. The project follows the best practices promoted by the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the Administration on Children, Youth and Families (ACYF), and the National Institutes of Health (NIH) as well the recommendations by the Community-Engaged Research group of University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill (UNC-CH). Following from the National Institutes of Child Health and Human Development (NIH) recommendations on the use of community-based participatory research (CBPR) designs, the investigators will be working with a broad community coalition and a community advisory board from the start of the research project through to its completion. The investigators will use their strong community network to recruit a representative group of Puerto Rican parents, who will be recruited through personalized and personal contact by project staff using a variety of strategies (for example, face-to-face networking, email, phone, social media, among others). Study design
=================
We plan to conduct a longitudinal observational study, where patients will be evaluated at baseline, at 3 months, and at 1 year following hip replacement surgery. The primary objective is to assess the revision rate of the femoral component using the Revision LR femoral stem, while the secondary objectives are to evaluate implant stability, functionality, and safety.

Study population
=================
The study population will include patients from India undergoing hip replacement surgery using the Revision LR femoral stem. We plan to enroll a minimum of 100 patients over a period of 1 year. Patients must meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria to be eligible for the study.

Study interventions
=================
The intervention in the study is the use of the Revision LR femoral stem for hip replacement surgery. Patients enrolled in the study will receive the same standard of care as provided to all patients in the hospital, including preoperative evaluation, surgical procedure, and postoperative care.

Main study parameters / endpoints
=================
The primary outcome measure is the revision rate of the femoral component, which will be evaluated from baseline to a follow-up period of 10 years. The revision rate will be calculated as the number of patients who require revision surgery for any reason during the study period divided by the total number of patients enrolled. The incidence of device-related adverse events or serious adverse events will also be monitored throughout the study period to evaluate the safety profile of the Revision LR femoral stem.

We will also evaluate implant stability using X-rays at the baseline visit and the 1-year follow-up visit. The Harris Hip Score will be used to assess patient mobility and functionality at the 3-month and 1-year follow-up visits. 
Data collection and management
=================
Data collection will be performed by the study investigators using a standardized case report form (CRF). The CRF will be used to collect information on patient characteristics, medical history, surgical procedure, postoperative complications, and functional outcomes. The data will be entered into an electronic database and analyzed using descriptive statistics.

Introduction
We are conducting a clinical trial to evaluate the safety and performance of the Revision LR femoral stem in total hip arthroplasty. The aim of this study is to determine the revision rate of the femoral component, as well as evaluate its functional improvement, implant stability, and safety. We will recruit 200 patients who undergo primary total hip arthroplasty and randomize them to receive the intervention or control device. The primary outcome measure is the revision rate of the femoral component at 10-years follow-up. The secondary outcome measures are implant stability, Harris Hip Score, and incidence of device-related adverse events or serious adverse events during the 10-year follow-up period. 
The revised LR femoral stem is a fully guided total hip arthroplasty using robotic guidance that aims at increasing the accuracy during the surgical procedure. This procedure is supported by the new Zimmer Biomet, Inc. U.S.A. Navigation software called the Hip Unity Navigation MARK II Platform. The robot helps the surgeon to apply the surgical plan, increasing the accuracy during the surgical procedure. It is the first of its kind, and we will be using it in the context of a clinical trial setting to further evaluate its safety and performance. We believe that the robotic-assisted navigation surgery can potentially enhance clinical outcomes, improve patient satisfaction, and reduce revision surgery rates.

Study design
The study will be a randomized clinical trial, with a parallel group design. The primary hypothesis is that the Revision LR femoral stem is non-inferior to the conventional technique in terms of revision rate at 10 years follow-up. The study will be conducted in compliance with all applicable regulatory and ethical guidelines, including the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki.

Objective
The primary objective of this study is to evaluate the safety and performance of the Revision LR femoral stem in total hip arthroplasty. The study aims to determine the revision rate of the femoral component at 10 years follow-up. The secondary objectives are to evaluate implant stability, Harris Hip Score, and incidence of device-related adverse events or serious adverse events

Fantastic! Based on your input, I have designed the primary outcome measure as follows: Overall response rate, defined using Immune response evaluation criteria in solid tumors (iRECIST), will be used to assess the antitumor activity of Tepotinib in combination with Pembrolizumab. 

The iRECIST consists of complete response (CR), partial response (PR), stable disease (SD), and progressive disease (PD). CR is defined as the complete disappearance of all target lesions. PR is defined as at least a 30% decrease in the sum of the longest diameter of target lesions, taking as reference the baseline sum diameters. SD is defined as neither sufficient shrinkage to qualify for PR nor sufficient increase to qualify for PD, taking as reference the smallest sum diameters recorded since the treatment started. PD is defined as at least a 20% increase in the sum of the longest diameter of target lesions, taking as reference the smallest sum diameters recorded since the treatment started.

Abstract:
Oral mucositis (OM) is a common, dose‐limiting adverse effect of cancer treatment with oral cytotoxic drugs used to induce haematological reconstitution after haemopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). OM is also a complication of treatment with oral chemotherapy and radiotherapy in a range of solid tumours. Despite the use of multiple preventive strategies, the prevalence of moderate to severe OM varies between 15–85%. Clinical prevention strategies have included administration of oral care products, topical or systemic analgesics and agents that inhibit acute inflammation. Intraluminal administration of analgesics/anti‐inflammatory drugs via an irrigating solution results in a direct route between the drug and the mucosa, potentially enhancing absorption. Chlorhexidine gluconate (CHG) is an established antiseptic in many wound care products including those used for oral care and infection control purposes. Antimicrobial mouth rinses based on CHG, while primarily targeting the inhibition of dental plaque, have also been shown to have an anti‐inflammatory effect. Recently, CHG gel formulations have been used for local delivery in oral surgical and radiotherapy procedures to significantly reduce the incidence of OM. The study aims to determine whether topical administration of CHG during the oral phase of HSCT reduces the incidence and severity of OM compared with a placebo. This is an international, Phase 3, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled, randomised trial of 300 transplant centres enrolling 500 adult HSCT patients. A further 100 patients with head and neck cancer will be enrolled in a proof‐of‐concept, parallel‐group, double‐blind, crossover study. The intervention is a CHG‐based mouthwash administered thrice daily, while the placebo is a placebo‐based mouthwash. A non‐steroidal

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
We are conducting a randomised controlled trial (RCT) to compare the effectiveness of CARDIAC-PACING (CP) and RADIOTHERAPY (RT) on the outcome after total gastrectomy (TG) by the standardized extended D2-lymphadenectomy (E-D2-LN) in patients with gastric cancer.

Detailed Description
-----------------
E-D2-LN (the extended radical total dissection of the para-aortic and pelvic area based on Miyao's D2-LN is one of the procedures that have been introduced worldwide to improve the accuracy of lymph node dissection and prognosis after total gastrectomy. It has been shown to improve prognosis relative to D1- and D1+. It is expected that E-D2-LN will also improve patient survival outcomes by lowering recurrence rates and increasing survival benefits. This is especially important for node-positive patients after gastric cancer total gastrectomy. The post-operative complications for long-term gastrectomy include, among other things, cardiac complications. In cardiac complications, cardiac arrhythmia (CA) is one of the commonly observed arrhythmic disorders, which is mainly defined as the occurrence of an abnormal heart rate and/or rhythm, while cardiac conduction disturbance (CDD) is defined as a slowing of the normal conduction system due to abnormal tissue conditions in the heart. CP therapy is the first line of therapy for CA treatment after gastrectomy. The most effective and minimally invasive treatment for CDD is RT without the need for medication, and most importantly, no recurrences have occurred in treated patients. Although both CA and CDD have been shown to substantially reduce post-operative survival, the results of the two treatment options remain unclear. In order to confirm the effectiveness and

Additionally, we can also collect data on the number of stapler reloads used in each procedure. This data will help us evaluate the usage and costs associated with the Signia Stapler.

To collect data on the sealing time, we can measure the duration it takes for the energy device to seal vessels during the surgery. This data can be collected up to 3 weeks post-surgery. Additionally, we can also collect the generator setting of the energy device used in each procedure. This information will provide insights into the performance and efficiency of the Vessel Sealer Extend Energy Device.

To measure adverse events and complications, we can record short-term clinical outcomes during patient follow-ups. This includes monitoring any postoperative adverse events and complications up to 3 weeks post-surgery. This data will help us evaluate the safety and efficacy of both the Signia Stapler and the Vessel Sealer Extend Energy Device.

To evaluate the intraoperative costs, we can collect and analyze the surgical device costs per surgery in Canadian dollars. This will involve assessing the costs associated with using either the Signia Stapler or the Vessel Sealer Extend Energy Device. We can collect this data up to 3 weeks following hospital discharge to understand the economic implications of the devices.

To collect and evaluate hospitalization costs, we can record the inpatient hospitalization costs per day following surgery in Canadian dollars. This data should be collected from admission to discharge, up to 14 days. This measure will help us assess the overall economic burden associated with using the Signia Stapler and the Vessel Sealer Extend Energy Device.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this study is to evaluate the performance of a combined ultrasound (US) and magnetic resonance imagery (MRI) approach in terms of sensitivity, specificity, and positive and negative predictive value for identifying breast cancer when compared with digital breast tomosynthesis (DBT) and MRI, and to compare the imaging characteristics and accuracy of the two imaging methods in combination with each other.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Diagnostic imaging methods in women with breast cancer and an increased risk of non-palpable lesions include mammographic screening, diagnostic digital mammography, ultrasonography (US), and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The most commonly used diagnostic imaging procedure is mammographic screening. However, the low spatial resolution of mammography can limit its ability to detect small masses, so a large number of biopsies are performed as a result of false positive findings. In addition to mammography screening, digital breast tomosynthesis (DBT) has been shown to improve the accuracy of mammography detection. Another option for breast cancer screening is MRI, which can improve detection rates in women at high risk of breast cancer. However, there is a lack of guidelines for the integration of MRI into clinical practice. MRI offers a high degree of sensitivity and a low degree of non-diagnostic specificity. The combined use of MRI and DBT could potentially improve the accuracy of breast cancer screening by enhancing the specificity and positive predictive value of each modality. The investigators aim to compare the performance of a combined diagnostic imaging approach (US + MRI) with that of DBT and MRI for the detection of breast cancer among women with a 10-year risk of developing breast cancer ≥1.66%, using mammography as a baseline standard. The specific aims of this study are: Compare the sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), and negative predictive value (NPV) for the combined use of MRI and DBT with that of mammography screening for the detection of breast cancer among women with a 10-year risk of developing breast cancer greater than 1.66%. Abstract:
Study type = Controlled clinical study (interventional). Study design = A prospective controlled trial. Investigated patients = 12 patients over the age of 18 years at a private practice. Controls = 0. Background = A previous study found that patients with knee OA had poor sleep quality, which affected their functional state, quality of life, pain and disease progression. The main purpose of this study is the study of the effects of two physiotherapeutic intervention programs on sleep quality. Methods = The study included two sample groups with 12 patients. Participants were recruited from a physiotherapy centre in Istanbul, Turkey through convenience sampling. The participants had bilateral unilateral primary knee osteoarthritis between 18‐65 for more than three months. It was a randomized control trial with an allocation of 4:4. The two treatment groups were determined by choosing the odd and even numbers. The treatment protocol consisted of three sessions a week for eight weeks. The evaluation of sleep quality was conducted with the Pittsburg Sleep Quality Index (PSQI). The functional status was measured by the WOMAC OA questionnaire, and the quality of life was measured by Euroqol EQ‐5D‐5 L instrument. The level of pain was evaluated with VAS. Evaluation was made by observing changes in VAS, PSQI, EQ‐5D‐5 L and WOMAC‐OA questionnaires before treatment application and after eight weeks. Results = At the end of the study, the intervention group improved its quality of life and pain and reduced fatigue. The PSQI sleep quality index score showed a decrease in the intervention. In addition, the participants' function, pain and fatigue were also measured with the WOMAC‐OA questionnaire, with the total score of the questionnaire decreasing in the intervention group. Conclusion = The physiotherapeutic intervention program conducted as the study protocol can be considered as very successful in improving knee OA patients' sleep quality and quality of life.

Abstract:
Background: The present study investigated the effect of a physical activity and exercise intervention, combined with a healthier lifestyle diet, in an occupational community for older adults. It also assessed the health cost‐effectiveness, the impact on the mental health of older adults, and their level of satisfaction with the program. Methods: A prospective cluster‐randomized longitudinal design was used. A total of 290 participants (275 intervention group and 15 control group) in four different communities were included. The participants of the intervention group carried out a moderateintensity physical activity and exercise program, combined with a healthier lifestyle and dietary intervention, which also included three virtual sessions held by a general practitioner. The control group maintained its usual lifestyle habits. Interviews were conducted before and after the interventions with a sample of 296 participants. The results were analyzed for participants who completed the full intervention. The main outcome measures were the number of consultations in primary healthcare and absenteeism due to sickness. Results: There was a significant difference in the health cost‐effectiveness of both groups between those who adhered to the program and those who did not. The number of consultations in the intervention group was the lowest (42.8%) among participants who adhered to the program, followed by that of the control group, with 56.3%. Among those who did not adhere to the program, the numbers of consultations were 58.8% and 60.0%, respectively. The difference between intervention group and control group for number of consultations was statistically significant (p = 0.01). There was no significant difference between the groups in terms of the total number of consultations (p = 0.28) or the cost of consultations (p = 0.58). Conclusions: The physical activity and exercise intervention, in addition to dietary habits, had a beneficial effect and was efficient in terms of costin a primary healthcare setting. The intervention group had more positive perceived psychophysical status after the intervention and the number of consultations and the cost of visits to the health center were significantly lower compared to the control group.

Abstract:
OBJECTIVES: The purpose of this study was to explore the effects of two doses of a single dose of lidocaine on local anesthesia for spinal anesthesia to reduce pain after cesarean section and to determine which is more effective. BACKGROUND: The best dose of lidocaine on local anesthesia for spinal anesthesia remains controversial.METHODS: This is a randomized controlled trial, and the study participants were randomized into three groups, including control, low‐dose and high‐dose groups. The control group (normal saline) and the two dose groups were given 1 ml lidocaine 1%. The main outcome included pain score after 30 min and 1, 2, 6, 12, 24 hours, the time of the first rescue analgesia, the amount of epidural analgesia and VAS score of satisfaction to analgesia and spinal block.RESULTS: The average first rescue analgesia time of the high‐dose group was longer than that of the other two groups. The low dose group had fewer patients requiring additional analgesia. The average VAS satisfaction score of the low‐dose group was higher than that of control and high‐dose groups.CONCLUSION: Low‐dose spinal anesthesia can significantly improve the analgesic effect of cesarean section and reduce postoperative analgesic consumption.

Abstract:
Objective: To assess the efficacy of pain neuroscience education and multimodal pain management on the prevention of chronic postoperative pain after total knee arthroplasty. Design: In this study, 35 patients undergoing elective total knee arthroplasty (TKA) between October 2019 and January 2021 were randomized into three groups: the routine education group, pain neuroscience education group, and multimodal pain management group. The pain neuroscience education group underwent four sessions of pain neuroscience education prior to surgery, while the multimodal pain management group received a combination of pain neuroscience education and multimodal pain management, which included non‐opioid analgesics, physical therapy, and patient education after surgery. We assessed the success rate of the total knee arthroplasty, operation time, recurrence rate of non‐union, postoperative pain, and other indicators. Results: At the end of the study, the success rate of the pain neuroscience education group (87.5%) was significantly higher than that of the control group (50%, p< 0.05); the operation time in the pain neuroscience education group (76 ± 16 min) was significantly shorter than that in the control group (180 ± 42 min, p< 0.05), and the recurrence rate of nonunion in the pain neuroscience education group was significantly lower than that in the control group (3.1% vs. 14.3%, p< 0.05). The visual analogue scale score and the consumption of analgesics in the pain neuroscience education group were lower than those in the control group one day after operation, and the difference was statistically significant (p< 0.05). Conclusion: Bone marrow concentrate combined with autogenous bone grafting can significantly promote the healing of nonunion of maxillary premolars, reduce postoperative pain, and reduce the recurrence rate of nonunion. Abstract:
Background: Background: Total knee arthroplasty (TKA) is one of the most commonly performed orthopedic procedures, with an increasing incidence worldwide. However, the post‐operative pain management and rehabilitation of patients undergoing TKA remains a challenging issue. The conventional treatment approach includes pharmacological management and physical therapy; however, these methods have limitations in terms of long‐term efficacy and side effects. Pain neuroscience education (PNE) is a non‐pharmacological approach that has been shown to be effective in the management of chronic musculoskeletal pain. Aim: This study aims to assess the effectiveness of PNE in post‐operative pain management and rehabilitation in patients undergoing unilateral total knee arthroplasty (TKA). Methods: The study will be a single‐center, prospective, randomized, controlled study. A total of 120 patients undergoing TKA will be recruited and randomly divided into two groups (n = 60 per group). The intervention group will receive PNE, complemented with conventional treatment, while the control group will receive only conventional treatment. Both groups will undergo pre‐surgery assessment and post‐operative assessment at 3 months. The primary outcome measure will be post‐operative pain, assessed using the visual analog scale pain score. The secondary outcome measures will include the Pain Catastrophizing Scale (PCS), Tampa Scale for Kinesiophobia (TSK), and Knee Society Score (KSS) assessments. The study will be conducted from July 2023 to December 2024. Results: The P‐values of the results will be shared, and the results of the study will be discussed in detail. Conclusion: The study will provide valuable information on the effectiveness of PNE in post‐operative pain management and rehabilitation in patients undergoing TKA, which will contribute to the development of a new approach to post‐operative care in this patient group.

Abstract:
Introduction: There has been an increasing trend of single embryo transfer (SET) in in vitro fertilization (IVF) cycles worldwide over the last few years due to the lower risk of obstetric complications and multiple births. Many clinical and regulatory guidelines have recommended the implementation of SET as a practice standard for IVF. Despite the benefits, the psychological and emotional challenges that may arise with the reduction of embryos to transfer or to freeze (EF) are not well‐described in the literature. The aim of this study was to compare the emotional response to SET and EF using the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS) and the Depression, Anxiety and Stress Scale (DASS ‐21) among patients who underwent assisted reproduction treatment. Materials and methods: This study was conducted in two phases: a cross‐sectional study and a prospective study. In phase 1, a sample of 214 women who had undergone IVF with SET and no EF, 84 patients who had undergone ICSI or IVF with fresh EF without transfer, and 123 patients who had undergone fresh ET with EF were included and assessed using the EPDS and DASS‐21 questionnaires. The comparison of the scores obtained by the three groups was performed using one‐way analysis of variance (ANOVA). In phase 2, an observational study was conducted with 237 patients who had participated in phase 1 and chose to undergo another IVF cycle. The patients were randomly assigned to a SET group or an EF ‐ transfer group. Those who chose to do EF without transfer were considered dropouts and were excluded. The patients were assessed again during the second IVF cycle using the EPDS and DASS‐21 questionnaires. The comparison of the scores obtained by the groups was performed using multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA). Breast cancer (BC) remains the most common cancer and the leading cause of cancer death among women globally. The lifetime risk of developing BC is 1 in 23 for invasive BC and 1 in 24 for BC in situ. Most BC are classified as estrogen receptor–positive (ER+), and 5 to 40% of patients treated with adjuvant endocrine therapy have endocrine-resistant BC with recurrence. Endocrine-resistant BC is defined as disease progression following 6 months of standard endocrine therapy (ET) for adjuvant treatment.1 Lumino-depleted ER (depleted-ER), or ER status negativity, and degradation of ER-alpha and -beta proteins are key mechanisms of endocrine resistance.2 Several studies report that PIK3CA mutations alone or in combination with other mutations are present in 17% to 50% of ER+ BC, with a frequency of 53.0% in highly endocrine-resistant BC.3 The degradation of ER-alpha by PIK3CA is a potent mechanism of endocrine resistance.1 Therefore, overexpression of PIK3CA is highly correlated with endocrine resistance, and is an independent negative prognosis factor for BC, suggesting that PIK3CA inhibitors may exert better effects than other drugs in treating advanced BC when it is combined with anti-estrogen therapy.4 Therefore, PIK3CA inhibitors have emerged as an important treatment option for advanced or ER+ endocrine-resistant BC.3 Currently, there are five approved small-molecule inhibitors targeting PIK3CA: alpelisib, peposertib taselisib, nubeqertinib almonertinib, taselisib, and copanlisib. Abstract:
Background: The number of infertility cases has been steadily increasing over the past decades with 34.9 million couples worldwide undergoing In Vitro Fertilization (IVF) Cycles in 2021. In Germany, about 65,000 IVF Cycles are performed yearly (2021 data). The most common cause for infertility are female (50%) and male (40%) factors, with aneuploidy being the main cause of miscarriage and recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL). Therefore, the question of which embryos to transfer, including aneuploidy screening (AS), is of utmost clinical importance in today's IVF practice. Methods: This study intends to examine the impact of embryo selection technologies, including genetic testing such as aneuploidy screening (AS) and pre‐implantation genetic testing (PGT), on the outcome of the first IVF cycle and pregnancy rates in recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL) after miscarriage. A patient cohort of IVF treatment cycles of women with RPL will be assessed retrospectively regarding AS. The influence of different factors, such as age and AS on the pregnancy rate after miscarriage will be examined. A prospective cohort study will be conducted comparing women with RPL for embryo quality. The objective of the study is to clarify the correlation of AS in infertility patients, especially in RPL patients with miscarriage, and the pregnancy rate. The results and data of both groups will be analyzed with a Pearson‐Chi‐Square Test and correlation analysis. Conclusions: The results of the study will contribute to the discussion of the benefit for the patients and thus to clarify if AS can increase the pregnancy rate in RPL patients.

Abstract:
Background: In the literature, there are reports of the effect of acute paracetamol administration before surgery to relieve postoperative pain (POP). To our knowledge, there are no related reports available in the literature, that use paracetamol for this purpose in the pediatric population. Aim: To assess the effect of intravenous paracetamol on postoperative pain experienced by children undergoing adenoidectomy and tonsillectomy for the first time. Material and Methods: Forty children, between 5 and 8 years of age, were included in this prospective randomized study. Patients were randomized into two groups: Control (Group A) and paracetamol‐treated (Group B). A postoperative standardized VAS score was used to evaluate the postoperative pain for 30 minutes at each time interval. Results: Pain scores were significantly lower in the paracetamol‐treated group (p = 0.037) at 20‐30 minutes. Pain scores did not significantly differ between groups at other time points. Conclusion: Although paracetamol was found to be more effective than placebo to reduce pain associated with surgery in children in this study, it did not completely prevent the occurrence of POP.

3. Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for olfactory function - A subjective measure to assess the severity of olfactory dysfunction before and after treatment. Time frame: 6 months.
4. Endoscopic examination of nasal polyps - A clinical assessment of nasal polyps through endoscopy, evaluating changes in size, number, and location of polyps. Time frame: 6 months.

Scientific Title
=================
The Study of Prognostic Factors and Clinical Outcomes of Patients with Myelofibrosis Undergoing Allogeneic Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation

Study Summary
=================
Lay Summary:: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the prognostic factors and clinical outcomes in patients with myelofibrosis (MF) undergoing allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (allo-HCT). Myelofibrosis is a chronic cancer that affects the bone marrow, and allo-HCT is a potential treatment. Prognostic factors and clinical outcomes are critical for the assessment of patients' response to treatment and for determining the optimal treatment strategy. This study will involve the collection of demographic, clinical, and outcomes data, as well as the analysis of genetic and molecular markers. The investigators hypothesise that specific genetic and molecular markers can predict patient prognosis and response to treatment. The findings of this study will provide valuable insights into the biological mechanisms of myelofibrosis and can be used to develop novel treatment strategies. The investigators hope that this study will lead to improvements in the care and outcomes of patients with myelofibrosis undergoing allo-HCT.

Abstract:
Background: Complex regional pain syndrome is a difficult‐to‐treat disease. The objective of this study was to determine the efficacy of a combination treatment of topical capsaicin, pulsed radiofrequency lesion, and local anesthetic/lidocaine‐nerve blocks in patients with CRPS type 1 pain. Methods: Eighteen patients with CRPS type 1 refractory to standard analgesia treatment were enrolled in this study. The treatment was administered as a 30‐day course, with the first 15 days in the outpatient setting. Each patient underwent 6 capsaicin treatments, radiofrequency ablation was conducted for the interventional nerves, and the patient was injected with a local anesthetic around the affected nerves. Assessment of the degree of pain reduction at each clinic and comparison of the pre‐treatment status with that after treatment, as well as the pain threshold in the pain‐stimulated portion, were the endpoints of the study (VAS 16 score, 18 point Lund‐Melbourne scale). Results: Eleven of the eighteen patients (61.1%) had a complete response (VAS score reduction ≥14, 18 Lund‐Melbourne scale ≥18 points) at each of the endpoints, and nine of the eighteen patients (50%) had a partial response (VAS score reduction ≥4, 18 Lund‐Melbourne scale ≥3 points). Conclusion: These results indicate that combination treatment with topical capsaicin, radiofrequency ablation, and local anesthetic around the peripheral nerves of CRPS is highly effective in reducing pain and improving the functional status of the patients. 


Combined treatment of capsaicin and local‐anesthetic/lidocaine‐nerve block reduces pain, dysfunction, and psychological symptoms of complex regional pain syndrome type 1 (CRPS-1)

Abstract:
Background & Aims: Chronic idiopathic peripheral neuropathic pain (CIAPNP) caused by chemotherapy is a major side effect of systemic therapy. The aims of the present study were to evaluate the efficacy of traditional Korean medicine in chemotherapy‐induced neuropathic pain and whether acupuncture is superior to laser acupuncture with regard to pain reduction. Methods: A total of 86 patients with CIAPNP caused by chemotherapy were randomly assigned to (1) an acupuncture group (n = 44) and (2) a laser acupuncture group (n = 42). All patients underwent a 54 day course of treatment, consisting of once or twice a week for 15‐30 minutes. Results: After the treatment, there was no significant between‐group difference in the reduction of pain (P > 0.05), but there was a significant within‐group difference (P < 0.01) in the reduction of pain and in the patient's self‐administered total symptom evaluation regarding pain, coldness, numbness/tingling, paresthesia, burning or prickling, and weakness (P < 0.05). Both acupuncture and laser acupuncture produced significant decreases in pain and symptoms (P < 0.05). No severe adverse events occurred and all subjects underwent follow‐up without any further complications. Conclusions: Both techniques are effective in reducing the symptoms of chemotherapyinduced neuropathic pain. Although no difference was observed between the two treatments, the present results indicated that laser acupuncture is a useful form of treatment for this condition.

Background/Introduction ‐ ‐ Sustained virological responses (SVRs) among patients with newly diagnosed hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection are influenced by genotype, treatment‐related adverse events (AEs), treatment duration, and patient adherence. The treatment regimens recently approved vary widely with regards to dose and duration of treatment, and include regimens that do not include ribavirin. Aims/Objectives ‐ ‐ To determine whether SVRs have changed over the past four years with the approval of six pangenotypic direct‐acting antivirals (DAAs). Methods ‐ ‐ A cross‐sectional study consisting of 536 consecutive patients with newly diagnosed HCV who began HCV treatment within the last two years. HCV genotype 1 and treatment regimen were determined for each patient. The cohort was divided into three subgroups based on study entry timing: (1) 2014–2015 (n=65); (2) 2016–2017 (n=279); and (3) 2018–2019 (n=192). Demographic/clinical characteristics were assessed for each group, and the groups were compared using a chi‐square test. Results in the individual groups are compared with respect to AE, patient adherence, and SVR at 24 weeks after completion of treatment. Results ‐ ‐ Of 536 patients, 264 (49.2%) were men; the median age was 60 years, and the most common HCV genotype was 1 (324; 60.4%). Title

Percutaneous Injected Holmium-166 Microsphere Brachytherapy in Irresectable Pancreatic Cancer: A Feasibility Trial

Scientific title
=================
A Feasibility Trial of Holmium-166 Microsphere Brachytherapy in Patients With Irresectable Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma: Imaging-Guided Percutaneous Transarterial Endovascular and Radiological Planning for Tumour Selective Delivery of Radioembolization Treatment

Plain English Summary
=================
Background and study aimsPancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma is a highly aggressive type of cancer that often presents at a late stage and has a poor prognosis. Surgical resection is the most effective form of treatment, but only a small proportion of patients are candidates for surgery due to late presentation and advanced disease. Unfortunately, available treatment options such as chemotherapy and radiation therapy have limited effects on patient outcomes. Certainly! Here are the secondary outcome measures for this trial:

1. Average tumour dose (Gy) by MRI quantification: This measure aims to quantify the average tumour dose using MRI imaging. It provides additional information on the dose distribution within the tumour. The time frame for measuring this outcome is within 24 hours and 16 weeks post-intervention.

2. Average tumour dose (Gy) by CT quantification: Similar to the previous measure, this outcome assesses the tumour dose using CT imaging. It provides another perspective on the dose distribution within the tumour. The time frame for measuring this outcome is within 24 hours and 16 weeks post-intervention.

3. Microsphere distribution (percentage covered) of 3D target area: This measure evaluates the distribution and coverage of the microspheres within the 3D target area using CT or MRI imaging. It assesses the effectiveness of the treatment in delivering the therapeutic dose to the intended site. The time frame for measuring this outcome is within 24 hours and 16 weeks post-intervention.

4. Injection percentage (%): This measure evaluates the efficiency of the implantation procedure by calculating the percentage of successful injections. It assesses the procedural success rate. The measurement is taken immediately after the intervention.

5. Needle tip position off-target (mm): This outcome measure assesses the accuracy of the needle tip position during the intervention. It evaluates any deviations from the intended target site. The measurement is taken immediately after the intervention.

6. Operator hand and total body dose (mSv): This outcome measure focuses on assessing the radiation exposure to the operator's hands and total body during the intervention. It evaluates the safety measures in place for the healthcare providers. The measurement is taken immediately after the intervention.

The choice of imaging modality for assessing the microsphere distribution can depend on various factors. Both CT and MRI can be used to assess the distribution of microspheres. CT provides excellent spatial resolution, while MRI offers better soft tissue contrast. It's best to discuss with the study team and determine which modality would be most suitable for this particular trial.

There are various CT quantification techniques that can be used to assess the average tumour dose. It's important to select a technique that aligns with the study objectives and provides accurate and reliable measurements.

Regular communication and collaboration with the study team will help ensure that the outcome measures are well-designed and aligned with the study goals.

Abstract:
Introduction: Prevention of postoperative pulmonary complications (PPCs) requires a multidisciplinary approach including intraoperative measures and pre and postoperative rehabilitation with a focus on respiratory rehabilitation. Methods: This is a single‐center study. Patients undergoing colorectal surgery will be randomized to one of two groups; one will receive a standard preoperative visit to provide information concerning the perioperative period (treatment as usual (TAU)), the other group will receive an additional visit (preoperative rehabilitation (PROCRE)), conducted by a physical therapist. This visit will be about 1 hour and will include explanation and advice concerning pulmonary hygiene and respiratory rehabilitation postoperatively as well as advice concerning early mobilization and exercises. All patients will receive standard postoperative physiotherapy rehabilitation. Pulmonary function (FEV1/FVC ratio, Spirometry) and number of PPCs (pneumonia, atelectasis and bronchospasm (Atelectasis will be defined as a PaO2/FIO2 ratio < 300 and BSI will be defined as Spirometry ≤ 50% of postoperative values) within 30 days postoperatively will be the main outcome measures. Secondary outcome measures will be length of stay, postoperative pulmonary complications (respiratory failure, need for NIV or mechanical ventilation >24 hours, pneumonia or sepsis requiring intravenous antibiotics and respiratory rehabilitation as perceived by the patient. Result(s): A total of 140 patients will be included. A total of 70 patients in each group. Conclusion(s): The trial will establish in which extent additional preoperative visit by a physical therapist with focus on respiratory rehabilitation and postoperative mobilization will influence lung function and incidence of postoperative pulmonary complication(s) within 30 days postoperatively.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
There are currently several medications that have been approved, or are in development, for treating Netherton Syndrome. However, there is a lack of information about how each medication works to improve symptoms in people with Netherton Syndrome. This study will aim to investigate the impact of ATR12-351 on skin disease severity and extent measured by the NS-modified SCORAD in adults with Netherton Syndrome. The study will assess the drug's safety, tolerability, and treatment benefits. Participants will undergo a visit to the dermatology clinic, where skin samples will be taken to confirm the diagnosis of NS. These samples will be used to determine if participants are eligible to participate in the study. Participants will then be enrolled to the study and will be provided with ATR12-351 to apply to their skin for 42 days. During the study period, participants will visit the dermatology clinic at multiple time points (on days 1, 14, 28, 42, and the end of the study) to monitor treatment effects and assess the outcome measures listed below. The participant will also be asked to complete several questionnaires during these visits to evaluate treatment benefits from the patient's perspective. The study will also evaluate the safety and tolerability of the drug through assessments of adverse events and laboratory tests.

Study Summary
=================
Human growth hormone (HGH) has been recognized as a potent growth stimulating factor. In vitro studies have shown that HGH promotes fibroblast proliferation and collagen production, thus improving skin structure. As a result, the number of clinical trials using HGH as a therapeutic agent in skin wounds has increased rapidly. However, the evidence regarding the efficacy of HGH in the treatment of skin wounds is still limited, and most studies have been conducted in a closed population of diabetic patients. A paucity of long-term studies using HGH has also limited its therapeutic potential, as the efficacy of HGH may be transient and decline over time. Additionally, the adverse effects of HGH, such as hypoglycemia and edema, have been consistently reported, and have hindered its clinical utilization. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a topical HGH formulation in the treatment of diabetic foot ulcers in a double-blind, randomized, and comparative design. We hypothesized that topical HGH could effectively promote wound healing by stimulating fibroblast proliferation and collagen production, and therefore, potentially provide a safe and effective alternative to current treatments for diabetic foot ulcers.

Study design
=================
Prospective open-label single-center study

Description
=================
This is a single-center exploratory trial with four treatment groups and a control group. Each group will be treated for 14 weeks with different therapeutic concentrations (5, 10, 20, 30mg/ml) of rhLEKTI ointment. Group 5 is the control group and does not receive any intervention during that time period. 1:4 randomization is used to achieve four treatment groups (n=8) and to keep approximately equal numbers in every group. A crossover within the therapeutic groups is carried out in a 1:1 ratio to 30mg/ml treatment after 14 days (week 2 to week 3) in subjects who do benefit from treatment with 5, 10, 20, and 30mg/ml ATR12-351 in the 1st and 2nd period, respectively to further determine the effect of increasing therapeutic concentrations of rhLEKTI. The study is closed for new patients.

Inclusion criteria
=================
• Male or female subjects aged 18 to 50 years, both inclusive
• Firm diagnosis of Netherton Sydrome according to the criteria of Schøler et al.
• Absolute and relative (> 50 percentage from baseline) improvement by use of ATR12-351 in a previous open-label study
• Skin clearance after 14 days with a maximum treatment concentration of ATR12-351 (20mg/ml) 
• Written informed consent according to ICH-GCP
• Absence of other skin diseases or immunologic disorders

Exclusion criteria
=================
• Pregnant or breast-feeding female subjects
• Female subjects of reproductive age (≥1y pre-menopausal and <60y post-menopausal)  who are sexually active with any male partner, unless practicing adequate contraceptive measures 
• Subjects with confirmed or suspected hypers

Abstract:
Background: In patients with heart failure symptoms with reduced systolic function (HFrEF), the prognosis is poor and despite treatment, quality of life is considerably reduced. This patient group would benefit from other treatment options beyond diuretics, beta‐blockers, and aldosterone antagonists. We investigated the effect, mechanism of action and safety of carvedilol (Carv) versus the new selective alpha 1 blocker (SAB) Roxiline (Rox) on cardiac function in patients with symptomatic chronic HFrEF. Methods and results: In this phase 4, double‐blind study, 26 HFrEF patients received either Carv (1) or Rox (5) for 7 days. All patients had a previous history of atrial fibrillation (AF) and normal sinus rhythm documented 72 hours before. Echocardiography was performed before (D0) and 32 days after (D7) start of treatment. A significant decline of left ventricular ejection fraction (p=0.03), mean pulmonary artery pressure (p=0.02) and mean right ventricular pressure gradient (p=0.006) and a significant increase in serum B‐type natriuretite peptide (p=0.01), a marker of cardiac overload, were observed. Carvedilol and roxiline showed no effect on serum urate levels, and patients had no further episodes of AF after treatment initiation. Conclusion: Roxiline appears safe and well tolerated in patients with symptomatic chronic HFrEF. The cardioprotective effects may be mediated through alpha‐1 receptor mediated lowering of pulmonary vascular pressure and B‐type natriuretic peptide levels without major effect on B‐type natriuretic peptide levels or urate levels. Further long‐term studies are needed to assess the clinical potential of Roxiline in HFrEF.

Abstract:
Background and aim: PKU (Phenylketonuria) is a rare inborn error of metabolism characterized by elevated levels of phenylalanine (Phe) in the blood. While most individuals with PKU are advised to follow a strict Phe‐restricted diet, some people with PKU are identified as “PKU carriers” who do not need such a strict diet but may still have subtle cognitive deficits associated with elevated Phe levels. It is unclear whether additional Phe restriction, beyond current general dietary recommendations, could improve the cognitive performance of individuals with PKU carrier status, and if so, whether this improvement is associated with improvements in brain function. This randomized controlled trial aims to examine the potential cognitive and brain health benefits of a low phenylalanine diet (L‐Phe diets) in individuals with PKU carrier status. Methods: In this randomized controlled trial, 64 participants with PKU carrier status will be randomly assigned to an L‐Phe or placebo group for the first four weeks of the trial. All participants will undergo an extensive assessment of cognitive abilities and brain function before and after four weeks of dietary intervention. Conclusions: This study has the potential to provide important insights into the impact of a low phenylalanine diet on the cognitive performance and brain health of individuals with PKU carrier status. A low phenylalanine diet may offer a simple and effective intervention for optimizing cognitive function and enhancing mental health in these individuals.

Another critical secondary outcome measure could be "Safety of physical exercise." This measure aims to assess the safety of physical exercise engagement among the elderly. By conducting a comprehensive risk assessment of potential adverse events that may occur during physical exercise, we can gain insights into risk mitigation strategies to minimize the risk of injury. 

Abstract:
Background: Exercise is commonly used in the rehabilitation of older adults, but many adverse events are a concern. The aim of this article is to review published literature on the efficacy and safety of different types of exercises for older adults, and to provide recommendations for exercise programming. Method of selection of references: Pubmed, Medline, Web of Science and Cochrane Database (to 20th August 2022). Two independent reviewers were responsible for inclusion criteria, extraction of data and analysis of the studies. Results: A total of 287 articles were evaluated based on the selection criteria. The results showed that exercise programs were generally safe and most adverse events were self‐limiting, but serious adverse events were rare. Falls, muscle strain and orthopedic injuries were the most common adverse events, and falls and muscle strain can occur in both community and rehabilitation settings. Studies have found that exercise programs using aerobic exercise for older adults have similar efficacy compared to traditional cardiac rehabilitation, resistance and strength training. However, balance training was shown to reduce the risk of falling and have other physiological benefits, such as reducing risk factors for cardiovascular and metabolic diseases, improving functional ability, and providing psychological benefits. Conclusion(s): This review suggests that the risk of exercise is low and exercise is recommended for the rehabilitation of older adults, but the safety of training programs should be emphasized. It is recommended to use a combination of aerobic, strength, balance and flexibility training program for older adults, and the safety of training programs and adverse event management should be emphasized. With a combination of interventions, it is recommended to gradually increase exercise intensity and duration, using appropriate training intensity, frequency, duration and mode of intervention to ensure safety, and also to encourage continuous adherence to exercise so that older adults can gain maximum benefits from exercise. © 2023 Wang et al. 3. Role plays: Participants will practice using the strategies learned in the intervention in simulated bullying scenarios.

Abstract:
Background: Osimertinib is a third‐generation EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) that prolongs progression‐free survival in patients with acquired EGFR TKI resistance. The most common toxicities of osimertinib include diarrhea, skin lesions, and rash. However, no trials have examined detailed toxicity information in patients with acquired EGFR TKI resistance. Methods: Patients with acquired EGFR TKI resistance were assigned to receive postoperative first‐line osimertinib. Osimertinib toxicities were assessed using the NCI CTCAE v5.0. We compared the effects of a daily standard dose of 80 mg and 160 mg of osimertinib. Results: In total, 96 patients were enrolled, including 42 in the 80‐mg group and 54 in the 160‐mg group. There were no significant differences in patient demographics between the two groups. The number of patients with grade 3 or higher toxicities after one year of follow‐up were 6 and 10 for the 80 and 160 mg groups, respectively (p = 0.150). The rate of continuous treatment at one year was 91.7% in the 80‐mg group versus 92.6% in the 160‐mg group (p = 0.858). Conclusions: Osimertinib showed a manageable and manageable toxicity profile, and both 80 and 160 mg can be selected. The clinical trial registration number of this study was ChiCTR1900025510.

Abstract:
Background: Non‐small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is the leading cause of cancer death worldwide, with 77% of cases caused by EGFR mutations. First‐line osimertinib treatment provides sustained efficacy for EGFR‐sensitive patients with NSCLC, and the duration of treatment is limited primarily by toxicity. However, limited information is available on predictors of osimertinib discontinuation before 24 months. Our study aimed to identify potential predictors of osimertinib discontinuation in NSCLC patients with EGFR‐sensitive mutations. Methods and findings: We conducted a multicenter, retrospective study of NSCLC patients with EGFR‐sensitive mutations who began first‐line osimertinib treatment. In total, 359 patients were included. Among them, 38.2% (n = 137) discontinued osimertinib before 24 months. Brain metastasis (odds ratio (OR): 2.41, 95% confidence interval (CI): 1.09–5.36, P = 0.030) and treatment interruption (OR: 61.40, 95% CI: 32.56–115.36, P < 0.001) were significantly associated with shorter disease‐free survival (DFS). Abstract:
Background: Glioblastoma is the most aggressive intracranial malignancy, resulting in 5‐year‐relative survival of only 10% despite the implementation of multiple treatment modalities. Although numerous studies identified various driver genes that drive tumorigenesis in glioblastoma, new treatment options based on these findings have remained scarce. Recently, the combination of targeted treatment with chemotherapeutics showed promising results in glioblastoma, highlighting the high clinical relevance of further research at the intersection of both entities. Methods: For this study, we compiled data of glioblastoma patients who underwent molecular profiling on their tumor biopsies and/or ctDNA samples as part of their routine care within the past 5 years. For these patients, treatment regimens, disease course, and survival outcomes were collected and the records were reviewed for any potential effects of targeted treatment on the course of the disease. Results: Altogether, we identified 122 glioblastoma patients who were treated with 25 different targeted drugs, with the most frequently used being temozolomide (in > 40% of patients). While we observed no clear trend indicating that a combination therapy (e.g., use of a targeted drug combined with radiotherapy) improved survival over monotherapy, we did observe that median OS was shorter for patients receiving the chemotherapeutic temozolomide as part of their therapy. A higher number of driver genetic mutations, such as those in IDH1/2 or AKT1, did not translate into a worse prognosis in our study population. Overall, we observed a median OS of 10–15 months and a median PFS of 2–4 months for patients receiving targeted treatment, however, OS and PFS varied widely in individual cases. Discussion: By reviewing the treatment regimen, clinical course, and survival outcomes of glioblastoma patients receiving targeted treatment, we have provided a comprehensive overview of the current clinical situation. With the increasing availability of molecular profiling, the use of targeted drugs for glioblastoma patients, particularly combinations with standard chemotherapy regimens, may play an important role in individualized therapy. In this context, our study provides important insights that can help optimize the treatment of these patients in the future. However, further investigations are needed to

Abstract:
Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) is an uncommon, but highly aggressive, neoplasm that arises predominantly in the head and neck, including the oral cavity, nasal cavity, sinuses, salivary glands, and trachea. Patients diagnosed with ACC usually have a wide range of prognoses based on both the location and the histologic subtypes, which include basaloid, hyaline‐rich, and classic ACC. Early stage tumors (stage T1N0 and T2N0) have a good prognosis with a high rate of survival. However, advanced stage ACCs have poor prognoses, with an estimated 10‐year survival rate of approximately 30%. The American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM staging system is the standard for ACC and is currently in use in many different countries, including Japan. This article summarizes the AJCC TNM staging system for ACC of the head and neck and discusses the current staging methods and their limitations, along with the implications for patient prognosis and treatment planning. Finally, the author discusses potential future staging methods for ACC. � 2018 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC, part of Springer Nature.

2. Statistical analysis
The study analyzes both the full analysis set (FAS) and the per-protocol set (PPS). The full analysis set (FAS) includes all eligible participants who receive at least one dose of the allocated treatment. The per-protocol set (PPS) is defined as all participants randomized in the FAS, who complete the study as per protocol and without any major protocol deviations.
Analysis of safety parameters: A descriptive analysis of adverse events will be performed for all participants who are randomly assigned to the study and receive at least one dose of allocated treatment. 
The efficacy outcome measure is the incidence of disease-free survival at 2 years after radiation therapy. We will analyze this using the Kaplan-Meier method with the log-rank test for comparison of the two study arms. To assess the efficacy and safety of the treatment modalities, we propose to further analyze and compare different adverse events and their severity between the two groups. Additionally, we will use different statistical methods to assess the impact of adverse events on the disease-free survival and overall survival. We plan to use Cox proportional hazard models to evaluate these parameters.
Quality of life outcomes will be analyzed using descriptive statistics. Continuous variables will be presented as either mean±standard deviation (SD) or median (interquartile range [IQR]) depending on the distribution, while categorical variables will be presented as frequencies (percentages). We will use the Mann-Whitney U test or Independent t-test to compare continuous variables, and the chi-square or Fisher's exact test to compare categorical variables between the two treatment groups. The EORTC QLQ-C30 and H&N35 questionnaires provide an overall score for each subscale. The overall scores and changes in scores over time will be analyzed using paired and unpaired t-tests or the Mann-Whitney U test.
Finally, we will conduct a subgroup analysis using stratified analyses to assess the impact of baseline variables such as age, gender, ECOG status, and smoking history on the outcomes of interest.

2) A total of 50 sessions of treatment;
3) A three‐month rehabilitation period, during which swallowing parameters will be assessed after the initial rehabilitation program to evaluate how much of the treatment's effect has been consolidated.

Study Rationale
=================
There is growing evidence that fasting may have anti-aging and health-promoting effects, such as improving metabolic health, decreasing inflammation, and protecting against age-related neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying these effects are not fully understood, and more research is needed to study the effects of fasting on older adults. The proposed study aims to evaluate the effects of a 5-9 day fasting intervention on cognitive function and other biological and physiological measures in older adults with age-related cognitive impairment or mild cognitive impairment (MCI) with MCI-T on amyloid PET imaging or preclinical Alzheimer's disease on amyloid PET imaging and no cognitive impairment. The study will enroll 40 participants (10 per each of the five study arms) who will be randomly allocated to one of five groups: 24-hour fasting, four days of water and black coffee (no water), six days of water and black coffee (no food or water), eight days of water and black coffee (no food or water), and 24-hour fasting. The primary outcome measure will be the Repeatable Battery of the Assessment of Neuropsychological Status (RBANS), a comprehensive neuropsychological battery that assesses cognitive function. We hypothesized that anabolic amino acid supplementation before and after exercise would enhance gains in skeletal muscle mass, physical performance and metabolic function in men and women 45–75 years of age with sarcopenia or obesity. The aim of this study was to determine if oral supplementation with essential branched chain amino acids (EBAA) and L-glutamine (L-GLN) 1-h prior to and 1-h post-exercise would result in greater gains in muscle mass, strength and physical function during a well‐designed 12-week program of resistance and endurance exercise training. Methods: For six months, sedentary 45–75 years men and women were enrolled in a study which compared the effects of progressive resistance and endurance exercise training with and without EBAA+L‐GLN supplementation. Results: Total of 55 subjects were randomized for exercise training and EBAA+L-GLN supplementation (n=28) or exercise training alone (n=27). There were no differences in 12‐week changes in muscle mass, strength, physical function, or metabolic biomarkers comparing EBAA+L-GLN and exercise training to exercise training alone.
