Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Background: The prevalence of postpartum depression is high, which has a significant impact on the mental health of women and their families. The current study aims to develop a new intervention, based on cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), that can be delivered to women during the first weeks after childbirth to reduce the risk of postpartum depression. Hypothesis: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)-based intervention can reduce depressive symptoms in women during the first weeks after childbirth. Methods: In this experimental study, 160 women will be selected via convenience sampling during the postpartum period (within 12 weeks after giving birth). The eligibility criteria for the study include having a newborn, being at least 12 weeks along in pregnancy or having had a child previously, not having been diagnosed with depression/anxiety, and lack of participation in the study before. The intervention will be based on the CBT method and include ten sessions, each consisting of group meetings with 8-12 people, lasting approximately one hour. The meetings will be held online via the Zoom videoconference platform and will take place weekly, at 5:30 to 6:30 pm. The research will consist of three parts: the pre-test, intervention, and post-test. The pre-test and post-test data will be collected through a structured questionnaire, and the CBT intervention will be based on group meetings, with group-based exercises, group discussions, behavioral activation, relaxation exercises, cognitive restructuring, and problem-solving strategies.

Intervention 1: Patients in the treatment group will receive two interventions:1. Brief intervention: This will involve a one-session, 45-minute intervention delivered by a healthcare professional trained in brief motivational interviewing. During this session, the patient will be provided with a brief feedback about the severity of their diabetes-related distress and depression. They will be assisted in identifying their barriers and motivators for diabetes self-management and setting individualized goals for improvement. The session will conclude with a discussion of potential strategies to help the patient reach their goals and recommendations for follow-up care.2. Follow-up intervention: This will involve monthly self-management phone calls conducted by a trained healthcare professional to evaluate the patient's progress, provide ongoing support and encouragement, and adjust their treatment plan as needed. These phone calls are expected to last 15-20 minutes, depending on individual preferences and requirements. We believe that these interventions will result in improved adherence and clinical outcomes, such as glycemic control and overall disease management.

Intervention 2: Patients in the control group will receive standard care, which generally involves providing patients with diabetes education and tools to help them manage their condition, including self-monitoring of blood glucose and the use of hypoglycemic medications.

Intervention 3: Patient in the treatment group will receive one session of motivational interviewing conducted by a healthcare professional trained in the use of the diabetes distress scale. During this session, the patient will receive a brief feedback on their diabetes distress level and receive motivation for self-management.The session will be followed by monthly follow-up phone calls to evaluate the patient's progress, provide ongoing support and encouragement, and adjust the treatment plan as needed.

Abstract:
PURPOSE: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of aflibercept combined with FOLFIRI as a preoperative treatment in rectal adenocarcinoma (RAC).METHODS: A preplanned nonrandomized study was conducted. Nine patients with stage III RAC treated with FOLFIRI and 2 mg aflibercept b.i.w. were included. The primary endpoint was the frequency of downstaging from the initially assessed T4 to T2‐T3 (defined as "early" downstaging).RESULTS: Early downstaging occurred in 2 cases (22%). The rates of downstaging to T0‐T3 were 10% and 19%. In all, 45% of the patients had tumors that were downstaged or completely resected (CR or PR) after preoperative treatment with aflibercept plus FOLFIRI. A total of 8 cases (88%) experienced an adverse event (AE) or serious adverse event (SAE) during the study, which mostly were gastrointestinal AEs, but no grade 3/4 events occurred. Two patients interrupted treatment.CONCLUSIONS: These data provide evidence that the combination of aflibercept and FOLFIRI could be considered as a preoperative chemotherapy treatment. However, further randomized clinical trials are needed to establish this as a standard of care.

Brief Summary
-----------------

Abstract:
Purpose: To perform a meta‐analysis of randomized controlled trials to determine whether exercise improves functional performance of multiple sclerosis (MS) patients. Methods: CINAHL, Medline, and EMBASE were searched from the year 1966 to November 2020. The randomized controlled trials (RCTs) were included if: they compared exercise therapy with no intervention; and the primary outcome was functional capacity. A pooled effect size was calculated using the random‐effect estimation, with a mean difference (MD) and 95% confidence interval (CI). Results: Ten RCTs met the eligibility criteria and contributed data to the meta‐analysis. These trials involved a total of 326 patients (1,652 patients in the intervention group and 1,614 in the control group). A pooled effect size analysis with a random effects model showed that exercise therapy had significantly better effects than the control group in both the motor (MD: ‐0.07; 95% Cl: ‐0.15, ‐0.00, P = .04) and functional (MD: ‐0.16; 95% Cl: ‐0.25, ‐0.06, P = .0009) domains. The overall effect favoring exercise in MS patients was 0.03 with a 95% Cl from 0 (P > .05). Conclusion: Our results suggest that exercise therapy may improve motor function and functional status in MS patients. Further studies with higher‐quality RCTs are needed to better assess the benefits of exercise. [Figure presented]

groundtruth: Of course! The secondary outcome measures include several aspects of mobility and quality of life. Let's go through each one. The first secondary outcome measure is "Gait speed-10MWT." This measure focuses on assessing the effect of Ekso facilitated training on gait speed in PWPD using the 10 Meter Walk Test (10MWT). We will measure improvements in gait speed in meters per second.

Gait speed will be assessed at multiple time points, including baseline, re-evaluation (5 weeks), discharge (8 weeks), and follow-up (20 weeks). This allows us to evaluate the sustained effects of the Ekso therapy on gait speed over time.

The other secondary outcome measures are "Gait endurance-6MWT," "Dynamic balance," "Functional strength-5xSTS," "Quality of Life-WHOQOL-BREF," and "Fall risk." 

For "Gait endurance-6MWT," we will assess the change in meters walked during the six-minute walk test (6MWT). This measure helps us determine the effect of Ekso facilitated training on gait endurance.

For "Dynamic balance," we will use the Functional Gait Assessment (FGA) to assess improvements in dynamic balance. The FGA is measured on an ordinal scale ranging from 0 to 30.

"Functional strength-5xSTS" focuses on evaluating the effect of Ekso facilitated training on functional strength in PWPD. We will measure the time taken to complete the Five time sit to stand (5xSTS) assessment.

"Quality of Life-WHOQOL-BREF" will assess the effect of Ekso facilitated training on the participants' quality of life. We will measure improvements in the scaled score recorded in percentage using the World Health Organization- Quality of Life Brief (WHOQOL-BREF).

Lastly, "Fall risk" will be evaluated by measuring the changes in the Timed-up-and-go (TUG) score. This measure helps us assess the participants' risk of falls.

Similar to gait speed, the secondary outcome measures will be assessed at baseline, re-evaluation (5 weeks), discharge (8 weeks), and follow-up (20 weeks). This allows us to thoroughly evaluate the sustained effects of the Ekso therapy on gait endurance, dynamic balance, functional strength, quality of life, and fall risk.

Background. Antioxidant therapy, particularly vitamin E supplement, is beneficial for patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in attenuating oxidative stress and improving lung function. However, most of the published trials have been small and poorly designed. Objectives. We conducted a meta‐analysis of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) to examine whether vitamin E could reduce exacerbations and improve lung function in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Search strategy. We searched the Cochrane Controlled Trials Register (The Cochrane Library Issue 4, 2005), MEDLINE (1966 to January 2005), and EMBASE (1980 to January 2005) for randomized controlled trials of antioxidant supplementation (vitamins C, E, and beta‐carotene) in COPD. We included trials that compared patients randomly assigned to receive vitamin E supplementation to patients who received no antioxidant supplements. Selection criteria. The clinical assessment of COPD included dyspnea, cough, wheezing, and mucus, and the spirometric assessment of lung function included forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV(1)) and maximal mid‐expiratory flow rate (MMFR). Lung function and bronchodilator were recorded. Results. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this study is to study safety in subjects with mild to moderate chronic Hepatitis C who have successfully completed HCV treatment with sofosbuvir and daclatasvir (12 weeks of HCV treatment), and who have an HCV RNA < 15 IU/ml during treatment.

Detailed Description
-----------------
HCV treatment with direct-acting antiviral (DAAs) has changed the landscape of hepatitis C treatment. High cure rates are now the standard, but there are still a number of viral breakthrough cases, especially viral breakthrough that follows the cessation of DAA therapy. HCV viral breakthrough, especially following the introduction of DAA, is a significant cause of HCV recurrence. The emergence of resistant NS5A and/or NS3 variants appear to be the main cause of breakthrough during treatment. Detection of resistance variants that have persisted after treatment can also herald the emergence of resistance during follow-up. Currently it is necessary to perform a resistance test, based on the results of the test, to determine whether or not the patient should receive a regimen of a different kind of DAA therapy. However, the cost of resistance tests has been a barrier to the use of this technique, as resistance tests have been shown to be too expensive for use outside of research settings. This issue can be particularly important for patients who have failed to clear the virus after treatment. In this study we want to evaluate the presence of resistant NS5A/NS3 variants in 40 patients with HCV genotype 1a treated with 12 weeks of sofosbuvir and daclatasvir therapy. This study will take place at the UMCU (University Medical Center Utrecht), the Netherlands. A number of patients will be enrolled in the study using the electronic medical record at the Utrecht outpatient clinic for the treatment of viral liver disease.

Official Title
-----------------
Safety in Subjects With Chronic Hepatitis C Who Have Successfully Completed Anti-Viral Treatment With Sofosbuvir and Daclatasvir and Have an Undetectable HCV Viral Load

Conditions
-----------------
Hepatitis C

I appreciate you asking about the sample size calculations. In this clinical trial, with an alpha value of 0.05, a power of 0.80, we will need to include 71 patients in Group A and Group B, with a power of 0.80. 
	In general, we use sample size calculations to determine the number of participants needed to ensure the study has sufficient statistical power to detect differences between treatment groups. Our sample size calculation takes into account the alpha (type 1 error) and beta (type 2 error) values, which are used to determine the critical value for significance. A type 1 error is a false positive, where we reject the null hypothesis when it is actually true. A type 2 error is a false negative, where we fail to reject the null hypothesis when it is actually false. 			
	The power of the study is a measure of how likely the study is to accurately detect a difference between treatment groups. We typically set the power to 0.80, which indicates that there is an 80% chance of detecting a true effect when it actually exists. By setting the power to 0.80, we can be confident that our results are statistically significant. 
	Once we have determined the alpha and beta values, we can use this information to calculate the sample size needed for the study. Typically, we use software programs such as G*Power to perform a power analysis, which takes into account the statistical properties of the study, including the sample size, the effect size, and the number of groups in the study. 
	In our clinical trial, we will have two groups, and we will use the G*Power software to calculate the sample size needed for each group. The G*Power software will take into account the alpha value, the beta value, and the effect size of the study. The effect size is a measure of the treatment effect that we expect to see in the study. In this case, we expect that the treatment effects of using self etch adhesive and fluoride varnish will be similar, so we will set the effect size to be equal between the two groups.

Abstract
=================

Background
-----------------
Current knowledge:
Humeral shaft fractures are a common fracture type seen in our emergency department. Most are treated surgically. There are several treatment options, including closed reduction and percutaneous stabilization with intramedullary nail or plate fixation. Recently, the use of bending plates in three-part fractures has become increasingly popular. In these fractures, the humerus is shortened by 2 centimeters and then reduced and fixed with two additional screws in order to improve the biomechanical properties. Few studies have been published on the use of bending plates in the periprosthetic humerus. There is a risk that these plates are also ineffective in the elderly as they are osteoporotic and may also sustain bone loss around the implant. The use of new screw types (locking and cannonball compression screws) increases the stability of these osteosynthetic plates.

Hypothesis:
The hypothesis is that plate fixation of the humerus with use of new cannonball compression screws is a safe and effective treatment modality in the osteoporotic periprosthetic humeral shaft. 

Objective
-----------------
To assess the clinical outcomes after bending plate fixation of the prosthetic humeral shaft with cannonball compression screws.

Design
-----------------
This is a prospective observational cohort study with a 12 -month follow-up.

Abstract:
Background: Radiation therapy (RT) is a key component in the treatment of many cancers. Hypoxia, or lack of oxygen supply, is considered a major factor of cancer treatment resistance. To date, methods to target hypoxic tumor cells are limited. MRI sequences that enable the mapping of intra‐tumor hypoxia have shown potential for improving treatment planning and delivery. In this prospective, multicenter cohort study, we aim to generate a large dataset of MRI-based maps of intra‐tumoral hypoxia (iHyp) in patients undergoing RT for prostate cancer and to explore their prognostic and predictive potential. Methods: The study population will include male patients ≥18 years, with histologically confirmed adenocarcinoma of the prostate (T2‐T4), scheduled to receive RT with curative intent, and an ECOG performance status of 0 or 1. Patients will undergo MRI with diffusion weighted imaging (DWI) and T2* sequences. A third MRI sequence, diffusion‐weighted, MR thermometry, will be conducted in a subset of patients undergoing RT, to measure the tumor's metabolic response to therapy. Hypoxia, or lack of oxygen supply, is known to be a major factor in tumor resistance to radiotherapy. By generating 3D maps of intra-tumoral hypoxia and studying their evolution during treatment, we can better understand the impact of hypoxia on treatment outcomes. This information will help us adapt the doses of radiotherapy to each session based on the daily level of intra-tumor radiosensitivity. Ultimately, this outcome measure aims to improve treatment effectiveness and personalize treatment plans for each patient. 

Study design and objectives for multicenter, prospective, non-interventional, national clinical research: a national multicenter cohort to build an experimental platform of hypoxia imaging and its clinical application

Abstract:
Radiotherapy is an essential component of multidisciplinary cancer treatment, which requires effective evaluation of its effect on tumor control and patient risk stratification. However, current imaging approaches cannot provide quantitative information on hypoxia, a key prognostic parameter. The study aims to develop an imaging method to quantify hypoxia in patients undergoing radiotherapy for curative or palliative purposes. The experimental platform will consist of two main steps: a preclinical study aimed at validating the imaging method, and a clinical study to develop a quantitative imaging method in patients treated with radiotherapy. 


Introduction
Studies have found that a hypoxic tumor microenvironment can reduce the effectiveness of radiotherapy, and hypoxia may be one of the main reasons for radioresistance (Zhang et al. 2013; Huang et al. 2016). As a result, clinical management of patients with hypoxic tumors requires an accurate evaluation of tumor hypoxia. A hypoxic tumor microenvironment usually indicates that tumor cells are refractory to radiotherapy, and hypoxia is considered to be caused by the abnormal microenvironment of tumor vessels, which is characterized by an irregular blood vessel structure and high blood flow. Therefore, hypoxia assessment is expected to complement angiogenesis therapy, radiotherapy, and immunotherapy as a clinical treatment method for hypoxic tumors (Wang et al. 2015; Qin et al. 2019). Study
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This Phase 1b dose-escalation and expansion study will assess the safety and efficacy of RP103 in patients with advanced or metastatic renal cell carcinoma (mRCC). Patients will receive multiple treatments of RP103 in cycles of 18 days in the dose escalation phase (Phase 1) and two doses of RP103 in the expansion phase (Phase 2). Each cycle will consist of a 10 milligram (mg)/meter squared (m2) dose of RP103 followed by a one-week rest period. Blood samples will be collected at various time points throughout the study.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The primary objective of this study is to evaluate the safety and tolerability of RP103 in patients with advanced or metastatic cancer. The secondary objective is to assess the efficacy of RP103 in terms of objective response rate (including complete response, partial response, and stable disease), progression free survival (PFS), TTP, and OS. Exploratory objectives include assessing the effect of RP103 on cancer cell proliferation and apoptosis, as well as pharmacokinetic (PK) parameters. 10 patients will be enrolled in Phase 1 and treated with RP103 at a dose of 50 mg/m2. If fewer than 3 patients experience dose limiting toxicity (DLT), the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) will be determined at the beginning of Phase 2, and 3 additional patients will be enrolled at the same dose level. If more than 3 patients experience DLT, or if the MTD is not reached, the trial will be terminated. Phases 2a (interested patients 1 and 2 below) and 2b (interested patients 3 and 4 below) include a rolling design with a 50% dose reduction over four doses. groundtruth: Certainly! The measure description for TEAEs would be the presence of TEAEs, SAEs, and lab abnormalities, according to the National Cancer Institute (NCI) Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) Version 5.0. We will assess TEAEs from the time the patient signs the informed consent form (ICF) up to 90 (+7) days after the last dose of SOT201. This assessment will be conducted approximately up to 3 years.

For the secondary outcome measures, I propose the following measures based on the trial's objectives. We should include the characterization of the area under the curve (AUClast, AUCinf, AUCtau) of SOT201, as well as the characterization of the maximum concentration (Cmax), time to maximum concentration (Tmax), and pre-dose concentration (Ctrough) of SOT201. These measures will provide valuable pharmacokinetic data on the drug's exposure levels and absorption characteristics. Additionally, we should consider measures such as objective response rate (ORR), duration of response (iDoR), clinical benefit rate (iCBR), progression-free survival (iPFS), and incidence of anti-drug antibodies (ADAs) against SOT201. These measures will help us evaluate the drug's efficacy, disease control, and immunogenicity. What are your thoughts on these suggestions?

Certainly! Here are the details for each secondary outcome measure:

1. Characterization of area under the curve (AUClast, AUCinf, AUCtau) of SOT201: This measure will be calculated using the trapezoidal method during a dosing interval (tau). We will assess AUC values from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17.) until cycle 20.

2. Characterization of maximum concentration (Cmax) of SOT201: We will monitor the maximum plasma concentration observed from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17.) until cycle 20.

3. Characterization of time to maximum concentration (Tmax) of SOT201: This measure will assess the time taken for the drug to reach its maximum plasma concentration. We will evaluate Tmax from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17..) until cycle 20.

4. Characterization of pre-dose concentration (Ctrough) of SOT201: We will measure the pre-dose trough SOT201 concentrations from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17..) until cycle 20.

5. Objective response rate (ORR): This measure will assess the proportion of patients who have a confirmed complete response (CR) or a partial response (PR), as the best overall response (BOR) determined by the Investigator as per the Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) v1.1. We will evaluate ORR from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted for up to approximately 3 years.

6. Duration of response (iDoR): iDoR is defined as the time from the first documented evidence of confirmed CR or PR until progressive disease (PD) determined by the Investigator per RECIST 1.1 or death from any cause, whichever occurs first. We will assess iDoR from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted up to approximately 3 years.

7. Clinical benefit rate (iCBR): This measure will include confirmed CR or PR at any time or stable disease (SD) of at least 6 months determined by the Investigator per RECIST 1.1. We will evaluate iCBR from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted for up to approximately 3 years.

8. Progression-free survival (iPFS): iPFS is defined as the time from the date of the first administration of SOT201 to the date of the first documented disease progression determined by the Investigator as per RECIST 1.1 or death from any cause, whichever occurs first. We will assess iPFS from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted for up to approximately 3 years.

9. Incidence of anti-drug antibodies (ADAs) against SOT201: We will assess the incidence of patients with anti-drug antibodies from Day 1 until 30 (±2) days after the last dose of SOT201.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a prospective, parallel-group, randomized controlled trial in 30 patients admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) of Hospital San José Cisneros (HSCJ). The hypothesis is that non-invasive neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) of the tongue and masticatory muscles will improve airway protective reflexes in patients on invasive mechanical ventilation.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a prospective, parallel-group, randomized controlled trial in 30 patients admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) of Hospital San José Cisneros (HSCJ). A total of 30 patients will be enrolled in the study and randomly allocated to two groups: the intervention group (Group A - neuromuscular electrical stimulation) and the control group (Group B - no stimulation). The hypothesis is that non-invasive neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) of the tongue and masticatory muscles will improve airway protective reflexes in patients on invasive mechanical ventilation. This study will be composed of three phases: Phase I: A minimum sample of 6 patients will be recruited before the start of the study, with one subject per group, who will act as a pilot for Phase II. If the results in this pilot phase are promising, the second phase of the study will be performed (Phase II). In Phase II, a total of five participants will be enrolled and assigned to the two groups (Group A - n = 2 and Group B - n = 3). The objective of this pilot phase is to determine the feasibility of NMES implementation and the study itself. If the hypothesis is met in the pilot phase, another ten patients (Phase III) will be recruited (Group A - n = 4 and Group B - n = 6) to

Objective: To examine the association between the implementation of the COVID‐19 vaccination and the increase of influenza‐like illness (ILI) in pediatric patients attending 52 pediatric emergency departments (PEDs) in Japan in the weeks immediately following the start of vaccinations.Methods: We conducted a prospective study for influenza‐like cases of febrile patients over 36 months old who presented between November 2020 and May 2021 at each of the 52 PEDs participating in a network. After excluding incomplete cases, multiple testing was conducted to identify time periods in which statistically significant increases in weekly ILI incidence occurred. Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: To determine whether a multifocal electrical stimulation (MES) device significantly improves the functional recovery of patients after stroke or other neuromuscular disorders.DESIGN: Prospective and randomized.SETTING: An inpatient rehabilitation service and clinical laboratories in a university‐affiliated teaching hospital.PATIENTS: A total of 61 patients, all with a recent neurological injury, randomly assigned to treatment (29) or usual therapy (32) groups.INTERVENTION: Patients in the treatment group received MES therapy for 90 minutes, 5 days a week for 4 weeks. Their usual therapy continued as well.MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: Functional recovery, as measured by Fugel‐Meyer (motor) assessment before treatment, after treatment, and 12 weeks later.RESULTS: Patients treated with MES for 4 weeks were significantly better on Fugel‐Meyer motor assessment than those who underwent usual rehabilitation. The functional benefits lasted for 12 weeks after therapy ended. Analysis of the data revealed that only 2 patients in the treatment group had residual pain after 12 weeks.CONCLUSIONS: The results of this study suggest that MES is effective at improving the functional recovery of patients with neuromuscular disorders, and that this therapy may be less painful than conventional methods of treatment.

Abstract:
Background: In 2018, the HIPAA omnibus ruled that health care institutions could disclose protected health information for non‐research purposes, such as quality improvement. Objective: To determine the impact of adding a “care coordination” communication to patient's care between primary care physician visits by a social worker for adult patients seen >2 years in the outpatient primary care clinic of a safety net hospital in Central Texas. This randomized pilot RCT tested the ability of patient‐centered communication to improve outpatient clinical outcomes over a 9 month period. Methods: We used a novel randomized pilot trial to test in a patient subset (n=28) the impact of a care coordination communication (C3) from a licensed social worker over 9 months compared to usual care. C3 was performed prior to the PCP visit or after clinical history obtained at the office. Outcomes were patient reported symptoms: depression, smoking, alcohol and drug use, quality of life and medical record data: outpatient visits and hospitalization in a 9 month time period. Data were collected prior to the intervention and then at 9 months post intervention. Patient reported outcomes were collected online and an average value was calculated. Outpatient visit and hospitalization data was collected over a 9‐month period including data at the time of the first primary care visit and hospitalization if this occurred prior to starting the pilot trial. Results: C3 resulted in a non‐significant improvement in patient reported outcomes: 8 in the C3 group and 6 in the usual care group were depressed (z=1.606, p=0.109). In a subset (n=6) of the patients, a significant decrease in visits to PCP (12 vs. 3 visits, chi‐square 2.46 p=0.03), and emergency room visits (1 vs. 3, chi‐square 2.46 p = 0.04). Discussion: This study demonstrates a potential positive impact of a non‐research intervention on non‐research outcomes for underserved adult patients. We demonstrate for the first time a potential impact of social work communication

Introduction
Chronic pain is a prevalent problem, affecting more than 100 million Americans.1 It is defined as pain that lasts more than 3 months and affects a large part of the population2 and is one of the main causes of disability and loss of independence3. Chronic pain is also associated with a higher risk of developing drug addiction and overuse of analgesic drugs, which can lead to tolerance, dependence, and misuse.4 In addition, individuals with chronic pain are more likely to develop other mental health problems, including depression, anxiety, and sleep disturbances.2,5 These mental health comorbidities are often difficult to treat and may have a significant impact on patients' quality of life.6
The prevalence of chronic pain in patients with substance use disorders is higher than in the general population.7 Studies have shown that up to 85% of patients with drug dependencies have chronic pain.8 It is estimated that up to 81% of patients with alcohol use disorder and 95% of patients with opioid use disorder have chronic pain.9 Chronic pain is also more prevalent in patients with stimulant use disorder, such as cocaine and amphetamine use disorder, with a prevalence of up to 70%.10 These data suggest that chronic pain may be an important contributing factor to the development of substance use disorders11 and vice versa.12
There are many explanations for the high prevalence of chronic pain in patients with substance use disorders. First, these patients may be more likely to use substances to self-medicate their pain, which can lead to an increase in tolerance, dependence, and overuse.13 Moreover, chronic pain is often associated with increased stress and psychological distress, which can increase the risk of substance use.14,15 Finally, there are biological mechanisms linking chronic pain to substance use disorders, including changes in the brain's reward system and neurotransmitters.16

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Patients with progressive respiratory failure requiring oxygen supplementation due to severe bronchiectasis who cannot be treated with surgical treatment, and severe restrictive lung disease requiring lung transplantation were enrolled and randomly assigned to intervention and non-intervention groups respectively in this study. After 3 months of follow-up, the results of blood gas analysis, 6MWT (six-minute walk test), FVC ventilator expiratory volume, DLCO diffusion capacity, PFT (pulmonary function test), 6MWD (6-minute walk distance), and QOL (quality-of-life) were compared with those before administration.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Bronchiectasis is a complex disease with diverse etiologies and significant morbidity and mortality. Patients with progressive lung disease often require long-term oxygen therapy due to poor lung function or respiratory failure. Currently, lung transplantation is the only effective treatment for bronchiectasis-related progressive respiratory failure. However, few patients were able to undergo lung transplantation due to lack of donors, high medical risks, and the high economic burden of surgical treatment, which was not suitable for Chinese patients. The long-term use of high-dose prednisone in bronchiectasis patients with progressive lung disease could cause serious side effects such as osteoporosis, adrenal insufficiency, and diabetes. In our research group, a previous study revealed that human airway epithelial cells and human lung primary cells expressed 63+ in bronchiectasis. Recent studies have shown that 63+ Cells are mainly located in the airway of children with infectious bronchiectasis. We have developed the world's first 63+ cell therapy drug "Changbao-01", which

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Diabetes mellitus (DM) is a chronic disease that affects metabolism. Prolonged hyperglycemia can lead to serious complications such as coronary artery disease, peripheral artery disease (PAD), and stroke. In patients with DM and PAD, treatment for advanced peripheral artery disease (PAD) is challenging, and revascularization is not always feasible. There is a need for alternatives to treat these patients. Autologous transplantation of P63+ lung progenitor cells (LPCs) are currently being investigated as a potential option for these patients. Previous studies have shown promising results with autologous transplantation of LPCs in patients with coronary heart disease, which have potential similarities to PAD. However, the safety, feasibility, and effectiveness of autologous transplantation of P63+ LPCs in patients with advanced PAD remain unclear. Therefore, the aim of this study is to assess the safety, feasibility, and efficacy of autologous transplantation of P63+ LPCs in patients with advanced PAD. The specific goals are: To describe the safety and feasibility of autologous transplantation of P63+ LPCs in patients with advanced PAD assessed up to 6 months To evaluate the changes in transcriptomic profiles of LPCs after transplantation To assess the distribution and characteristics of P63+ LPCs in surgically resected lung tissue sections

model_response: Study Overview ================= Brief Summary ----------------- Infection with Salmonella is responsible for various intestinal and extraintestinal infections, manifested especially as intestinal bacteremia, sepsis, urinary tract infection, and extraintestinal focus infections (e.g., arthritis, endocarditis, osteomyelitis, meningitis). Infection with a Salmonella strain with resistance to antibiotics poses a serious threat, particularly because there are only a limited number of effective agents. Concurrent treatment of Salmonella infections with antibiotics and cidofovir has recently been used to combat resistance and infections that have failed to respond to the antibiotics. Preliminary human data regarding the efficacy of this treatment have been presented in a publication but have not been validated yet. Therefore, the purpose of the study is to demonstrate that treatment using cidofovir and antibiotics reduces the severity and duration of symptoms in patients with Salmonella infection and significantly reduces Salmonella levels in the blood and intestinal contents. interventional

Study design
=================
Randomization: Randomized, Blinding: Double blinded, Placebo: Not used, Assignment: Crossover, Purpose: Treatment, Randomization description: This study is a double blind randomisation, crossover study with a 5-week washout period in a Latin square design. Patients will be stratified based on body mass index (BMI), smoking status, and gender to ensure equal distribution of participants in each strata. Patients will be randomly assigned to one of the 12 possible sequences (ABCB, ABCC, BBCAA, BBCCA, BBACC, BCCAA, BCCAB, CABAB, CBCCA, CBCCB, CCABB, CCCBA, in which A=Group 1 (Intervention), C=Group 2 (Placebo) and B=Washout for 5-weeks, and Group 2 also includes the treatment (Vitamin E) while Group 1 (Intervention) also includes the Placebo (Buprenorphine). Randomization will be done as follows: Each sequence will be randomly assigned an odd number. A table of random numbers will be created for each level of stratifying factor (BMI, smoking status, and gender). The sequence corresponding to the specific random number will be allocated to a participant who fits into the stratum criteria.

Intervention
=================
Intervention 1: Intervention: The intervention is high-dosage Bipolar Vitamin E (400IE/day) for 8-weeks. Vitamin E 50mg tablet contains Bipolar Vitamin E (RRR-alpha tocopherol acetate: 200mg  + d alpha tocopherol acetate: 200mg), 1 capful/day (2 ml/day, 30 days in one box or one month supply) during breakfast for 8 week. Intervention 2: Placebo:  Buprenorphine 8mg tablet will be administered during breakfast, 3times a week (either 2-weekly or 8-daily) for 8-weeks.

Introduction/Objective: Che‐1 in the chromatin and epigenetic modifications is involved in tumor‐associated inflammation and tumor proliferation/survival. Methods: We conducted a prospective clinical trial and enrolled 255 newly diagnosed patients with MM, including 80 patients with high Che‐1 expression, between February 2021 until December 2021. Results: High Che‐1 expression was associated with International Staging System (ISS), renal function, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and prognostic markers (P53, p16, and TP53) levels. Abstract:
[BACKGROUND] Dysregulation of gene expression is a hallmark of multiple myeloma (MM) tumorigenesis. One mechanism underlying the aberrant gene expression pattern is through the recruitment of chromatin modifiers, such as the BET family of bromodomain proteins, to specific loci. Inhibition of BET family proteins has proven to be an effective therapeutic strategy for MM. Here, we assessed the use of Che‐1 inhibitors, a non‐BET specific family of Bromodomain proteins, as a therapeutic strategy for MM. [METHODS] In this prospective, single‐center, randomized, open‐label, Phase Ib clinical trial, 45 MM patients were screened and assessed for eligibility. Eligible patients were then randomized into the treatment and control groups, and two courses of MCP‐154 and venetoclax treatment was administered to the treatment group. [RESULTS] Our results revealed that the treatment group had a 20% improvement in progression‐free survival (PFS) compared to the control group, with no significant difference in overall survival. Additionally, there was a delay in the development of minimal residual disease in the treatment group, suggesting that treatment with Che‐1 inhibitors may delay the progression of MM in this patient population. [CONCLUSIONS] These results suggest that Che‐1 inhibitors may be a promising therapeutic strategy for MM patients. However, further studies are needed to determine the long‐term effects of Che‐1 inhibitor therapy on PFS and other clinical outcomes.

Abstract:
Objective: The aim of this study is to demonstrate that the use of a structured interview, designed to elicit a comprehensive range of symptoms, increases the number and type of self‐reported symptoms in cancer survivors. Method: 400 patients were recruited from the Cancer Support Group for follow up after treatment. The patients were randomized to two groups: an intervention or a control group. The intervention group received a questionnaire developed by the research group, the Control group received standard care. Both questionnaires covered physical, psycho‐social, and spiritual aspects of well‐ being. Results: 250 patients completed the questionnaires (intervention and control), which contained 200 question about symptoms, experiences, opinions, and beliefs. The intervention group identified a significantly higher number of symptoms than the control group, and their symptoms were more diverse. Additionally, the group also felt that the interview helped them to better express their concerns. Conclusion: Structured interviews are useful methods in clinical practice for assessing the health needs and concerns of oncology patients. They also help to identify previously unrecognized symptoms and psychosocial needs in this population. 2012 Springer‐Verlag Berlin Heidelberg ‐.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to compare the performance of the Velo-VAS system with the standard of care, which includes standard medical examinations, to assess its technical and clinical performance.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The primary objective of this clinical trial is to demonstrate proof-of-concept that the Velo-VAS system yields diagnostic cardiac output measurements that are non-inferior in accuracy to traditional cardiac output measurements, specifically the Fick method with the modified ThermoDilution/Purkinje Thermodilution technique. We hypothesize that when a standardized amount of contrast is injected through a hand-injected manual IV, cardiac output (in liter/min) as measured by the Velo-VAS system will have an agreement with that measured by the modified ThermoDilution/Purkinje Thermodilution technique. The secondary objectives of this trial are to estimate the overall time and number of invasive procedures required for obtaining cardiac output measurements through the standard of care and the Velo-VAS system. It is hypothesized that the time and number of invasive procedures required for obtaining cardiac output measurements through the standard of care and the Velo-VAS system, respectively, will not be different, and that the Velo-VAS system can provide greater diagnostic accuracy of cardiac output measurements compared with the standard of care.

Absolutely. Let's go through the secondary outcome measures one by one. The first measure is the Brief Pain Inventory - Numeric Rating Scale. This measure assesses pain intensity by asking about worst and least pain intensity in the past 24 hours, pain on average, and pain right now. It uses an 11-point scale, with zero representing 'no pain' and 10 representing the 'worst imaginable pain'. This measure has been shown to have excellent reliability and validity in people with knee osteoarthritis. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks and 3 months.

The next measure is the Modified Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI). This measure assesses the presence of comorbidities in participants, including knee osteoarthritis. The CCI has been widely used in various patient populations, including knee osteoarthritis. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks and 3 months.

The next measure is endogenous pain modulation, which assesses the efficiency of pain modulation mechanisms in individuals with knee osteoarthritis. We can use the conditioned pain modulation (CPM) testing method to evaluate this measure. By assessing the ascending measure of pressure pain threshold (PPT) at the anterior shin and the conditioning stimulus in the form of forearm ischemia, we can calculate the percent efficiency of CPM (%CPM) as PPT2/PPT1 multiplied by 100. This measure can provide insights into the neurobiological effects of the intervention. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks.

The other secondary outcome measures include pain interference, pain catastrophizing, Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS), Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), multi-joint pain assessed through a body diagram, knee awareness, functional leg strength, medication use, adverse events, patient global impression of change, blinding effectiveness, usefulness of the program for managing knee OA, frequency of the program, duration of the program, acceptability of the delivery of the brain stimulation, acceptability of the delivery of the yoga session of the program, likelihood of recommending the program to others with knee OA, burdensomeness of completing questionnaires and physical assessments, adherence rate, and rate of completion of home sessions. Each of these measures serves a specific purpose and provides valuable information on various aspects of the intervention and study outcomes.

Abstract:
The purpose of this study was to investigate changes in skeletal muscle composition and structure during high‐intensity, short‐duration physical training (HIIT) among middle‐aged women. The study sample consisted of 18 women (20‐35 years of age) with 4‐18 weeks inactive period. All subjects took part in a ten‐week HIIT program, which was designed according to their physical fitness. The intervention took place twice or three times per week, and consisted of 16 short bouts of high‐intensity running and 1 longer period of moderate‐intensity jogging or walking. The intervention was preceded by assessment of muscle strength and composition. Muscle strength was assessed by one repetition maximum (1RM) in leg press and in knee extension. Muscle structure and cross‐sectional area were assessed by B‐mode ultrasonography (US). The results indicated that there was an increase in muscle strength in both leg press and knee extension after the ten‐week HIIT program. In quadriceps muscles, muscle composition was not changed, but a trend towards reduction of the intramuscular fat content was observed. Muscle cross‐sectional area and fiber diameter were not changed. Muscle strength increased both in type I and type II fibers, whereas no changes were observed in muscle composition or structure in calf muscles. We conclude that HIIT is effective in improving muscle strength, independent of exercise modality or muscle type.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Sickle cell trait (SCT) carriers (defined as individuals who have only one copy of the haemoglobin S gene, and are heterozygous for sickle cell disease) were shown to be at a greater risk than the general population for sudden death occurring early in the course of moderate intensity physical exercise. However, the exact mechanism by which SCT carriers are at greater risk is not understood. There have been several studies that have used various imaging modalities to try and elucidate the mechanism, though with varying results. A systematic review by Hutchins et al. [6] of 11 studies identified 8 that had used cardiac MRI to identify SCT carriers. The results were conflicting with respect to the presence or absence of abnormalities in the cardiac chambers and the degree of myocardial cellularity that had been reported. Furthermore, 3 of the 4 studies that had evaluated the presence of an abnormal myocardial signal by use of inversion recovery sequences, found this abnormality in SCT carriers. There have also been a number of reports of late gadolinium enhancement (with and without hypertrabeculation) and T2‐weighted images suggestive of myocardial fibrosis in SCT carriers, as well as an increase in diastolic thickness on cardiac MRI, suggesting an increase in LV size [7]. This suggests that there is a need to better understand the underlying pathophysiological changes that occur in the heart in SCT carriers participating in exercise. It has also been postulated that cardiac MRI may be a better method than exercise stress test for detecting potential athletes at increased risk of sudden death [5]. Therefore, this study aims to determine, in SCT carriers enrolled in this study, the prevalence of subclinical cardiovascular abnormalities using cardiac MRI as compared with matched controls selected by age, gender and body mass index who do not have any known cardiovascular disorders.METHODS: Following ethical and research clearance, participants will be recruited through the use of advertising. In total, 50 healthy controls without any known cardiac pathology will be enrolled for this

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of choline PET/CT in predicting patient outcomes in patients with prostatic disease affected by metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Prostate cancer is one of the most common types of cancer among men in the United States. It's estimated that there will be 268,000 new diagnosis annually of prostate cancer, and nearly 34,000 deaths annually. Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC) is the most advanced stage of the disease and is responsible for the majority of deaths caused by prostate cancer. Early diagnosis and treatment of mCRPC are essential for improving patient outcomes and increasing survival rates. Choline PET/CT is a diagnostic test that uses a radioactive tracer called choline and a CT scan to identify prostate cancer metastases in the body. This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of choline PET/CT in predicting patient outcomes in patients with mCRPC. Specifically, we will assess how accurately choline PET/CT can detect the presence of prostate cancer metastases and whether it can predict the survival time of patients with mCRPC. We also aim to assess the feasibility and safety of choline PET/CT in patients with mCRPC. Our study will enroll up to 40 patients with mCRPC who have scheduled PET/CT scans as part of their routine clinical care. All patients will receive standard-of-care treatment for mCRPC during the study. All patients will undergo choline PET/CT scans, and their health outcomes will be monitored for up to three years after the scan.

Official Title

Evaluating The Effectiveness Of Choline PET/CT In Predicting Patient Outcomes In Patients With Prostatic Disease Affected By Metastasic Castration-resistant Prostate Cancer: A Proof-of-concept Study

Conditions
-----------------
Prostatic Disease, Castration-resistant Prostate Cancer

Study Rationale
=================
TKR is the standard treatment for osteoarthritis of the knee, and tranexamic acid is a medication used to prevent and control blood loss during surgery. However, TXA has only been used empirically before spinal anesthesia for knee arthroplasty. There are very few studies that have investigated the effect of different administration times for TXA, and there is still no gold standard for the use of TXA in knee arthroplasty. Therefore, by setting different TXA administration times and different dosage ratios of TXA to rocuronium, this study will assess the effectiveness of different administration methods and find the optimal method based on the recovery of blood coagulation (assessed on the basis of 7-point global assessment by nurses and surgeons) and coagulation function (coagulation parameters).

Abstract:
Background: Older adults 70+ account for approximately 55% of cancer incidence in Bangladesh, and nearly 70% of these individuals are socially disadvantaged. We hypothesized that a community‐based social support model (Peer Connect) could augment the cancer care team and support the psychosocial needs of socially disadvantaged older adults with cancer. Aims: This paper presents the methodology of a planned pilot study to evaluate the feasibility of a cluster randomized control trial (RCT) of an intervention aimed at improving the psychosocial outcomes of socially disadvantaged older adults with cancer in Bangladesh. Methods: The pilot study is a mixed methods study that will be conducted concurrently with the RCT. A total of four intervention arms (i.e., focus group‐based intervention, peer support‐based intervention, peer support plus community resource referrals plus social media‐based intervention, and standard of care) and two control arms (i.e., health facility‐based peer support‐only and no intervention) will be assessed. The pilot study aims to evaluate the feasibility of the RCT methodology using a 3 + 3 + 1 sampling process. Both quantitative and qualitative data will be collected. Data saturation and data triangulation will be used to ensure the representativeness of the findings. Statistical analyses will include descriptive analysis, thematic analysis, and correlation analysis. Results: The pilot study will recruit 2084 individuals, with 521 in the focus group‐based intervention arm, 521 in the peer support‐based intervention arm, 521 in the peer support plus community resource referrals plus social media‐based intervention arm, 521 in the health facility‐based peer support‐only arm, 260 in the no intervention arm, and a small sample (estimated 21‐49 in each arm) in the primary outcome study. Discussion: The peer connect model is hypothesized to effectively address the social determinants of health in the context of older adults with cancer in Bangladesh. The results of the planned pilot study will inform the design of a full‐scale RCT to evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention.

Duration of response (DoR) measures the duration of CR or PR in participants responsive to treatment. This is a useful measure to assess the durability of clinical benefit and the potential for long-term disease control. The assessment time frame for DoR is within 36 months.

Time to objective response (TTR) is the time from the start of treatment to the first time a participant attains a confirmed CR, PR, or SD. The assessment time frame for TTR is within 36 months.

For PSA response, we measure the percentage of participants with clinically meaningful prostate-specific antigen (PSA) response (defined as a reduction of PSA level of ≥50%) and the percentage of participants with biochemical progression-free survival, both at 6 months and overall. These measures provide valuable insights into how YL201 affects the changes in PSA levels and the course of disease progression in participants with mCRPC. Overall survival measures the time from the start of treatment to death from any cause and provides a comprehensive assessment of the long-term prognosis of participants. We will also be assessing the safety and tolerability of YL201, including adverse events, laboratory abnormalities, and vital signs.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The goal of the study is to study how the investigational medication called ASP9174, works in people with a history of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL), and to collect data on the safety of study drug. This is an exploratory study. Participants will be evaluated at baseline and on specified days thereafter. Blood samples will be drawn at baseline and at specified time points during the study to determine the effects of ASP9174 on various genes and proteins.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 2, open-label, non-randomized, multicenter exploratory study of the efficacy and safety of ASP9174 in subjects with a history of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL). Subjects who complete the study may receive compassionate use. Participants will be administered ASP9174 daily in 21-day treatment cycles for 5 consecutive cycles. After 5 cycles, each additional cycle will consist of 1 treatment day followed by 20 days off treatment. Participants will be evaluated at baseline and on specified days thereafter. Blood samples will be drawn at baseline and at specified time points during the study to determine the effects of ASP9174 on various genes and proteins. Participants will not be allowed on a new anticancer therapy until study completion. For participants who complete the study, subsequent therapy will be dependent upon the discretion of the investigator. If study drug is no longer required by the participant, the participant may be eligible to receive compassionate use of ASP9174 for up to 1 year after the last dosing visit.

Official Title
-----------------
A Phase II, Open-Label, Multicenter Exploratory Study of ASP9174 in Subjects With a History of Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma (NHL)

Conditions
-----------------
Malignant Lymphoma, Non-Hodgkin, Recurrent, Solid Tumor Neoplasms, Lymphoid Neoplasm

Intervention / Treatment
----------------

Introduction
=================
This work is to develop a novel method using machine learning to predict the presence of a cardiac infarction within 1 month after hospital discharge.

Objective
=================
We aim to develop a predictive model with performance metrics that are superior to the currently existing systems of the Netherlands. Secondary to this study objective is to describe predictors for 1-month risk of acute myocardial infarction, such as patient characteristics or biomarkers that can be measured during hospital stay.

Study design
=================
This study is a retrospective, observational study with a secondary analysis of a dataset.

Participants
=================
Admitted, non-emergent patients of the coronary care unit (CCU) of the Amsterdam University Medical Centers (UMC).

Inclusion criteria and exclusion criteria
=================
Inclusion criteria
- Admitted patient at the CCU of the AUMC during a period of one year from March 2018 to February 2019 or during a period of one year from March 2019 to February 2020.
Exclusion criteria
- Age < 18
- In-hospital mortality by the patient
- Exclusion is performed when patient characteristics are inaccesible

Primary outcome
=================
The primary outcome is the presence of an acute myocardial infarction within 1-month after hospital discharge.  An acute myocardial infarction is defined according to Troponin values being above the 99th percentile, according to local laboratory reference.

Secondary outcomes
=================
No secondary outcomes were defined

Data collection:
=================
Clinical data collected at patient level at baseline
- Age
- Gender
- Diagnosis before admission to the CCU (such as stable angina or stable heart failure)
- Admission type (routine/admission for unstable angina pectoris or heart failure)
- Laboratory tests (CK-MB, Troponin)
- Prognostic parameters (such as comorbidity and history of cardiovascular disease)
- Time between event and diagnosis

Abstract:
Fifty‐two children, aged 6‐17 years, were randomized to receive either a novel oral chemotherapy combination or 6 courses of intravenous cisplatin, 800 mg/m4. In the oral group 33 courses (66%) was administered; in the conventional group 40 courses (77%). There were no treatment‐related side effects in the oral group. Grade 4 thrombocytopenia was noted in 13/40 patients (33%) in the cisplatin group, and 1/33 patients (3%) in the oral group had grade 1 vomiting. One year disease‐free survival in the oral group was 86%; in the cisplatin group disease‐free survival was 74% (p, not significant). The 5‐year event‐free survival in the oral group was 53% versus 47% in the cisplatin group (p, .065). No difference in overall survival was detected. This oral chemotherapy regimen is well tolerated, with a comparable toxicity profile to that of cisplatin; it achieves similar disease control, longer event‐free survival, shorter hospitalization and is more readily administered in underdeveloped centers.

For Cohort 1, the secondary outcome measures include progression-free survival by disease site (bone only vs. non-bone), overall survival (OS), toxicity profile and safety (overall and disease site-specific), and changes in quality of life. For Cohort 2, the secondary outcome measures include progression-free survival by disease site (bone only vs. non-bone), OS, toxicity profile and safety (with special emphasis on flare reaction), and changes in quality of life.

Inclusion Criteria

1. Pathologically/cytologically confirmed diagnosis of prostate cancer at any stage;

3. Patients should have received prior prostate cancer radiotherapy, including but not limited to radiation therapy, brachytherapy, and/or external-beam/stereotactic radiation therapy;
4. Patients should have documented progression while receiving or after at least one prostate cancer therapy;
5. Life expectancy of > 3 months, as assessed by medical review;
6. Availability of 18F-choline PET imaging and appropriate scanner capability.
Minimum age: 18.0

Exclusion Criteria
=================
1. Prior curative-intent multimodal therapy (including surgical treatment);
2. Concurrent active malignancy or other condition that will significantly shorten the life expectancy of the patient;
3. Concurrent medical, psychiatric or addictive disease that, in the opinion of the investigator, would limit the ability of the patient to tolerate study procedures/treatment or would jeopardize the study objectives or interpretation of the data. Specifically, any psychiatric or addictive disorder should be in full remission at trial entry;
4. Presence of symptoms suggestive of brain or leptomeningeal metastasis, unless confirmed to be free from these disorders by repeat brain or leptomeningeal imaging.

Key secondary study objectives include the ability to detect the presence of metastatic prostate cancer, to determine the impact of FDG-PET-based metastasis on overall survival and quality of life, to describe the characteristics of FDG-avid lesions in different cohorts, and to evaluate the association between FDG-PET-2 and radiographic or PSA-based disease progression or death. 
Safety Objectives include the proportion of patients with serious adverse events, the proportion of patients with adverse events leading to study discontinuation, and the overall safety profile of FDG-PET-based MDRT in combination with standard treatments.

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Quality of analgesia measured by visual analogue scale: This measure rates pain severity from 0 to 10, with 0 representing no pain at all and 10 representing the worst intolerable pain. The assessment will be conducted during the first 48 hours.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Parameters of adequate ventilation and oxygenation: Monitoring the PaO2/FiO2 ratio and PaCO2 at regular intervals (1, 2, 3, 4, 8, 16, 24, 36, and 48 hours) to evaluate respiratory function.
- Sedation score using the Ramsay score: Assessing sedation levels every 8 hours for 48 hours using a scale ranging from 1 (agitated and uncomfortable) to 6 (asleep with no response to stimulation).

model_response: The incidence of treatment-emergent AEs, SAEs, and AEs leading to permanent treatment discontinuation will provide critical safety data to inform decision-making regarding the long-term safety of Itepekimab in patients with COPD. These outcome measures will assess the cumulative safety profile of Itepekimab over an extended period of time.

The secondary outcome measures include the evaluation of the efficacy of Itepekimab in participants with COPD over the extended treatment period. The following outcomes will be analyzed: lung function (measured using spirometry and diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCco) testing), COPD symptoms (measured using the Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease Assessment Test (C-CAT)), exacerbations of COPD, quality of life (measured using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ)), and healthcare resource utilization. These outcomes will provide information on the long-term efficacy of Itepekimab in improving lung function, reducing COPD symptoms, and improving quality of life for participants with COPD who have received prior treatment with Itepekimab.

Participation Criteria
=================
Eligibility Criteria
-----------------
Inclusion Criteria: Participants who have completed the treatment period of the clinical studies EFC16750 or EFC16819. These participants will have received Itepekimab or Placebo during the parent trial and will have been randomly assigned to one of the study arms in the extension trial. Participants must meet the following criteria: Able to speak, read, and understand English or Spanish and willing to comply with protocol procedures and study assessments. In addition, participants must have a documented diagnosis of COPD and have completed the treatment period of the parent trial without evidence of any significant changes in their health status.Exclusion Criteria: Participants with a history of significant medical conditions such as unstable angina, myocardial infarction, or heart failure within the last six months will be ineligible for enrollment. Study Plan

The secondary outcome measures are designed to provide additional information about the efficacy of Itepekenimab in improving symptoms and quality of life for participants with COPD. Secondary outcome measures are designed to evaluate the functional Itepekimab concentrations in serum, incidence of treatment-emergent anti-drug antibody responses, annualized rate of moderate-to-severe acute exacerbation of COPD (AECOPD), annualized rate of severe AECOPD, time to first moderate-to-severe AECOPD, time to first severe AECOPD, change from baseline of the parent studies (EFC16750, EFC16819) in Pre-BD and post-BD FEV1, the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) total score and domain scores, the EuroQol-5 Dimensions-5 Level (EQ-5D-5L) single index score, and the EuroQol Visual Analogue Scale (EQ-VAS). 2015-2022 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group 

The primary outcome measure is the incidence of treatment-emergent AEs, SAEs, and AEs leading to treatment discontinuation, which is essential in ensuring participant safety. The annualized rate of moderate-to-severe and severe AECOPD, time to first moderate-to-severe and severe AECOPD, and Pre-BD and post-BD FEV1 changes from baseline are related to the impact of COPD on participants' daily activities and overall quality of life. These outcome measures provide further insights into the efficacy of Itepekimab in managing COPD symptoms over an extended period of time.

Maintaining healthy blood glucose levels improves cardiovascular mortality, hospitalizations for heart failure, and stroke/TIA in patients with type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease. This meta-analysis will explore the hypothesis that cardiovascular risk reduction with good glycemic control is similar for people of all ethnicities.
INTRODUCTION
Background
Making informed choices about diabetes care requires a clear understanding of the risks and benefits of different interventions for achieving good glycemic control. In a recent meta-analysis examining cardiovascular risk factors in patients with type 2 diabetes, the investigators found that glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) was significantly lower in ethnic minorities. Non-white racial categories included Asian, American Indian/Alaska Native, African American, and other racial and ethnic minorities were included in the study. Although the absolute values were lower than those of other ethnic groups, there were no significant differences in 8-year cardiovascular mortality rate between black Caribbean and British whites or Hispanics and non-Hispanic whites.1 A recent study focusing on Asian Americans found that the highest HbA1c was in patients of South Asian and other Asian ancestry and the lowest in East Asian descendents.2 It has also been shown that African Americans are more insulin resistant than other populations, which may help explain why they have a higher risk for cardiovascular disease compared with other groups.3

PURPOSE OF THE RESEARCH
The purpose of this study is to conduct a meta-analysis to determine whether maintaining blood glucose levels in the normal range is as beneficial to patients with type 2 diabetes in terms of cardiovascular protection as it is to people of other racial and ethnic backgrounds who are less likely to develop cardiovascular disease.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of the study is to evaluate the effect of pre-training stretching on muscle function and strength among competitive ballet dancers before, during, and after a day of rehearsal during their three-hour ballet session.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Participants will perform an hour-long dance session followed by three hours of stretching. Five minutes before performing a task, participants will perform the standardized warm-up. After completing the task, they will repeat all measurements. Three hours later, the participants will repeat the same procedure. Participants will be asked to perform a full day of rehearsal in their usual way. They will measure their stretching performance before, during, and after the rehearsal. The participant's stretching routine will be recorded before, during, and after the rehearsal to ensure that it is done properly. The study will be conducted in a private room to prevent the participants from falling asleep. The stretching duration for each muscle group will be recorded, and a timer will be used to ensure that each muscle group is stretched properly. To record the duration of stretching, the researcher will observe the participant and ensure that the duration is not greater than 3 minutes. The participants will perform a set of tests to measure their performance. These include an arm hanging test, a squat strength test, and a plank strength test. The test procedure is fully detailed in the protocol. The participant will be asked to sit on a chair with their feet on the ground while their hands are holding onto a bar. These positions will be repeated for 30 seconds twice.

Official Title

The Effect of Pre-training Stretching on Muscle Function and Strength Among Competitive Ballet Dancers

groundtruth: Certainly! Let's start with the first outcome measure, retention. This measure evaluates the retention rate of the restorations using the United States Public Health Service criteria. It assesses any loss of restorative material. We'll need to evaluate retention from baseline to 24 months.

The scoring criteria for retention will be based on the United States Public Health Service criteria. We'll use the following scores: Alfa for no loss of restorative material, Charlie for any loss of restorative material. These scores will help us assess the effectiveness of the deep margin elevation technique in improving the stability and longevity of the restorations.

Marginal discoloration is an important measure to evaluate the sealing ability of the restorations and the presence of any gaps or defects at the restoration margins. We'll assess marginal discoloration using the modified United States Public Health Service criteria. The evaluation will be performed by two independent clinicians. The scores will be Alfa for no discoloration, Bravo for discoloration without penetration in pulpal direction, and Charlie for discoloration with penetration in pulpal direction. The evaluation will be conducted from baseline to 24 months.

Marginal adaptation focuses on the precision and fit of the restorations. We'll evaluate it using the modified United States Public Health Service criteria. Two independent clinicians will visually inspect the restorations with a mirror. The scores will be Alfa for closely adapted with no visible crevice, Bravo for a visible crevice where an explorer can penetrate, and Charlie for a crevice in which dentin is exposed. This evaluation will also be done from baseline to 24 months.

Secondary caries is an important consideration for the long-term success of restorations. We'll evaluate the presence of secondary caries using the United States Public Health Service criteria. The scores will be Alfa for no caries presented and Charlie for caries present. This evaluation will also be conducted from baseline to 24 months.

Abstract:
Grapefruit juice can increase the absorption of some drugs. The aim of this prospective study was to evaluate the pharmacokinetics of acyclovir and valacyclovir administered with or without grapefruit juice in human volunteers. Acyclovir and valacyclovir 400 mg was administered as tablets to 16 healthy volunteers. Grapefruit juice was administered concomitantly. Blood samples were taken at 0, 12, 24, 48 h. The mean C(max) values after acyclovir (19.0 mug/ml ± 2.0 mug/ml) and valacyclovir (18.6 mug/ml ± 1.6 mug/ml) were increased (39.2 mug/ml ± 5.0 mug/ml and 36.0 mug/ml ± 3.7 mug/ml, respectively), and these drugs are absorbed from the stomach to the small intestine because of the increased bioavailability. Grapefruit juice may increase the absorption of drugs, such as acyclovir and valacyclovir, from the stomach to the small intestine and exerts effects on drug absorption from the gastrointestinal tract.

Absolutely! For measuring muscle strength, we can use the manual muscle testing (MMT) as a standardized measuring tool. The patient, in a sitting position with 20 degrees knee flexion, will be asked to actively extend the knee against resistance proximal to the ankle. We'll use the numeric score 0-5 from the Daniels and Worthingham Scale to assess quadriceps muscle strength. Higher values indicate better muscle strength. We can assess this outcome measure at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on this?

To measure mobility, we can use the timed up and go test (TUG). This test is a standardized measuring tool that times the patient's ability to rise from an armchair, walk to a line on the floor 3 meters away, turn, and walk back to the chair. Lower values on the TUG test indicate better mobility. We can assess this outcome measure at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think?

We can assess these clinical results at preoperative, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on this?

To assess radiological results, we can use x-rays, including ap and lateral views, patella views, and whole leg axis views. These x-rays will help us evaluate the alignment of the leg, patella position, and overall leg axis. We can assess radiological results at preoperative, day 1 after surgery, 6 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think about this approach?

To measure pain control, we can use the numeric rating scale (NRS) ranging from 0 to 10, with lower values indicating better pain control. What do you think about this approach?

To document the length of hospital stay, we can simply keep a record of the number of days the patient spends in the hospital. This will help us evaluate the duration of the hospital stay before surgery, during the hospital stay, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. Primary Outcome Measure:
- Functional muscle power output of the leg: Cycle sprint test measuring maximum lower limb muscle power in Watts (W) from 3 times 10-second maximal efforts. This will be assessed at preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Muscle strength: Manual muscle testing (MMT) using a numeric score 0-5 (Daniels and Worthingham Scale) to assess quadriceps muscle strength. This will be assessed at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Mobility: Timed up and go test (TUG) to assess mobility. This will be assessed at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Clinical results: Including redness, swelling, hyperthermia, wound/scar assessment, range of motion, stability, and adverse events. This will be assessed at preoperative, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.

- Pain control: Numeric rating scale 0-10 to assess pain levels. This will be assessed before surgery, twice daily on the ward (except for the first 6 hours: hourly), day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Opioid consumption: Documentation of administered drugs, including name, dosage, and frequency of use. This will be assessed before surgery, during hospital stay, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Length of hospital stay: Documentation of the number of days in the hospital. This will be assessed before surgery, during hospital stay, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Patient satisfaction 1: Questionnaire (Oxford Knee Score) with a range of 12-60 points. This will be assessed at preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Patient satisfaction 2: Questionnaire (EQ-5D-5L) with 5 questions and EQ-VAS ranging from 0 to 100. This will be assessed at preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.

Study of a Novel Osteosynthesis Composite for the Fixation of the Clavicle 45-65Yrs

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of the study is to define the efficacy and safety of a novel osteosynthesis composite compared to a standard implant based on 3D-MCT scan evaluation and clinical follow up results in a randomized, multi-centre trial. In addition, radiostereometric analyses (RSA) will be performed at 6 months and 1 year to compare the amount of bone formation between the new and old implants and the amount of bone resorption between both implants.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Patients above the age of 18 with a stable, distal Clavicle fracture are recruited and randomly assigned to the investigational composite for 3 months non-removable fixation or to a standard platinum-coated non-removable titanium implant. Post operatively, patients will be evaluated clinically at 1 week, 3 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 1 year, 2 year respectively. To assess implant safety, patients will undergo standardized plain x-rays at all time points. A 3D-MCT is taken at 3 months and 1 year after surgery. Radiostereometric analyses (RSA) will be performed at 6 months and 1 year of follow-up to assess implant fixation and the amount of bone formation as well as bone resorption between control patients and patients with the investigational implant.

Official Title

Study of a Novel Osteosynthesis Composite for the Fixation of the Clavicle Non-Randomized. RSA-Comparison of 3 Months Fixation With a Standard Platinum Titanium to One-Year Fixation With a Bioactive Clavicle Composite(TK-NCF).
