Study Overview
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this study is to investigate the effect of a low dose of melatonin and zinc on metabolic factors in pregnant women with preeclampsia. Melatonin is considered to be a modifier of metabolic disorders. In this context, we intend to perform a multi-center, prospective, open-label, randomized, controlled, parallel-group, intervention study. A total of 40 pregnant women diagnosed with preeclampsia who met the inclusion criteria will be randomly assigned to one of the two study groups. The control group (n=20) will receive routine treatment with the exception of daily oral intake of Lysine Acetylsalicylate 21 mg/day, according to the protocol already established for preeclampsia screening in gestosis screening program, and the experimental group (n=20) will receive daily oral intake of melatonin and zinc in dosage of 3 mg and 20 mg, respectively.

Detailed Description
-----------------
10 Pregnant women diagnosed with preeclampsia with gestational age > 35 weeks and 6 days will be divided into 2 groups: Control Group (n = 20) will receive routine treatment with the exception of daily oral intake of Lysine Acetylsalicylate 21 mg, according to the protocol already established for preeclampsia screening in gestosis screening program; Experimental Group (n = 20): daily oral intake of melatonin and zinc in dosage of 3 mg and 20 mg, respectively. The drug will be administered until delivery. Data will be analyzed with a statistical package for social science (SPSS for Windows, version 26.0), which includes the chi-square test, the Fisher exact test and the Student's t test to the dependent sample.

Official Title
-----------------
The Effect of Melatonin and Zinc Supplementation in Pregnant Women With Preeclampsia.

Preeclampsia

The primary outcome measures are the safety dose of the combination of hydroxychloroquine and CDK4/6 inhibitors in patients and the recommended phase II dose. For the safety dose, we aim to evaluate the safety profile of the combination therapy in patients with solid tumors, including the occurrence of dose-limiting toxicities (DLT). This evaluation will be based on specific criteria such as liver and kidney injury, non-hematological toxicity, and hematological toxicity. The time frame for this measure is 12 months to ensure long-term monitoring of adverse events and safety outcomes. For the recommended phase II dose, we aim to determine the optimal dose of the combination therapy for further evaluation in phase II clinical trials. The time frame for this measure is also 12 months.

This measure will evaluate the proportion of patients with tumor response to the treatment, indicating potential effectiveness in achieving tumor regression or stabilization. The time frame for this measure will be 12 months. Similarly, the progression-free survival (PFS) measure will evaluate the impact of the combination therapy on the length of time patients remain free from disease progression. This measure will help us assess the efficacy of the treatment in delaying tumor growth or spread. The time frame for this measure will also be 12 months.

Background
=================
Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, with an estimated 18.1 million new cases and 9 million deaths in 2018 . Solid tumors account for the majority of cancer cases, and treatment options are often limited or ineffective, especially for patients with advanced or metastatic disease . Immunotherapies have revolutionized cancer therapy in recent years, but many patients still experience suboptimal responses or treatment-related toxicities. VISTA, a checkpoint receptor, is a promising potential target for immunotherapy . Aim
The aim of the study is to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and efficacy of SNS-101 (anti-VISTA) as a monotherapy and in combination with cemiplimab in patients with advanced solid tumors. Design
The study will be a phase 1/2, open-label, multi-center study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and efficacy of SNS-101 as a monotherapy and in combination with cemiplimab in patients with advanced solid tumors. Abstract:
The use of 18F‐FDG‐PET/CT for the assessment of early tumor response to anti‐tumor treatment is increasingly reported as the superiority over conventional imaging (MRI / CT) is demonstrated. With the approval of the FDA's PET‐response criteria in 2009, PET‐CRC as the only dedicated imaging response criteria have been established. Since then, the first publications on oncological PET tracers have shown an increased diagnostic performance for response criteria compared to conventional imaging. Based on these encouraging results, the EU has now set up a consortium (IMPRESS‐2) that aims to evaluate and apply oncological PET tracers in clinical routine. In the first step, the study aims to compare 2 oncological PET tracers ‐ 18F‐FLT and 18F‐FET‐PET/CT for detection of early response in patients with colorectal cancer after neoadjuvant therapy. 60 patients with colorectal carcinoma who receive neoadjuvant treatment are prospectively followed for 6 months, taking into account 4 different time nodes (1 month, 2 months, 4 months and 6 months). The tumor response will be evaluated by means of PET‐CRC, TNM and RECIST 1.1, as well as histopathology. The results will be presented in an interim analysis. The subsequent study section will investigate the best PET tracer in a randomized comparison with regard to inter‐ and intra‐observer variability, intra‐ and inter‐scanner variability, diagnostic performance and reproducibility. The planned PET tracer selection for clinical routine is to be compared with other established imaging procedures (MRI / CT, diffusion-weighted MRI), whereby the aim is a decision for oncological response criteria. Our study group is experienced and has previously published on this topic. Together with the University Medical Center of the Johannes Gutenberg University in Mainz, which coordinates the project, we expect a strong project organization with an active collaboration between the participating sites

Intervention Description:: Rivaroxaban is a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) drug that provides several advantages over classic oral anticoagulants such as warfarin, including a lack of diet or drug-drug interactions, more reliable administration, and a lower cost for patients. Based on the literature evidence, the use of this drug provides potential therapeutic benefits regarding ischemic events and major bleeding. As a result, the DOACs are considered a standard of care for atrial fibrillation, venous thrombosis, and, more recently, for coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). These advantages have been discussed and confirmed in several clinical trials in primary and secondary prevention of thromboembolic complications. In an unselected cohort of COVID-19 patients with high thrombotic risk, rivaroxaban had better outcomes than the traditional therapeutic alternatives. We will conduct a monocenter, prospective, randomized, parallel-group, double-blind, placebo-controlled outpatient study, with a follow-up of one year, to compare rivaroxaban and placebo in COVID-19 patients admitted to the hospital. The objectives are the determination of the efficacy of a regimen of low-dose rivaroxaban in reducing the incidence of thromboembolic events in COVID-19 hospitalized patients with high thrombotic risk, and in reducing mortality and the duration of hospital stay.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The role of renal denervation in improving clinical outcomes in patients with symptomatic paroxysmal atrial fibrillation despite durable pulmonary vein isolation has not been fully elucidated.OBJECTIVE: We investigated the long‐term safety, efficacy, and the effect on health‐related quality of life of renal denervation in patients with recurrent paroxysmal atrial fibrillation who had undergone durable pulmonary vein isolation.METHODS: In the present study, we examined 77 patients who had undergone renal denervation through a transfemoral approach after a pulmonary vein isolation procedure. Before the procedure, patients completed a quality of life questionnaire. They were treated with a single session of radiofrequency catheter ablation of the renal arteries. The primary endpoint of the study was the cumulative atrial fibrillation burden 12 months after percutaneous renal denervation.RESULTS: At the end of the follow‐up period (12‐month post‐ablation), all patients (n=77) showed a significant reduction in atrial fibrillation burden. Among the patients who experienced one or more documented episodes of atrial fibrillation during the first three months after renal denervation, a significant decrease in atrial fibrillation burden was noted, ranging from 54.2% to 95.9% (p< 0.05). Furthermore, there was a significant increase in patients with a sustained AF burden <5%.CONCLUSIONS: Renal denervation, in addition to a pulmonary vein isolation procedure, effectively prevents atrial fibrillation recurrence in patients who have experienced atrial fibrillation recurrence within the first three months after an initial ablation procedure.

6. Change in arterial blood pressure after renal denervation: Comparing arterial blood pressure 3 months and 12 months after renal denervation to pre-treatment measurements using ambulatory and office blood pressure measurements.
7. Change in day heart rate following renal denervation: Evaluating day heart rate following renal denervation compared to before, as assessed by the implantable cardiac monitor.
8. Change in patient activity: Assessing patient activity following renal denervation compared to before, as assessed by the implantable cardiac monitor.
9. Change in heart rate variability: Monitoring heart rate variability following renal denervation compared to before, as assessed by the implantable cardiac monitor.

Study
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
A clinical trial with 10 participants. The subjects will receive passive heating for 45 minutes. The physiological parameters will be measured at baseline, during heating, immediately after heating, and at 1, 4, and 8 hours post-heating to evaluate the changes in response to passive heating. The control group will receive no intervention.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This study aims to determine the effects of passive heating on physiological responses, including core temperature, oxygen consumption, cardiac output, blood pressure, and heart rate. The subjects will be assigned either the experimental group (passive heating for 45 minutes) or the control group (no intervention). The physiological parameters will be measured using the CorTemp™ smart pill, Bair Hugger® system, Finopres© system, and open circuit spirometer. Data analysis will be performed using statistical methods to compare the results between the groups and determine the impact of passive heating on physiological responses. Recruitment: 20 participants in total (10 in each group) Informed consent will be obtained before enrolling the subjects. The study will be conducted in a controlled environment with the subjects lying down and resting comfortably in a supine position. The experimental group will receive passive heating using a hot water bottle or body wrap for 45 minutes. For the control group, there will be no intervention. All subjects will be monitored for any adverse effects. There is a risk of mild discomfort during the passive heating intervention, but no known serious risks are associated with it. This study is expected to take approximately 2-3 months to complete, including data analysis and publication.

Intervention Description:: The primary outcome measure of the trial is tooth survival, which is defined as the maintenance of pulpal vitality and the absence of clinical and radiographic signs of pulp necrosis or failure. The study includes two interventions: a test intervention—the use of sodiumhexametaphosphate as a pulp capping material—and a control intervention—the use of MTA as a pulp capping material. Both test and control material are delivered in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions. All participants receive one application of the test material or control material under local anesthesia. The test material is delivered in a cavity preparation on the pulp surface to cover the exposed pulp and achieve a tight seal. No removal or drilling is done, as these procedures may result in pulp infection. 
Follow-up visits are scheduled at 6 months, 12 months, and 18 months after the pulp therapy procedure. At each visit, the tooth is examined clinically and radiographically to assess pulpal healing and the absence of pulp necrosis. Radiographic evidence of pulp necrosis or failure includes focal widening of the periodontal ligament space, periapical radiolucency greater than 5 mm or indefinite in size or shape, and non-occluded radiolucent defects.[31] Additional interventions are performed as needed, such as root canal treatment or extraction.[32]

# Pulp Capping Materials in Primary Teeth: A Randomized Clinical Trial
Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Background and Aims Dental pulp is the soft tissue that resides within the central part of the tooth. Its main function is to provide nutrients to the tooth and help maintain its vitality. When the dental pulp encounters injury or infection, it can become inflamed and diseased, leading to pulp death and tooth loss. Pulp capping is a dental procedure that aims to prevent pulp death and preserve the tooth by covering the injured or exposed pulp with a material that promotes healing and protects the remaining viable tissue. MTA (Mineral Trioxide Aggregate) and sodiumhexametaphosphate are both commonly used pulp capping materials in primary teeth. However, MTA has several advantages over sodiumhexametaphosphate, including better physical properties, better sealing ability, and a lower risk of leakage. Previous studies have shown that pulpal healing rates and successful outcomes are high with both MTA and sodiumhexametaphosphate, but no significant differences have been reported between them. Therefore, the aim of this study is to assess which pulp capping material is more effective in managing pulpal necrosis of primary teeth. Hypothesis The null hypothesis is that there is no difference between the two pulp capping materials in terms of clinical success rate over one year. Methodology A multi-center, parallel, randomized, controlled clinical trial will be conducted in pediatric dentistry clinics in Iran. A total of 150 children aged 3-6 years with pulp necrosis of primary teeth will be recruited and randomly assigned to either MTA or sodiumhexametaphosphate (SHMP) groups. Both materials will be applied to the injured pulp by the same operator, and the clinical success of the procedure will be evaluated for one year following treatment. Abstract:
BACKGROUND: There is a growing concern over the health risks associated with consuming high fat and sugary foods. This randomised controlled trial tested the effectiveness of an educational intervention, involving a parenting‐focused nutrition programme (PNP), plus an intervention arm (which received the regular PNP intervention alongside the additional nutritional information) on improving knowledge and confidence, and changing nutrition‐related behaviours in parents of children aged 7‐11 years.METHODS: Parents (n = 290) were recruited from two primary schools in South East London. One school was randomly allocated an intervention group, while the other was a control group. The Intervention consisted of a seven‐session nutrition programme plus the routine school nutritional information. The control condition received the regular PNP intervention. The study measured parent knowledge, confidence, self‐efficacy, nutrition behaviours, general lifestyle, and their self‐perceived ability to provide a healthy, balanced diet for their child.RESULTS: Findings suggest that parents in the intervention group displayed improved knowledge, self‐efficacy, and dietary behaviours compared to parents in the control group. However, changes were not maintained after six months.CONCLUSIONS: Although the results are inconsistent, the study suggests that the PNP intervention is an effective tool for improving parental nutrition knowledge and health behaviours in young children. The inclusion of this educational intervention in the school environment, along with nutritional information, could prove to be a valuable tool in promoting healthy eating behaviours in children and their families

Introduction
Cervical cancer is a common cancer and the third most common type of cancer in women worldwide (1). It is estimated that 604,000 new cases will be diagnosed globally in 2022, with over half of these cases occurring in developing countries (1). Cervical cancer is a major public health issue, accounting for 7.5% of all cancer deaths in women (2). Surgery is the most common treatment for early-stage cervical cancer (3). However, it can have significant physical and psychological consequences for patients, including pain, discomfort, and anxiety (3).
Warm compress, defined as the application of a warm water bottle or heat pack on the pelvic region, has been used for pain relief in various contexts, including menstrual cramps, back pain, and musculoskeletal disorders (4). It is believed that the thermal effect of warm compress helps to stimulate blood circulation, reduce muscle tension, and provide a soothing sensation (4). There is limited evidence on the use of warm compress for pain relief during surgery in patients with cervical cancer (5). However, it has been reported that warm compress can help to alleviate pain and improve patient satisfaction (5).
The aim of this study is to investigate the effectiveness of warm compress for pain management during surgery in patients with early-stage cervical cancer. The main objective of the study is to compare the pain intensity level of patients who receive warm compress during surgery with those who do not receive warm compress. The secondary objectives are to compare the postoperative recovery time, postoperative complications, and patient satisfaction level between the two study groups.

Abstract:
Background Current evidence suggests that the introduction of electronic health record systems has yielded ineffective interventions, resulting in physicians devoting a less substantial amount of time to the medical history and physical examination. The purpose of this study was to determine the use of electronic medical records for the inactive diagnosis of uncontrolled hypertension among patients without a history of hypertension. Method Patients, identified using two physician practices medical record systems, were 30 years and older. The 2012 National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey norms were used to determine those patients who had an uncontrolled diagnosis of hypertension according to mean systolic and diastolic blood pressure values. Results The mean age was 48 years, and most were women (64%). The majority of patients had an uncontrolled diagnosis of hypertension according to SBP and DBP values in the 2012 NHANES survey norm (67% and 87%, respectively). Approximately two‐thirds of the patients with an uncontrolled diagnosis of hypertension had a recorded blood pressure reading of <140 or <90 mmHg in their electronic health records. Conclusions Our study found that more than half of the patients with an uncontrolled diagnosis of hypertension had an inaccurately recorded blood pressure value, and these errors were not identified in the electronic record system. The results suggest that physicians must rely more on the manual evaluation of patients in order to provide appropriate care and improve clinical outcomes.

Objectives : Decision‐making in cancer is very complex. The objective of this retrospective, observational study was to investigate a possible role for the patient's decision‐making style in the survival time of patients with resectable metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas. Methods : Survival data from a cohort of patients with pancreatic cancer were obtained from the German‐Austrian pancreas database. The patients with pancreatic adenocarcinoma were dichotomized according to their decision‐making style. Cox proportional hazard analysis and Kaplan‐Meier analysis were used to analyze the survival of the patients. Results : Data from 221 patients with resectable metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas were analyzed. The median age of the patients was 59 years (range , 29‐76 years). Seventy‐six of the patients (34%) followed a collaborative decision‐making style, whereas 145 patients (66%) made independent decisions, 3 patients (1%) followed a passive decision‐making style, and 7 patients (3%) followed a supportive decision‐making style. A multivariate analysis showed that an independent decision‐making style was an independent prognostic factor for overall survival (hazard ratio (HR) , 1.91 [95% confidence interval (CI) , 1.20‐3.04]; P=0.006). Detailed Description
-----------------
Diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common Adult lymphomas with the incidence increases rapidly with age. The clinical course is indolent and often progressive with an overall 5 year survival (OS) of 27%-56%. The first line treatment for DLBCL is cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone (R-CHOP) regimen. Approximately 40% of patients experience relapse within 2-3 years after the completion of first line treatment. The most commonly employed salvage regimen in second-line treatment of RR-DLBCL is R-CHOP, with an objective response rate of 50-70%. However, the long-term survival benefit of these patients is not well documented. Since no effective salvage regimens exist, patients with RR-DLBCL often have a poor prognosis and most of them cannot be cured. Hence, it is crucial to develop an efficient salvage regimen for second-line treatment of RR-DLBCL patients with limited toxicity. Doublet Chevotherapy (DC) is widely used worldwide as a salvage regimen for RR-DLBCL. DC refers to the combination of an anthracycline and an epipodophyllotoxin. Epirubicin and cyclophosphamide doublet (EC) and gemcitabine and cisplatin doublet (GP) are common second-line DC regimen for DLBCL. There are many complications in peripancreatic collection such as gas leakage, abscess, pseudocyst, duodenal fistula and pancreatic fistula after surgery. In Korea, intraoperative drainage of peripancreatic collection and postoperative close observation and treatment are performed in order to prevent fistula. However, in such cases, the time to fistula occurrence is 1 to 50 days, and the time required for fistula treatment is 2 to 6 weeks. There are a variety of methods of treatment due to the different time point of treatment, location of the drain, type and method of observation, location and time of examination, and the degree of accuracy of diagnosis due to imaging. In particular, the current diagnostic criteria for postoperative pancreatic fistula are based on the clinical diagnosis of IHPBA (International Study Group on Pancreatic Fistula), rather than the method of radiological examination. The International Study Group on Pancreatic Fistula (ISGPF) defines postoperative pancreatic fistula (POPF) as the following: (1) at least an 8 cm (23 mL) increase in serum amylase (or lipase) concentration compared to normal at least 3 days after operation; (2) amylase level greater than 300 IU/L without evidence of intra-abdominal infection (such as peritonitis, abscess and organ ischemia); (3) Drainage fluid amylase greater than 3 times the serum amylase at any time or 10 times the serum amylase if a drain is present in the absence of infection. This method is mainly used because surgical site infection in the postoperative period makes it difficult to distinguish from pancreatic tissue. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study aims to investigate the effects of prolotherapy on the muscle strength of the upper trapezius muscle and the lower limbs of women with chronic low back pain (C-LBP). There will be two groups: one group will receive prolotherapy injections and the other group will receive sham injections. The participants will be asked to perform three sets of ten repetitions of an overhead shoulder press exercise for the upper trapezius muscle and ten knee extensions and leg press exercises for the lower limbs. These exercises will be performed before the injection and four weeks after the injection. We will assess the effects of prolotherapy on the muscle strength of the upper trapezius muscle and lower limbs by measuring the peak torque of the upper trapezius muscle and lower limbs. We hypothesise that prolotherapy will result in an increase in muscle strength of the upper trapezius muscle and lower limbs of women with C-LBP.

BACKGROUND: Malignant hyperthermia (MH) is an inherited disorder of skeletal muscle metabolism that can lead to severe hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, and cardiac arrest during induction and maintenance of anesthesia or after general anesthesia. Patients with neuromuscular disease have a higher risk of developing an MH crisis. OBJECTIVES: The objective of this investigation was to evaluate the prevalence and risk factors for MH in an Australian cohort of patients with established neuromuscular disorders. METHODS: A prospective study of all suspected MH cases between September 1999 and June 2005 was conducted. The cases were divided into two groups: patients with documented positive MH test results were analyzed as a group‐1, and patients with negative test results were analyzed as a group‐2. The baseline characteristics of the patients and perioperative anesthetic variables were analyzed. RESULTS: There were 27 suspected cases, of which 23 had positive MH tests (group‐1) and 4 had negative test results (group‐2). Nine patients with confirmed MH (three patients with Becker muscular dystrophy and six with Duchenne muscular dystrophy) were identified (21 of 166 patients). The mean (+/‐SD) age at MH diagnosis was 13.7 +/‐ 5.9 years. The mean age at the time of MH episode was 16.1 +/‐ 5.9 years. One patient developed MH during muscle biopsy and four patients developed an MH episode during general anesthesia. The most common triggering intraoperative drugs and/or anesthetic techniques were succinylcholine and volatile agents. Six patients had postoperative complications. CONCLUSIONS: These results showed that group‐1 patients were at risk for MH episodes either during muscle biopsy or during induction of anesthesia, and they had a 33% postoperative complication rate. I would suggest considering the following outcome measures:
1. Auditory brainstem response (ABR) intensity: This measure provides objective information about the integrity of the auditory pathway from the ear to the brainstem. It can help monitor the progression of hearing loss in pediatric participants with OTOF, GJB2, or GJB2/GJB6 mutations. We can measure ABR intensity at different time points throughout the study, such as annually for 4 years.

Another important measure is otoacoustic emission (OAEs) amplitudes. OAEs are a non-invasive measure of cochlear function and can provide information about the health of the outer hair cells in the cochlea. Monitoring OAEs amplitudes can help assess the structural integrity of the cochlea and detect early signs of cochlear dysfunction in pediatric participants with gene-related hearing loss. We can also measure OAEs amplitudes annually for 4 years.

Yes, we should include pure tone intensity thresholds as an outcome measure. This measure assesses the softest sound that a participant can hear at different frequencies. It's crucial for evaluating the degree and configuration of hearing loss and tracking changes in hearing sensitivity over time in pediatric participants with OTOF, GJB2, or GJB2/GJB6 mutations. We can measure pure tone intensity thresholds annually for 4 years as well.

The last outcome measure I would recommend is speech detection and perception thresholds. This measure evaluates the ability of participants to detect and perceive speech sounds at different intensity levels. It's important for understanding the impact of gene-related hearing loss on speech understanding and communication abilities in pediatric participants. We can assess speech detection and perception thresholds annually for 4 years.

For secondary outcome measures, I suggest focusing on auditory skills and speech perception over time. We can include measures such as open- and closed-set task phoneme accuracy and word comprehension, early speech perception (ESP), pediatric speech intelligibility (PSI) test, and auditory skills checklist (ASC). These measures will provide insights into the development of auditory skills and speech perception abilities in pediatric participants with gene-related hearing loss. We can assess these measures annually for 4 years as well.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The primary purpose of this pilot study is to examine if a virtual reality (VR) gait retraining program can provide a method to detect subtle abnormalities in gait during early stage recovery after hip fracture surgery. The secondary aim is to examine whether or not this VR-based system can provide training that leads to improved gait function with a safe means of tracking progression. An additional secondary aim is to explore whether gait function changes are associated with self-reported and objective measures of gait and daily activities. Participation will consist of six 1-hour sessions over two weeks at University of Louisville Hospital to assess gait function and associated self-reported and objective measures of gait and daily activities. The participants will consist of 20 older adults ages 65 and older.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Hip fracture is a traumatic event associated with increased mortality rate and decreased quality of life. Reasons for the increased mortality rate include complications associated with bone healing and the risk of subsequent falls. The purpose of this study is to examine if a computer-based system can detect subtle abnormalities in gait following hip fracture surgery before they become clinically evident. If early detection is possible, appropriate interventions can be performed immediately. The secondary purpose of the study is to examine if a computer-based system can provide a training method that improves walking function. Currently, walking training is delivered by therapists based on clinical experience. This system provides a safe method of early-stage gait training with objectively recorded information on gait and daily activities. The treadmills are equipped with cameras that record walking speed, stride length, stride timing, and movement of the hips, trunk, arms, and legs. Data will be recorded as the participants walk. Participants will complete an initial assessment to demonstrate their ability to walk. Once they have finished training, they will leave their virtual world to return to their real world. Study design

Interventional, single-centre, prospective, randomized and open trial

Description
=================
This study is a prospective, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, and multi-center interventional study with an expected enrollment of sixty participants. Two groups will be created. The randomization process will be computerized and performed by an independent biostatistician from the Department of Biostatistics. Participants will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to either the intervention group or the placebo group. The randomization result in the first place will be based on the minimization of the confounding factor of the initial APACHE II score between the two groups. The randomization sequence is generated by an independent biostatistician using SAS statistical software (version 9.4 or higher). Participants are stratified by center and allocated to one of the two groups using a minimization algorithm. The minimization algorithm is applied to generate the randomization sequence. The software assigns each participant to the intervention group or the placebo group according to the predetermined randomization sequence. The participants will be blinded to their group assignment, as the intervention and placebo conditions are similar in appearance and will be administered by the same staff. 

The intervention group will receive a spinal cord stimulation intervention conducted by professionals, while the placebo group will receive a placebo stimulation intervention. The study intervention will be delivered within 4 hours of randomization and repeated daily for a period of 48 hours or until discharge, whichever occurs first. Spinal cord stimulation and placebo stimulation will be administered using a biopac electrical stimulator (Biostim) device (Biopac System Inc., Goleta, CA). The device has an electrode (length 3.3 cm, diameter: 30g, 1 electrode per group) that is attached to the patient's back at the level of their second lumbar vertebra, between the spinous process and the intervertebral disc. Study of the influence of electrical stimulation of the dorsal roots of the spinal cord on neuromuscular function in weaning and nonweaning ARDS patients

Abstract:
Introduction: Spinal cord stimulation (SCS) is a promising intervention that has shown potential in improving respiratory outcomes in patients with respiratory failure. However, little is known about its effects on neuromuscular function in ARDS patients. Purpose: The aim of this study was to assess the effects of SCS on the diaphragm and respiratory muscle function in ARDS patients. Methods: This was a prospective study conducted on a sample of 40 patients with ARDS. Patients were randomized into SCS (20 patients) and controlled (20 patients) groups. Both groups received similar treatments for ARDS. The SCS group received the additional intervention of SCS applied to the T4‐T9 level. Diaphragm muscle thickness and area were assessed by ultrasonography at baseline and post‐intervention. Respiratory muscle function was evaluated by measuring maximal inspiratory and expiratory pressures. Patient outcomes, incidence of adverse events, and duration of mechanical ventilation were recorded. Results: The SCS group demonstrated a significant increase in diaphragm muscle thickness and area compared to baseline, while no significant changes were observed in the controlled group. There were no differences in the respiratory muscle function parameters, patient outcomes, or incidence of adverse events between the two groups. The duration of mechanical ventilation was significantly shorter in the SCS group compared to the controlled group. Conclusion: SCS resulted in significant improvements in diaphragm muscle thickness and area in ARDS patients, but did not significantly improve respiratory muscle function or patient outcomes. The shorter duration of mechanical ventilation observed in the SCS group suggests that SCS may have potential benefits in improving respiratory outcomes in ARDS patients

Abstract
-----------------
We are conducting a clinical trial to assess the effectiveness of apixaban, an oral, anti-Factor Xa drug, compared to enoxaparin, an injectable, anti-Factor Xa drug for the prevention of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in post-operative patients undergoing radical cystectomy for urothelial carcinoma. The study hypothesis is that apixaban has equal or superior efficacy for DVT prevention compared to enoxaparin, with significantly fewer bleeding complications. 

Introduction
-----------------
Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a serious potential complication following radical cystectomy for urothelial carcinoma. It occurs without symptoms in over 50% of patients. Enoxaparin, one of the recommended treatments for DVT prevention, is an injectable, anti-Factor Xa drug that is associated with adverse effects such as injection site bleeding, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Apixaban, an oral, anti-Factor Xa drug has shown promising results in the prevention of DVT in surgical patients. However, there have been no studies comparing apixaban to enoxaparin in the post-operative period following radical cystectomy. 

Our objectives are to compare the efficacy and safety of apixaban and enoxaparin for the prevention of DVT in post-operative patients undergoing radical cystectomy for urothelial carcinoma. The primary endpoint is the incidence of symptomatic DVT verified by imaging modality within the first three months post-operatively. The secondary endpoints include the incidence of all-cause DVT, major bleeding complications, adverse events, and health-related quality of life. 150 patients will be recruited from the urology and interventional radiology clinics at our institution. We propose a single-blind, randomized controlled trial (RCT) design. RCTs are widely recognized as the gold standard for evaluating the effectiveness of interventions, and this design will allow us to compare the outcomes of the experimental and control groups. To ensure the study's credibility, we will use a third-party blinded assessment process. This will involve randomly assigning the participants to either the experimental or control group, and a third party who is unaware of the groups will conduct the assessment of the outcome measures. This will reduce the potential for bias in the results.

Latex allergy is a common condition, with up to 80% of healthcare workers being exposed. In orthopedic surgery, glove perforation is a common complication, with studies showing perforation rates of up to 18%. One possible solution to this problem is using double gloves instead of the traditional single glove. However, there are limited studies examining this topic. This study aims to investigate the effectiveness of using double surgical gloves in orthopedic surgery in reducing perforation rates. The participants in this study will either use double gloves or the traditional single glove and will be examined for perforations presence, location, cause, and type. The study will also assess the participants' levels of discomfort and satisfaction with the glove-wearing experience. The results of this study will provide valuable information on the effectiveness of using double gloves in reducing glove perforations and improving the overall glove-wearing experience for both healthcare workers and patients.

Abstract:
Background/Purpose: The treatment of knee osteoarthritis (OA) is complex and multifaceted, requiring a therapeutic strategy that not only combines conservative treatments such as physical therapy and occupational therapy with exercise but also utilizes non‐invasive and minimally invasive interventions such as transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) and microcurrent electrical nerve stimulation (MENS). Despite the importance of evaluating such interventions, measuring the level of pain caused by the knee OA and its subsequent improvements remains challenging. This study aims to determine the efficacy of TENS and MENS in reducing knee pain and the effect of their combination. Patients and Methods: This randomized controlled trial was conducted on 160 patients with knee OA. Patients were randomly assigned to three groups: Groups A, B, and C. Subjects were evaluated through various outcome metrics at baseline and then, after two weeks of intervention, at a follow‐up session. Group A received TENS, group B received MENS, and group C underwent both treatments. Pain assessment by a Visual Analog Scale (VAS), physical examination for flexion of the ankle and knee, isokinetic muscle strength test, isometric strength test, and evaluation of the knee’s range of motion were performed in all three groups. Results: The results revealed that TENS and MENS reduce pain and improve muscle strength, range of motion, and function after two weeks of treatment. However, the combination of TENS + MENS led to greater reductions in pain and improvements in all outcome metrics compared to the single interventions alone. The combination therapy also improved all outcome measures more than any single intervention alone. Conclusion: This study suggests that the use of TENS and MENS in combination may be a more effective treatment for knee OA than any single intervention alone.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Physical activity is an important component of physical literacy, but physical activity behaviours are decreasing among children. Many health care professionals have expressed a concern that children lack the confidence and skill to participate in physical activities. Physical Literacy for Children - Physical Activity Program (PLC-PAP) is a 10-week physical activity intervention that has the potential to improve health outcomes by increasing physical activity participation. The purpose of this study is to determine how effective PLC-PAP is at improving physical activity, motor competence, psychological skills and cognition in children aged 5-12. The results of this study will have implications for clinicians and public health strategies focused on childhood physical activity. The results will also provide guidance for future intervention development.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Physical activity is an important component of physical literacy, but physical activity levels are decreasing among children. Children are more likely to participate in physical activity if they have positive perceptions of their physical competence. Physical Literacy for Children - Physical Activity Program (PLC-PAP) is an evidence-based, structured, 10-week physical activity program delivered by trained and certified physical activity leaders. The Program involves 25 minutes of aerobic and strength activities, skills instruction, 5 minutes of coordination, teamwork, and competitive skills, instruction on mental skills, and a 10-minute parent education session. This study will investigate the efficacy of PLC-PAP. 50 participants from community organizations who have not previously enrolled in the program will be recruited. Participants will be measured for physical activity levels, motor competence, self-efficacy, and cognitive performance before and after the 10-week intervention. Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to provide evidence on the efficacy and safety of endoscopic treatment for carotid artery occlusive disease (CAOD). Methods: A random number table was used to generate a sequence of numbers for patient assignment. The allocation method was simple and was based on even‐odd numbers. Patients who presented with severe carotid artery occlusions, including proximal occlusion and bilateral occlusion, were allocated to the combined group, whereas patients with isolated carotid artery occlusions were allocated to the medical treatment group. Results: The 126 patients were allocated to the combined and medical treatment groups. Two patients in the medical treatment group (1 female, 1 male; age, 62 ± 6.4 years; median NIHSS [National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale] score, 7.67 ± 1.8) suffered from recurrent cerebral ischemia and were lost to follow‐up. All 126 patients were examined with transcranial Doppler and ultrasound imaging. Among these patients, 65 patients were assigned to the combined group and 61 patients were assigned to the medical treatment control group. Cerebral angiography was performed in all of the patients before and after the procedure. All of the patients underwent postprocedure computed tomography angiography scanning after the procedure. There were 7 deaths in the control group at the 3‐month and 6‐month follow‐ups, but none of the patients in the combined group had serious complications. Interpretation: In summary, these results indicate that endovascular treatment is a viable therapy for severe carotid artery occlusive disease.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Tracheostomy decannulation is a common procedure in critically ill patients with prolonged mechanical ventilation. Unfortunately, successful decannulation is often challenged by frequent reintubation, and the risk factors associated with reintubation are incompletely understood. This study seeks to prospectively evaluate the clinical predictors of reintubation in a single-center cohort of tracheostomy patients undergoing decannulation, with the aim to develop and validate a screening tool for successful decannulation. A secondary objective is to evaluate the impact of early tracheal suctioning on decannulation success and reintubation rates.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Tracheostomy decannulation is a common procedure in critically ill patients with prolonged mechanical ventilation. Although it offers numerous benefits in terms of patient comfort and reduced days on mechanical ventilation, successful decannulation may be hindered by frequent reintubation. The objective of this study is to prospectively explore the predictors of reintubation in a single-center cohort of tracheostomy patients undergoing decannulation. We aim to develop a screening tool to identify patients at risk of reintubation and facilitate decision-making regarding tracheostomy management. A secondary objective is to evaluate the efficacy of early tracheal suctioning in preventing reintubation and improving clinical outcomes after successful decannulation. Patients will undergo daily tracheal suctioning to assess the impact of tracheal secretions on decannulation success and reintubation rates. Using the data collected, we plan to develop a scoring system to predict the risk of reintubation in tracheostomy patients undergoing decannulation. This scoring system will take into account several clinical and laboratory factors, including age, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), tracheostomy placement time, and tracheal suctioning adequacy. The risk scores will be validated in two independent cohorts of patients undergoing decannulation. This prospective study will help identify clinical predictors of reintubation

Intervention
=================
Intervention : Tracheostomy tube removal
The procedure of tracheostomy tube removal is performed by an experienced physician specialized in respiratory medicine. The procedure involves inserting a tube into the trachea through the neck and inflating a cuff at the end of the tube to seal the opening. The cuff is deflated, and the tube is slowly withdrawn from the neck. The procedure is performed under direct observation to ensure that the tube is removed correctly and no complications occur. The tube is typically removed after 12 to 24 hours of ventilation, depending on the patient's condition.After the removal of the tracheostomy tube, a bronchial wash is performed to prevent infection. The procedure involves suctioning mucus and other secretions from the airways to ensure that the breathing passage is clear. The procedure is performed under direct observation by a physician specialized in respiratory medicine. Once the procedure is complete, the patient is monitored closely for any complications.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The investigators plan a 12 month, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study involving up to 2400 participants 28 years of age or older with body mass index (BMI) between 27 and 45 kg/m2 with at least one additional cardiovascular risk factor. Eligible participants will be randomized 2:1 to receive naltrexone-bupropion extended release (XR) combination product 150-150mg twice daily plus placebo or placebo oral tablets twice daily for 12 months. A primary endpoint of the study is the treatment-emergent effect of naltrexone-bupropion on the composite rate of cardiovascular death, non-fatal myocardial infarction, non-fatal stroke, or hospitalization for unstable angina at 12 months.

Detailed Description
-----------------
An imbalance in eating behavior contributes to the development of obesity. Obesity is associated with a more than two-fold increase in the risk of a major cardiovascular event, like a heart attack or stroke, compared with people of normal weight.1 Binge eating, characterized by frequent binge eating episodes and compensatory behaviors, is a commonly reported eating behavior that contributes to excessive weight gain and obesity.2 Binge eating episodes are characterized by the consumption of a large amount of food within a short period of time, and individuals with binge eating generally report feelings of lack of control over their eating behavior and negative emotions during and after the binge.3 The N-opioid System and Obesity: The opioid system, which is located in several brain regions involved in the regulation of appetite,4 appears to regulate body weight by decreasing food consumption and increasing feelings of fullness after meals.5,6 Binge eating can stimulate the opioid system via the activation of several neurotransmitters, including endogenous opioids, dopamine, and gamma-aminobutyric acid,3 and excessive activity of opioid receptors during a binge appears to result in an increase in food intake in animal models of obesity.

Abstract:
To assess the relative cost‐effectiveness in terms of costs and outcomes of oral Naltrexone (NTX) and the combination of NTX and bupropion (bup‐NTX) for adults with opioid use disorder (OUD) in a community‐based, primary care population.METHODS: A decision analytic model was adapted from the literature to assess utility and costs of OUD treatments. The model was populated with data from patients in a randomized controlled trial (NCT02757073). Monte Carlo simulations were used to evaluate the uncertainty of model estimates. Patient‐level inputs included patient characteristics, drug use parameters, treatment initiation, and treatment completion rates.RESULTS: The lifetime cost per quality‐adjusted life‐year (QALY) of treatment with NTX (214.51 USD/QALY) was lower than bup‐NTX (377.75 USD/QALY) and medication‐assisted therapy (986.78 USD/QALY) with methadone. Sensitivity analyses indicated that the results were robust to variations in treatment costs.CONCLUSIONS: NTX is cost‐effective compared to both bup‐NTX and MAT with methadone across a broad range of model inputs and parameters. The model indicates that NTX is a cost‐effective treatment option for adults with OUD within a primary care population.

Abstract:
Motor‐evoked potentials (MEPs) of the lower limb can be recorded non‐invasively in various clinical conditions and in different states of consciousness. We studied the recovery of lower limb MEPs after propofol‐induced anesthesia in 14 healthy volunteers. Bilateral MEPs of the knee flexors and extensors were recorded in the awake state and during three stages of anesthesia. The MEP amplitude and latency of the extensor muscles were studied by paired t tests in different anesthetic states. MEP amplitude was significantly reduced after induction of anesthesia and remained so following recovery. There was no significant difference in MEP latency between awake and anesthetized individuals or during recovery. We conclude that recovery of lower‐limb MEPs after an anesthetic event may take several days.

Abstract
-----------------
Extracorporeal shock wave therapy is a new physical therapy for tendon diseases, however, there have been controversies on its effectiveness. The present study aimed to investigate the efficacy of extracorporeal shock wave therapy in patients with tendinosis of the adductor longus compared to ultrasound. A total of 61 patients who had more than 3-month history of anterior knee pain and no obvious efficacy of exercise and physiotherapy were allocated to one of the three treatment groups: extracorporeal shock wave (ESWT), ultrasound (US), and dexamethasone iontophoresis (I/P). A total of 37 patients were enrolled in the ESWT group, 14 in the US group, and ten in the I/P group. Before treatment and at one-month after treatment, the patients were assessed using the International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) score, Lystedt symptom score, and Tegner activity score [TAS]. Significant changes in the values after treatment was observed for the IKDC score in each group (P < 0.001), while the Lystedt symptom score showed a significant change only in the ESWT group (P < 0.001). For the TAS, only the ESWT group had a significant increase in the score after treatment (P < 0.001). Significant differences were observed between each group and the control group in the IKDC score, the Lystedt symptom score, and TAS (P < 0.05). Shock wave therapy is more effective for the conservative treatment of adductor longus tendinosis than ultrasound and dexamethasone iontophoresis, and it is recommended as the first-line treatment for tendinosis of the adductor longus.

ASP-2215 is a bispecific antibody that targets HER3 and EGFR for treatment of cancers overexpressing HER3 including TNBC. This phase 1 study will determine the highest recommended dose (i.e., recommended phase II dose [RP2D]) of ASP-2215 in combination with pembrolizumab and trastuzumab followed by neoadjuvant chemotherapy (naCT) in participants with unresectable Stage III/IV triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) with recurrent disease post-neoadjuvant/ adjuvant therapy. This phase 2 study is designed to evaluate efficacy and safety of ASP-2215 in combination with pembrolizumab and trastuzumab followed by standard-of-care neoadjuvant chemo in these participants. This study includes two parts: Phase 1: The first part of this study is for Phase 1 testing and will include a dose-escalation portion followed by a dose expansion portion, with approximately 16 participants being enrolled into each Phase 1 dose cohort. Phase 1 will assess safety and tolerability of ASP-2215 and determine the RP2D. Phase 2a: The second part of this study includes an expansion cohort of the RP2D of ASP-2215/pembrolizumab with trastuzumab and neoadjuvant chemotherapy, which will allow collection of additional information about the safety and effectiveness of the ASP-2215/pembrolizumab combination. Phase 2b: Phase 2b is designed as an extension or separate study depending on findings of Phase 2a; this portion is optional and will allow for evaluation of clinical benefit and/or long-term efficacy of ASP-2215/pembrolizumab combinations in these participants.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of the HS400 System when used for the treatment of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

Detailed Description
-----------------
Prior to the study procedures, eligible subjects must complete the STOP-BANG screening test. If eligibility is met, subjects who choose to proceed with the study will participate in an evaluation visit in which they will have a physical exam, blood draw, completion of a questionnaire regarding previous medications, previous surgeries, medical history and other demographic data. If eligibility is met, and the subjects and physician agree, subjects will be randomized to a device or standard of care group within the study. Subjects randomized to the device group will undergo surgery to place the HS400 System and will begin CPAP treatment. Subjects randomized to the standard of care group will begin CPAP treatment without the HS400 System being inserted. All subjects will wear an Actigraph Activ8 device for a minimum of 14 days at each visit. All subjects will return to the study site for monthly visits for 6 months to evaluate and record subject safety and compliance with the prescribed study treatment. Subject safety will be evaluated by assessing adverse events (AEs), medical tests (e.g. vital signs), laboratory values and/or physical exams. Compliance to the study treatments will be evaluated by examining the recorded data from the subjects' Apnee devices

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Vitamin D plays an important role in bone health, and it has been suggested that it promotes osteogenesis and anti-inflammatory effects. Therefore, the addition of vitamin D-fortified bone meal to the existing formula of bone graft extender (Mixxoil®) seems reasonable. This study will evaluate the effect of vitamin D fortification of BGX on bone healing and bone fusion after total knee arthroplasty.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Total knee arthroplasty (TKA) is a commonly performed surgical procedure to treat patients with end-stage osteoarthritis (OA). Despite its high success rate and low complication rate, a significant portion of patients experience osteolysis around their implants and loosening requiring repeated or total revision surgery. With rapid improvement in prosthesis design and patient characteristics, new implants have been introduced to treat these patients, but most of these new implants still rely on bone to support the prosthesis. The lack of bone stock in these patients requires a means to provide additional bone stock using graft substitutes or bone graft extension (BGX). Unfortunately, bone grafts are associated with donor pain, infection, and morbidity. Bone-substitute materials are expensive, and there are additional costs and challenges with retrieving bone grafts from the donor site. Therefore, using allograft bone as BGX remains popular in patients who require primary or revision TKA, but the need for additional bone-graft supplementation remains unresolved. The investigators hypothesize that the addition of a vitamin D-fortified calcium phosphate-based bone graft extender (Mixxoil®) in the formulation will help encourage new bone formation.

Official Title
-----------------
The Effect of Vitamin D-Fortified Bone Graft Extender in Osteoarthritic Patients Undergoing Primary Total Knee Arthroplasty

Conditions
-----------------
Osteoporosis, Arthritis, Osteoarthritis, Knee, Knee, Postoperative Rehabilitation, Prosthesis Failure, Osteolysis, Revision Replacement, Knee, Tibial Prost

This trial seeks to test the safety of a new minimally invasive surgical technique using a novel robotic system, developed by the researchers, in participants who have been diagnosed with lower limb paralysis that has been caused by a spinal cord injury. This new technique involves implanting an electric stimulation device into the spinal cord, which will be connected to the patient's skin surface. The device will deliver a mild electrical current to the spinal cord, which helps to restore partial movement and bladder function in patients who have been diagnosed with lower limb paralysis. This study will be conducted in a double-blinded, randomized, placebo-controlled, crossover trial. Abstract:
Background: Previous studies have shown that single‐incision laparoscopic surgery using the LESS approach does not increase trocar related bowel, vascular, and solid organ injuries compared with conventional 3 or 4 ports laparoscopy. We aimed to assess the safety and effectiveness of a totally subxiphoid single‐port approach to hepatectomy. Methods: We prospectively collected data of 35 patients who underwent resection of the liver using an 8‐cm incision along the subxiphoid region. The patients were divided into three groups based on the duration of surgery (55–75 min, 75–95 min, and ≥ 95 min). Surgeon and observer assessed the difficulty of the case at the end of the operation and gave the Visual Analogue Scale. Results: The mean operation time was 84 ± 17 min (range, 70–115 min) and the blood loss volume was 143 ± 34 mL. Four patients (11.4%) had conversion to minilaparotomy in the early postoperative period. No patient had serious complications. There were no bile‐related complications or organ injury that had to be treated during the hospital stay. Postoperative pain was mild based on the Visual Analogue Scale (1.90 ± 2.36 points). Conclusion: Single‐incision laparoscopic subxiphoid hepatectomy is safe and feasible with short learning curves.

In arm 1, subjects receive Gammagard 400 IU/kg/day, in arm 2, they receive Gammimmune 400 IU/kg/day and in arm 3, they receive normal saline.

Intervention
=================
Bioequivalence studies have a specific design, which is an incomplete block cross-over design. The study consists of two fixed-sequence test treatments on different days. For the first treatment, subjects will receive a low dose of tadalafil 2.5 mg orally under fasting conditions. The low dose is administered as a reference dose for bioequivalence studies and is followed by an 8-hour washout period. For the second treatment, subjects will receive a high dose of tadalafil 10 mg orally under fasting conditions under a second cassette administration of a 40 mg sildenafil tablet orally under fasting conditions on a different day, with an 8-hour washout period.

Abstract:
Background Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) is a clinically heterogeneous hematopoietic cancer that affects several hundred thousand new patients worldwide annually. With median response rates of only 10–30 % and overall response rates (ORR; complete remissions plus complete remissions with partial hematologic recovery ) of 40–60 %, it is imperative to improve clinical outcomes for patients with AML. For this purpose, novel treatment strategies have been developed, which have been found to enhance response and result in improved survival. A recent case report of a successful re‐induction of remission in a patient with relapsed/refractory AML with the hypomethylating agent azacitidine highlights the potential clinical utility that could eventually come from developing new hypomethylating agents. In this article, we review the biological and clinical rationale for azacitidine‐based remission induction therapy (AZA‐RIT) in AML and the experience to date in this setting. Methods The PubMed database was searched for studies involving AZA‐RIT in AML. Results Our analysis showed that AZA‐RIT can induce complete remission in patients with relapsed/refractory AML in two‐thirds of cases. In addition, there are studies that show azacitidine is associated with better survival compared to best supportive care in the case of relapsed/refractory disease. One study indicates that azacitidine can also be safely administered in combination with hypomethylating agents such as decitabine and guadecitabine (SGI‐110). Conclusions While these findings suggest that AZA‐RIT is an appropriate initial therapy for AML, further controlled studies are necessary before recommendations for its use can be made.

Study
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a prospective, randomized, and double-blind, placebo-controlled exploratory study to determine the feasibility and safety of Restorative Microbiota Therapy (RMT) using probiotic capsules in patients with chemotherapy-induced diarrhea. RMT is an emerging treatment modality, with recent studies suggesting that it can induce clinical remission in patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) who have experienced failed immunomodulatory therapy. RMT has shown promising results in patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS). In patients treated with injectable immunomodulatory agents such as interferon or glatiramer acetate, RMT treatment has improved clinical outcomes. This effect appears to be attributed to the restoration of specific microbiota. However, in patients with chemotherapy-induced diarrhea, RMT has not been previously investigated. This study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of RMT in patients with chemotherapy-induced diarrhea who have been treated with non-myeloablative chemotherapy regimens and corticosteroids.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Background: Chemotherapy-induced diarrhea (CID) is a common side effect of antineoplastic drugs, affecting up to 80% of patients receiving chemotherapy and causing significant morbidity and increased patient mortality. In recent decades, the use of immunotherapy for malignancies, including checkpoint inhibitors, has led to a shift in patients' quality of life and treatment outcomes. Despite its benefits, increased susceptibility to CID is one of the challenges in immunotherapy. Immunotherapies enhance the activity of the body's immune system against cancer, leading to an increase in autoimmune reactions, including colitis. Studies have shown that gut dysbiosis and alterations in the gut microbiota are associated with the onset and progression of CID. There is growing evidence that suggests a role for the gut microbiota in the development of diarrhea.

Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine if piroxicam causes or contributes to the development of esophageal strictures in patients with reflux disease.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a prospective, randomized double-blind placebo-controlled study of 170 patients with mild to moderate reflux symptoms. 85 patients will be randomized to receive piroxicam and 85 to receive placebo for three months. The two study groups will include patients who have: Gastroesophageal Reflux Symptom Index (GERSI) score of ≥ 10; Refractory to PPIs (H.2 Receptor Antagonists) for at least 3 months Patients will be asked to keep a 4 day reflux diary, score themselves daily using the GERSI score sheet and undergo upper endoscopy with biopsies at entry and at three months. They will also be asked to complete a quality of life form (Short Form (36) Health Survey) and a pain profile (Short Form McGill Pain Questionnaire ) at entry and at 3 months.

Description
=================
Background: Alzheimer's dementia (AD) is a progressive, neurodegenerative disease characterized by cognitive impairment and dementia. Current medical treatments are limited and provide only modest symptomatic relief. Recently, there has been a growing interest in non-drug interventions such as repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) as potential treatment options for AD. Conventional cognitive assessment tests such as the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) may lack sensitivity and specificity in early AD. The standardized neuropsychological battery (SNSB) is a comprehensive assessment tool that measures multiple cognitive domains and has been shown to have excellent reliability and validity in early-stage AD.SNSB test items and tasksThe SNSB test has multiple test items and tasks that assess cognitive domains essential for everyday functions, including orientation, memory, executive function, visual-spatial skills, attention, and language. The entire test takes about 45 minutes to administer and can be divided into two sessions to maximize patient comfort. The thresholds for improvement are determined by a decrease in tender and swollen joint counts, CRP levels, and patient global assessment. 

* The Clinical Disease Activity Index (CDAI)

It takes into account the number of tender and swollen joints, patient and physician global assessments, joint pain, tender joints, and CRP levels. The scores range from 0 to 76, with a lower score indicating a lower level of disease activity. 

* The Disease Activity Score-28 (DAS28)

* The Disease Activity Score-28 (DAS28) is a standardized index that measures the level of rheumatoid arthritis disease activity. Materials and Methods: Women >18 years of age with suspected urinary tract infection who received a single‐dose intravenous cefazolin or ciprofloxacin were offered enrollment in the study. The study began in April 2003 and ended in March 2004. Patients were initially screened and followed for 48 hours after completing the oral intravenous antibiotic therapy. After that, patients were followed for 2 months by completing a telephone survey that assessed vaginal symptoms, including vaginal discharge and itching, and included questions about patient satisfaction and need for a second treatment. Fifteen patients developed symptomatic vaginal candidiasis (14%; n=6; 11%; n=9) during their follow‐up. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The objective of this study is to evaluate the impact of an 8-week digital patient education program on reducing kinesiophobia and promoting physical activity in patients with myocardial infarction and atrial fibrillation. This will be determined through a comprehensive assessment of these outcomes.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a significant and common condition, affecting approximately 3 million people in the United States. The prevalence of AF increases with age, with an estimated prevalence of 10% in individuals aged 65-84 years, and 15% in individuals aged 85 years and older. The most common symptom of AF is palpitations, and other symptoms may include fatigue, shortness of breath, weakness, and dizziness. Patients with AF often experience anxiety and fear of movement, which can lead to reduced physical activity and a decline in overall health and quality of life. Digital patient education is an emerging approach to healthcare that has the potential to improve patient outcomes and reduce healthcare costs. In this study, patients with myocardial infarction or AF will be recruited and randomly assigned to either an intervention group or a control group. The intervention group will receive access to an 8-week digital patient education program specifically designed to reduce kinesiophobia and promote physical activity. The control group will receive standard care. At baseline, 8 weeks, and 3 months after program completion, patients in both groups will be asked to complete a comprehensive set of outcome measures, including the Tampa Scale of Kinesiophobia and physical activity assessment using the ActiGraph GT3X accelerometer. - Heart focused anxiety: The Cardiac Anxiety scale will be used to assess participants' anxiety related to their heart condition. This measure will be taken at the same time points as the primary outcome measure.
- Self-rated health: Participants' overall perception of their health status will be assessed using the EuroQol-visual analogue scales. This measure will be taken at the same time points as the primary outcome measure.
- Patients' experiences of the digital program: Individual semi-structured interviews will be conducted to gather qualitative data on participants' experiences. These interviews will take place after the 8-week program.

Study hypothesis
=================
That immunonutrition will result in significantly reduced recurrence and lower cancer mortality in high-risk patients undergoing cystectomy.

Phase III, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled design.

Interventional

Randomised controlled trial

Condition

Bladder Neoplasms

Intervention
=================
Group assignment will take place at the time of cystectomy. Eligible patients will be randomized to the experimental arm or the control arm. The former will receive a ready-to-drink beverage containing immunonutrition and the latter will receive a ready-to-drink beverage as the placebo, which neither has any nutritional value. The intervention will be initiated preoperatively and continue postoperatively for approximately 12 weeks. Participants will be followed for 15 years after their surgery, and the primary endpoint will be measured as time from randomization to the date of first recurrence of cancer or death.

Supplement

Tumor recurrence or death from any cause. Time from randomization to the date of first recurrence of cancer or death.

Disease-free survival. Time from randomization to the date of first recurrence of muscle invasive or non-muscle invasive cancer. Cancer-specific survival. Time from randomization to the date of first recurrence of muscle invasive or non-muscle invasive cancer. Incidence of acute and late-onset recurrent urinary tract infections, as recorded in patients' medical records. Incidence of recurrent urinary tract infections in patients' medical records. Quality of life, as measured with the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer generic quality of life questionnaire (QLQ-C30) and the bladder cancer questionnaire (QLQ-NPC). QLQ-C30 and QLQ-NPC will be administered at baseline and at 1-year follow-up.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Intraoperative nerve blockade in conjunction with analgesic management has been proved effective in reducing postoperative pain. Currently, intraarterial regional anesthesia (IARA) is not performed in some patients or on both sides of the body in patients undergoing surgery on one or both sides due to the limitations of the equipment used or the time needed to perform these operations.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The goal of this double-blind prospective randomized controlled trial is to determine which of the following surgical techniques is more effective during femoral nerve block and analgesic management: bilateral IARA or single shot of femoral nerve block .

Official Title
-----------------
Comparison of Intraoperative Bilateral Single Injection Femoral Nerve Block Versus Intra Arterial Regional Anesthesia (IARA) During Analgesic Management in Patients Undergoing Femoral Head Displacement

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
A multi-institutional phase II study that will evaluate the activity of chemoradiation plus nalirifox (NFX) alone or with atezolizumab (atezo) for the treatment of patients with unresectable locally advanced pancreatic cancer. This study will determine whether NFX in combination with chemoradiation and atezo, or NFX alone without chemoradiation, can improve on the outcomes of standard chemoradiation in patients with locally advanced pancreatic cancer. The study will assess the efficacy and safety of these therapeutic interventions in a cohort of 12 evaluable patients. Secondary objectives of this study include: establishing the maximum tolerated dose of NFX in combination with chemoradiation and atezo; establishing the maximum tolerated dose of NFX alone; and assessing the safety of these treatments in terms of toxicity.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will assess the efficacy and safety of NFX alone or in combination with atezo in patients with histologically or cytologically confirmed unresectable locally advanced pancreatic cancer. Eligible patients will be enrolled into a Phase II study consisting of two stages. Stage 1 will assess the activity of NFX in conjunction with conventional chemoradiation and atezo (arm A of phase II) in 12 evaluable patients. This will be an open-label trial. All participants will receive atezo for the duration of the study according to the approved atezo protocol. NFX will be administered concurrently with radiotherapy as a single arm in Arm A, while NFX will be given with the first cycle of chemotherapy as an additional dose prior to radiation therapy in Arm B. After completion of the Phase II component, the data will be analyzed. If, in the investigator's opinion, there are sufficient preliminary data that justify additional evaluation of NFX, the study may proceed to Stage 2. For each Stage 2 arm, up to 12 additional evaluable patients, will be assigned to receive radiation therapy with NFX + atezo (Arm B) or NFX alone (Arm C). Abstract:
Background: In response to the COVID‐19 pandemic, governments and scientific communities implemented recommendations for limiting social contacts. The implementation of such restrictions might have led to a reduction in risk behavior and substance use. This might have positive long‐term health effects. However, substance use is not only influenced by the availability of substances but also by social factors such as peer pressure. Therefore, during lockdown, this negative effect of peer pressure might have been limited. As peer pressure has been shown to be one of the strongest social influencing factors, its effect on substance use should be investigated. To date, there is scare knowledge on whether peer groups can influence the reduction or increase in drug use during lockdown. As previous works have shown that peer groups negatively influence alcohol and cannabis consumption, we hypothesized that peer groups increase nicotine use. The aim of this study was to examine the effects of both peer pressure and alcohol or cannabis use on individual substance use in peer groups. Methods: Participants were asked to fill in daily ecological momentary assessments (EMAs) on their substance use, feelings of peer pressure, and alcohol and cannabis consumption. We analyzed the effects of feelings of peer pressure and alcohol or cannabis use measured by these EMAs and examined if they are predictors for nicotine use and if they interact with peer groups. We calculated cross‐lagged regression models and lagged Pearson correlations to analyze the effects of peer groups on substance use. We also calculated separate regression models to analyze alcohol and cannabis use and nicotine use separately. Results: We collected data on 78 participants (73% female, Mage = 29.0, SDage = 6.5). On EMA day 1, peer groups did not influence the following day's substance use (Days 2 to 10). On day 11, we could not find any effects on nicotine consumption from peer pressure or alcohol or cannabis use. On day 11, peer pressure was significantly related to feelings of nicotine use (p < .001). Conclusion: This study shows that peer pressure in daily social situations strongly impacts the motivation to use nicotine. Peer pressure was

Abstract:
To elicit the most complete and accurate description of the experiences of women with cervical cancer, we used a mixed‐methods approach in which qualitative interviews were followed by a quantitative survey of the same women in the same interviewing context. Our purpose was to better understand what matters most to women with cervical cancer, including their preferred information, experiences of care, and sources of support in the oncology system. We analyzed 39 interviews and a 120‐item survey with 231 respondents, which yielded key themes. Women's priorities centered on communication, coordination, and personalization of care, and they expressed a desire for timely access to expert clinical care. Their biggest needs were social, emotional, and related to financial and food security. Survivorship tools that incorporate these perspectives are essential tools in the toolkit for cancer survivorship.
