Abstract:
Background: Radiation therapy plays an important role in the treatment of pancreatic cancer, but it also carries the risk of inducing gastrointestinal toxicity and immunosuppression. We hypothesized that combining N‐Acetyl‐l‐cysteine (NAC) with Radiation therapy (RT) may reduce the risk of these side effects without compromising the efficacy of RT. Methods: We conducted a prospective trial comparing the outcomes of NAC‐RT versus RT alone in patients with locally advanced or borderline resectable pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma. Results: Forty patients were randomized to receive either NAC‐RT or RT alone. The median age of the patients was 68 years and the median RT dose was 50.4 Gray in both groups. The overall response rate (ORR) was similar between the two groups: 70% in the NAC‐RT group and 65% in the RT alone group (p=0.59). The median progression‐free survival (PFS) was 16 months in the NAC‐RT group and 14 months in the RT alone group (p=0.47). There was no significant difference in the overall survival between the two groups: 24 months in the NAC‐RT group and 22 months in the RT alone group (p=0.54). The incidence of grade 3‐4 gastrointestinal toxicity was lower in the NAC‐RT group: 45% versus 75% in the RT alone group (p=0.02), and the incidence of grade 3‐4 immunosuppression was also lower in the NAC‐RT group: 30% versus 50% in the RT alone group (p=0.04). Conclusions: Our results suggest that the addition of NAC to RT does not compromise the efficacy of RT and may reduce the risk of gastrointest

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Dry eye is a multifactorial disease of the ocular surface characterized by a loss of homeostasis of the tear film and accompanied by ocular symptoms. Dry eye is often associated with meibomian gland dysfunction(MGD). It is important to develop a new dry eye therapy for MGD. There have been many studies on the effectiveness of MGD therapy and recent studies have shown that thermal therapy is effective for MGD. However, to the best of our knowledge, the effects of thermal therapy on the clinical subtype of dry eye(DED) are not yet clear. We previously used thermal therapy for the treatment of MGD. The clinical subtype of dry eye using our device showed a significant improvement in clinical signs and symptoms. The aim of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of a novel ocular device to warm eyelids and improve lid margin gland health.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Dry eye is a multifactorial disease of the ocular surface characterized by a lack of homeostasis of the tear film and accompanied by ocular symptoms. Dry eye is often associated with meibomian gland dysfunction(MGD). It is important to develop a new therapy for meibomian gland dysfunction (MGD). There have been many clinical researches which tried to prove the efficacy of MGD treatments. In particular, recent studies have shown that thermal therapy for MGD is effective. However, to the best of our knowledge, it is not clear whether the existing MGD treatments are effective based on eye's anatomic subtype analysis of dry eye(DED). We previously developed an ocular device to warm eyelids through infrared thermal energy. The effect of the novel device therapy was not investigated after MGD classification according to subtypes of DED classification. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of the novel ocular device based on the clinical characteristics.

Official Title
-----------------
A Novel Therapy for Treatment of Meibomian Gland Dysfunction in Dry Eye Disease

Conditions
-----------------
Meibomian Gland Dysfunction Meibomian Gland Dysfunction, Dry Eye Disease

Abstract:
The introduction of transplantation programs based on cadaveric donors in the 1970s enabled the treatment of patients with a history of inhaled corticosteroids associated with pulmonary fibrosis not adequately controlled by conventional treatment. There are no randomized controlled trials assessing this association. A study of 17 patients before and after transplantation showed no significant increase in mortality due to infections in this population, and the lung transplantation outcome was not different from that of patients without such a history. Nevertheless, this association remains controversial. The main limitation of these studies can be found in the fact that only patients with severe cases were included in the literature, which may explain the lack of results comparing these subjects with patients without a history of inhaled corticosteroids. The authors conducted a study based on a retrospective cohort of 63 transplanted patients undergoing lung transplantation for non‐reactive pulmonary fibrosis from 2012 to 2021 at a tertiary referral center in France. The primary objective was to compare the patient survival rate one year after transplantation between those with and without a history of inhaled corticosteroids. The secondary objective was to assess the complications in patients with a history of inhaled corticosteroids.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of the study is to test the use of a drug called sildenafil to treat the eye condition called dry eye. Dry eye is caused by a problem with the oil glands in your eyelids. These glands usually make an oil substance called meibum. The eyelid has two rows of glands - the upper eyelid has more glands than the lower eyelid. A normal tear film has a layer of tears covering the eye, this is made of water and oil. This helps protect the eye, and keeps it moist and comfortable. If your meibum glands are blocked, they can't make the oil they normally make. The tears may not have enough oil to help protect your eye. Your tear film changes and it can get worse. If this happens, you may have dry, irritated eyes. The study will last about 5 months. The treatment phase is 8 weeks.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will last about 5 months. There are two stages to this study: screen and treatment period. For the screen period you will take one dose of sildenafil and return to the clinic on Day 2 to see if you are eligible in this study. If you qualify, you will take a treatment of sildenafil (which will be supplied at no cost to you) and follow up visits every two weeks. Your participation in this study and your treatment is entirely voluntary. You can stop participating at any time if you choose to. There are no additional follow-up appointments after the study ends. Participants who complete the study will be informed of the outcome via the email address or contact number provided.

Abstract:
PURPOSE: This study attempted the evaluation and comparison of the effects of oral and intranasal 1%, 2% ketorolac on perioperative pain in patients undergoing sinus surgery. MATERIALS AND METHODS: Ninety‐five patients were divided into three groups and treated with oral 1%, 2% ketorolac (20 drops/ day), intranasal 1% and 2% ketorolac (1 drop/2h). The parameters assessed were pain perception, need for rescue analgesia medication and adverse events. Patients in the oral and intranasal groups were subdivided into 3 subgroups A, B and C according to the analgesic method used in the postoperative period. RESULTS: The first rescue analgesia need was 12.5 h in the oral group; 7.5h in the intranasal 1% ketorolac group; 4.5 h in the intranasal 2% ketorolac group (p < 0.05). The groups received analgesia less frequently, with the lowest number in the intranasal 2% ketorolac group [group A (1.2±0.8) x group B (1.5±0.6) x group C (1.3±0.4)] (p > 0.05). The intranasal and oral forms had 12 adverse events in 8% and 13% of the individuals, respectively, similar between groups. CONCLUSIONS: Intraoperative administration of 1% or 2% eyedrops with oral supplementation improved the analgesia received.

Mean arterial pressure (MAP) will provide insights into the patient's hemodynamic stability during the recruitment maneuver and general anesthesia. It can be calculated using the formula (SBP + 2*DBP) / 3, where SBP is systolic blood pressure and DBP is diastolic blood pressure. Monitoring MAP will help assess the cardiovascular response and any potential adverse effects. Additionally, assessing arterial blood oxygen levels through arterial blood gas analysis will provide information on the patient's oxygenation status during mechanical ventilation. This measure can indicate any respiratory complications or hypoxemia that may arise. What are your thoughts on these secondary outcome measures?

Description

Background: The objective of the current study is to determine the effect of a pre-exercise protein intake modality on acute and chronic muscle protein synthesis rates following lower body resistance exercise in young healthy sedentary men.  The data collected in this study is only one component in a larger, multi-faceted investigation examining the impact of exercise timing, resistance training frequency, and various pre-exercise nutrient formulations to enhance post-exercise muscle protein synthesis.  Aim: To determine the magnitude of muscle protein synthesis following lower body exercise with and without pre-exercise protein intake in the early post-exercise (acute) and chronic (48 hours) post-exercise periods.  Design: This investigation will be a randomized, placebo, counterbalanced, crossover design.  The subjects will report to the exercise lab on three separate occasions.  On each occasion, subjects will have blood samples drawn as well as undergo a lower body resistance exercise test.  Methods:  Using this approach, we are able to examine the effect of exercise alone vs. the co-administration of nutrition.  A total of 12 subjects will be recruited to participate in the study.   Participants will be randomized into one of three treatment groups.  This study will be a double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover design.  Participants will be recruited from the UCLA community, and will be exposed to three interventions in a randomized order: 1) 0.15g/kg body mass carbohydrate solution; 2) 10 grams of whey protein isolate; or 3) placebo solution.  Subjects will be asked to ingest each supplement formulation 45 minutes prior to exercise and 3 hours following exercise.  The intervention sessions will be completed over the course of 2-4 weeks, followed by a 2-4 week washout period.  Baseline data will be collected during the first visit in the laboratory.  This will entail anthropometric measures as well as diet and physical activity assessments.

This will allow us to compare the two interventions in order to determine their effects on outcomes.

Background: Evidence in recent years has shown an increased risk of Parkinson’s Disease (PD) for users of antipsychotic medications, which remains unexplained. Previous literature has also been limited by its sample size, which has been small and highly selected. This has created the opportunity to explore other pathways that may contribute to the increased PD risk.Parkinson's Disease is a slowly progressing condition that affects the body's ability to control movements. It is most common in individuals aged 50 to 65 years, and it is more common in men than women. There are currently no known causes or cures for PD, but it is believed that there are several factors that can increase the risk of developing the condition. These include a family history of PD, certain genetic mutations, exposure to toxins, and certain medical conditions such as strokes and head injuries.Antipsychotic medications are used to treat a variety of psychiatric conditions, including schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and depression

Abstract:
RATIONALE & OBJECTIVES: Detection and staging of primary tumor and metastasis is crucial in early diagnosis and proper treatment. The study aimed to evaluate accuracy and sensitivity of 68Ga‐FAPI‐46 (68Ga‐Far‐Inflazome‐Peptide) for the detection of primary tumors and possible metastasis detection at the baseline assessment in breast cancer patients.MATERIALS AND METHODS: The study prospectively included 12 early‐stage breast cancer patients who underwent baseline staging work‐up with 18F‐FDG PET/CT and 68Ga‐FAPI‐46 PET/CT. SUV measurements were noted. Detection rate was recorded.RESULTS: The mean age of patients was 31.42 ± 2.93. All patients had metabolic activity at FAPIDOTAT‐PET/CT while 1/12 had single metastasis in 18F FDG PET/CT. SUVmean 18F‐FDG was found to be higher than SUVmean 68Ga‐FAPI‐46 at primary tumor site. Concordance and accuracy of 68Ga‐FAPI‐46 PET/CT were 86.7%, and 79.2%, respectively, against FDG PET/CT.CONCLUSION: The current study showed a high rate of abnormal detection with 68Ga‐FAPI‐46 PET/CT scans among early stage breast cancer patients. Detection rate was comparable to 18F‐FDG PET/CT which is currently used for staging.

Abstract:
Asthma is a common chronic airway disease affecting 5% to 10% of the worldwide population. It is also considered a major public health issue in many developed countries, where 80% of the world’s asthma deaths occurred throughout sub‐Saharan Africa. However, the exact mechanism of asthma pathology is still unknown and the diagnosis of airway hyperresponsiveness (AHR) is mainly based on clinical manifestations. For the diagnosis of asthma, a method based on electrical impedance tomography in the airways of living adult subjects has been recently developed. The electrical impedance spectroscopy method, which is based on a quantitative assessment of the airway wall resistance to electrical current, provides information on the presence of bronchoconstriction, mucus presence, and airway inflammation. Our goal is to compare this non‐invasive method to the lung function test (LFT) and to the inflammatory markers (eosinophils, total neutrophils, C‐reactive protein, interleukin‐6) for the diagnosis of asthma. We have included in our study 60 patients with asthma for 6 month and 60 control healthy subjects. For the diagnosis of AHR, lung function tests (FEV1, FVC and PEFR) were performed to evaluate the reversibility of the airway hyperresponsiveness induced by the inhalation of an increased dosis of bronchial provocation agent: the methacholine. The results of the two methods of evaluation of the airway hyperresponsiveness (EIS and LFT) were compared to the inflammatory markers in the blood of the patients. The results of the non‐invasive evaluation of airway hyperresponsiveness based on the electrical impedance spectroscopy method appear to be significantly higher than the inflammatory markers in the blood of asthma patients.

Abstract:
In this prospective, single‐blind, open‐label, head‐to‐head comparison study, we will include patients with lobular breast carcinoma scheduled for breast‐conserving surgery or mastectomy who will undergo preoperative 68Ga‐FAPI‐46 PET/CT (positron emission tomography/computed tomography) and 18F‐FDG PET/CT and are willing to participate in this study. The primary objective is to assess the overall accuracy of 68Ga‐FAPI‐46 PET/CT compared to 18F‐FDG PET/CT in staging lobular breast carcinoma. The secondary objectives are to evaluate the safety and imaging performance characteristics of 68Ga‐FAPI‐46 PET. The study design is based on the following inclusion and exclusion criteria: (i) male and female patients aged ≥18 years with lobular breast carcinoma; (ii) patients who are considered eligible for breast preservation; (iii) patients who are scheduled for surgery within 30 days of imaging; and (iv) patients who have provided written informed consent. The primary outcome measure is the sensitivity and specificity of 68Ga‐FAPI‐46 PET/CT and 18F‐FDG PET/CT in staging lobular breast carcinoma. The secondary outcome measures are the positive and negative predictive values, accuracy, diagnostic sensitivity, diagnostic specificity, radiation dose, radiotracer uptake, and safety of 68Ga‐FAPI‐46 PET/CT in staging lobular breast carcinoma. A sample size of 75 patients will be recruited to achieve a 95% confidence interval with a +/‐ 15% margin (20% expected agreement or discordance between the 68Ga‐FAPI‐46 PET/CT and 18F‐FDG PET/CT results, 90% power, two‐sided alpha = 0.05).

Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: To examine the association between the use of statins and incident cognitive decline in a nationally‐representative sample of older patients.METHODS: Participants were included if they were aged > or =60 years and did not have cognitive impairment or stroke at baseline (2006 to 2008). The exposures of interest were statin use (yes/no), high‐dose statin use (≥40 mg/d) and adherence using the medication possession ratio (MPR; adherent=0.80, high‐adherence=0.80 to 0.90 and low‐adherence= < 0.80). Cognitive decline was defined as the 10% decliners (highest quintile relative to the lower four quintiles) from annual neuropsychological testing from baseline through follow‐up (mean duration=3.4 years; median=4.5 years). Covariates included potential modifiers of the association; demographics, socio‐economic status, health behaviors, medication use, physical activity, depressive symptoms, chronic medical conditions and comorbidities. Log‐binomial models were fit to estimate and test the adjusted relative risk (RR) of incident cognitive decline for statins, high‐dose statins and for statin adherence.RESULTS: Statin users had a 40% (RR=0.60; 95% confidence interval (CI)=0.47 to 0.75) lower likelihood to be cognitive decliners compared to non‐statin users. This association remained largely unchanged when further stratified by gender and age. When stratified by dose, the 40‐70 mg/d dose group showed a significant reduction in the likelihood of incident cognitive decline (RR=0.64; 95% CI=0.45‐0.92)

This may increase the time the patient lives or it might not change the course of the disease.Early detection and treatment for all breast cancer could reduce the risk of death by 35%. Breast cancer is detected mostly when there are changes in the breast, the lumps or lumpiness or other symptoms such as swelling or changes in breast size. The breast examination and mammograms or breast x-rays are used routinely as routine screening tests for breast cancer. Breathlessness is the primary reason for the majority of symptomatic individuals seeking medical attention and the presence of dyspnea is a marker for poor outcomes in patients. The presence of dyspnea is one of the most important indicators of the patient's physical status, and its accurate evaluation can help guide the selection of a treatment strategy. Dyspnea refers to the patient's subjective perception of breathing difficulties. Some individuals may feel normal at rest but experience shortness of breath upon exertion, while some may feel completely out of breath even at rest. In recent years, studies have proven that the quality of life of patients is closely related to the quality of treatment. If dyspnea develops, patient confidence will be undermined, resulting in decreased tolerance for anti-cancer treatment, which may lead to reduced compliance and poor treatment outcomes. The development and development of dyspnea often causes a significant reduction in activity and daily life. However, there are still few studies on the relationship between chest computerized tomography (CT) findings, especially lung lesions, and dyspnea. We plan to carry out a retrospective and prospective study to evaluate the correlation between chest CT and dyspnea in breast cancer patients. MethodsThe patients in this research will be divided into two groups, the study group and the control group, respectively. The study group will be the patients with dyspnea, and the control group will be the patients without dyspnea

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Outcome Measure: Electrocorticographic Recordings
- Measure Description: This outcome measure focuses on analyzing the intraoperative ECoG recordings acquired during awake surgery. By coupling cortical stimulation with simultaneous ECoG recordings and behavioral tests, we aim to identify the connection networks involved in cognitive functions. The regions defined as electrophysiologically connected to the stimulated region will be those for which an afterdischarge is recorded and/or a cortico-cortical evoked potential is obtained after an average of 5 successive stimulations.
- Time Frame: 12 months

Secondary Outcome Measure:
- Outcome Measure: Correlation between ECoG Data and Imaging Data
- Measure Description: This outcome measure involves comparing and correlating the disturbances of electrophysiological signals recorded during ECoG with imaging data such as MRI, functional MRI, and diffusion tensor imaging. This analysis will help us establish a more detailed mapping of the tumor areas and compare the disturbances recorded to those in healthy areas.
- Time Frame: 12 months

Abstract:
We describe a three‐step method for analysis of data for longitudinal measurement over time of change in pain in the same study participants. The method, called Growth Mixture Modeling (GMM), can be used with categorical and ordinal scale data, such as data on pain level and functional status. The GMM approach simultaneously estimates the rate of improvement, or growth over time; individual differences in the growth process; and a classification of patterns of change in each subgroup of participants. The method can be used with data from a single study or from the entire database of several studies. In a study of a chronic low back pain population with data collected at nine monthly intervals of follow‐up, GMM was applied to data on a 6‐level functional status pain scale. The analysis revealed five distinct groups of participants regarding their frequency of improvement and overall improvement over the study's nine months of follow‐up. Data for a subset of subjects, who were seen at months 1, 4, and 9, indicated high reliability for functional status scales using a 3‐ to 6‐month recall period. This method provides a better interpretation of change over time in pain and other outcomes from longitudinal measurement in clinical research of pain. © 2002, American Acupuncture Council. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study will compare the feasibility of utilizing a home rehabilitative virtual reality module against a traditional, center-based, 5-week aerobic exercise training intervention for cancer patients. The results will help the study investigators determine whether rehabilitation virtual reality (VR - the use of computer technology to simulate environments and objects to interact with) is an effective mode of rehabilitation. By having patients train at home instead of in a laboratory, it may increase access to the intervention and thus ultimately improve patient outcomes.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Today, cancer survivors are living longer than ever before. Unfortunately, as a result, patients are also living longer with the debilitating symptoms associated with cancer and cancer treatments. As survival rates increase, research shows that cancer patients are experiencing more cancer- and treatment-related fatigue, depression, poor quality of life, anxiety, fatigue, and pain. Studies show that aerobic exercise training reduces these problems and improves patients' physical, psychological, and social functioning. Unfortunately, very few cancer patients participate in cancer rehabilitation during treatment, despite being referred to rehabilitation programs by their oncology healthcare providers. One reason for low patient participation rates is the time and effort necessary to complete in-person treatments. Exercise treatments require the patient to leave their home, arrive on time for each treatment appointment, and travel a distance to and from the treatment center. When faced with these constraints, it is not surprising that patients are often non-compliant. The study team proposes the development of a home-based rehabilitation virtual-reality (VR) module. The VR-module allows patients to train at home through an internet-based interactive video game technology. These new technologies offer an alternative to in-person treatment and may help to overcome the low compliance rates that arise as a result of the physical limitations and the time and effort required to participate in cancer rehabilitation. The study investigators will create a virtual environment that is based on an established group aerobic exercise program used in in-person treatments. Participants will be trained to use the VR-module under the guidance of a trained interventionists. They will complete the VR exercise protocol daily for 12-weeks. Participant data will be extracted from the virtual environment and will be transmitted on a weekly basis to the study team. The study team

As part of the analysis, we will utilize a mixed-effects model to evaluate the agreement between the measurements obtained using supervised and unsupervised methods. This will be achieved by analyzing the differences between the results of the two spirometry testing approaches and investigating how these differences are influenced by various factors. By incorporating a subject-specific random effect in the model, we can capture the individual-level variability in lung function outcomes. We will use this approach to analyze both the primary and secondary outcomes of the study, specifically focusing on the lung function parameters, such as forced expiratory volume (FEV) and forced vital capacity (FVC). By adjusting for relevant factors, such as gender and age, the results of this statistical analysis will provide a thorough and robust assessment of the agreement between supervised and unsupervised spirometry methods in children with asthma. As this is a blinded study, it is important to note that the analyzer performing the statistical analysis will be blinded to the type of spirometry testing involved (whether it was supervised or unsupervised). Therefore, the analysis will be conducted independently of any subjective biases that might be introduced by knowledge of the testing method.

Study Overview
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
This study is a multi-center, randomized, cross-over design pilot study that will compare patient reported outcomes of home or clinic spirometry testing performed in 283 asthma subjects. Study participants will have approximately 4 weeks in each arm of the study. In the 1st arm of the study patients will be trained to perform spirometry with either an Optikam or a Koko spirometer in their home. They will return to their clinic or site in about 1 month, perform spirometry and complete quality assurance testing using both spirometers. They will return home after their clinic visit. One month later, patients will be trained to perform spirometry with the other test device and go home. After they have completed the second spirometry training, patients may again complete training at either home or at the clinic/site. At the patient's final study visit, they will perform a clinical spirometry test and complete quality assurance tests on the two spirometers. Patient demographics, smoking status, medications, and questionnaires will be completed and patients will receive a questionnaire about patient experiences with remote versus clinic study visits.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Asthma is one of the leading chronic respiratory illness affecting 18 million Americans. It is characterized by variable lung function impairment, wheezing, shortness of breath, and airway inflammation, and is associated with decreased daily function and quality of life despite available therapies. Asthma is an ideal area to assess efficacy of home spirometry since lung function tests are integral to asthma diagnosis and prognosis. Further, many asthmacare programs use spirometry as a tool for monitoring asthma control and initiating therapy. However, there are few studies assessing efficacy of patient-based testing. Most of the trials involve trained healthcare providers conducting in-home testing using an electronic device. While this is helpful in the healthcare environment, providing the subject with information about lung function and assisting in education and medication adjustment, the results may not generalize to untrained subjects performing spirometry outside of a medical setting. In addition, studies designed to assess untrained home spirometry may result in the use of test devices that vary in precision, reliability, and reproducibility making the results less reliable. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
SLE is an autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system attacks its own tissues and organs. Currently, there are no approved treatment options for patients with lupus. The aim of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of dupilumab in SLE patients.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The first arm (placebo - active drug) will be treated with placebo for 12 weeks and, at a later stage, dupilumab will be initiated for a total of 12 weeks. Patients in the second arm (duplexilumab in both stages) will be treated with dupilumab at both timepoints. After 24 weeks, the study will be completed. During the study period, blood samples will be collected at various timepoints for biochemical, immunological and molecular analysis. The study design is based on the assumption that dupilumab will be able to dampen immune responses. For this purpose, two doses of duplexilumab at 2 and 4 mg/kg body weight are applied at four-week intervals.

Abstract:
The authors performed a prospective, randomized, placebo‑controlled, double‐blind trial of oral iron therapy in 25 infants with thalassemia major treated on a daily basis with 2 mg/kg deferoxamine (DFO) and folic acid (FA) from 14 to 24 days of age. A supplement of DFO 2 mg/kg was given every evening with a single dose of oral ferrous sulfate or placebo at each feeding. The efficacy of supplemental oral iron was compared with that of DFO therapy alone by serial estimation of serum iron, hematocrit, and reticulocyte hemoglobin between 22 and 66 days of life. The investigators also recorded data on growth, feeding, stool volume, and development to ascertain side effects. In the supplemental iron group, an increase of 0.69 mg/dl was observed in hemoglobin levels, as compared with 0.30 in the DFO control group (P less than 0.0001). No difference was observed in the development of anemia between the groups. Neither did supplemental iron significantly diminish the increase observed between 22 and 66 days of age in serum iron, ferritin, or iron‐binding capacity. Oral iron supplements are safe and effective in preventing anemia in infants with thalassemia major.

Certainly! Here are the measure descriptions and time frames for each of the secondary outcome measures:

1. SF-36 score (Short form score): This measures the physical and mental health summary scores on a scale of 0-100, with higher scores indicating better health. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

2. Low anterior resection syndrome score: This measures the severity of low anterior resection syndrome, with scores ranging from 0 to 40. Lower scores indicate a better outcome. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

3. Anastomosis insufficiency: This outcome measure assesses the occurrence of anastomotic leakage, with a binary response of yes or no. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

4. Intraoperative complication: This measures the occurrence of intraoperative complications such as bleeding or ureter injury, with a binary response of yes or no. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

5. Exitus: This measures mortality, with a binary response of yes or no. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

6. Length of stay: This measures the duration of hospitalization following the surgical intervention, in days. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

7. Earlier readmission due to recurrence while waiting for surgery: This outcome measure is specific to Group B (late elective resection) and assesses the rate of earlier readmission due to recurrent diverticulitis while waiting for surgery. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

8. Postoperative complication: This measures the occurrence of common postoperative complications such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections, with a binary response of yes or no. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

Mental health issues are common in military personnel and can affect both their physical and mental well‐being. We seek to assess the impact of different military unit behaviors on the mental health of soldiers. Data were collected from 56 deployed Army units. Depression and anxiety measures were administered before and after a training exercise on units. Results reveal that certain military events and procedures can significantly increase depression and anxiety symptoms in soldiers. These findings highlight the need to address mental health concerns in a proactive manner within military units. Future research should focus on developing interventions to improve mental health outcomes for military personnel.

Brief Summary
-----------------
The objectives of this study are to develop a new integrated treatment for PTSD and alcohol problems including post-treatment support and relapse prevention delivered via text-messages and telephone calls. This new integrated treatment has been previously demonstrated to reduce PTSD and alcohol problems severity, and decrease risky drinking and alcohol-related consequences including arrests, injuries and hospital visits. Our initial evidence showed that among military veterans, this new integrated treatment resulted in reduced symptoms of PTSD and alcohol problems across a 20-week follow-up period as well as reductions in hazardous drinking days. This new integrated treatment has several advantages compared with a standard integrated treatment consisting of individual therapy provided by a face-to-face provider and brief motivational counseling on alcohol problems consisting of six in-person sessions. This new treatment: 1) is accessible and convenient to veterans who may have difficulty attending face-to-face sessions due to difficulties with mobility, transportation, or work schedules; 2) may be a more acceptable and preferred treatment modality to young veterans; and 3) has been shown to reduce high-risk drinking across a 20-week follow-up period, thereby potentially reducing alcohol-related health problems. For many people, especially those who were not in the U.S. military, we cannot be sure that this new integrated treatment will be effective with them or that the results that we have with veterans can be generalized to all individuals with PTSD and alcohol problems. Our study has two aims: 1) To evaluate the effectiveness of the new online integrated treatment compared with treatment as usual, while measuring outcomes at 2, 6, 12, 18, and 24 months; 2) To examine whether the initial findings that the new treatment reduces alcohol-related problems can be replicated in

The above outcome measures will be analyzed statistically using descriptive statistics, and results will be reported. 

Secondary outcome measures could focus on duration of response and progression-free survival, both of which are commonly measured in clinical trials involving follicular lymphoma. 

The treatment response will be determined based on changes in tumor size and lymph node involvement between the baseline and the follow-up visits. Response will be classified into complete response (CR), partial response (PR), stable disease (SD), and progressive disease (PD) based on Lugano 2014 criteria. Response assessment criteria will be applied at each follow-up visit and the end of the study. 

Progression-free survival (PFS) will be measured from the date of randomization until the date of objective disease progression, death, or the end of the study. 

Duration of response will be calculated from the date of first documented response to the date of progression or death from any cause. 

Other secondary outcome measures could include quality of life (QoL) assessed using validated instruments such as European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC) Quality of Life Questionnaire – C30 (QLQ-C30), and overall survival (OS), which will be measured from the date of randomization to the date of death from any cause. 

Safety analysis, including assessment of serious adverse events (SAEs) and death, will be conducted throughout the study.

Introduction
=================
The use of antibiotics in out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) patients is a controversial topic, and there is limited evidence to support the benefit of early administration of antibiotics. Additionally, there is the risk of causing harm by administering unnecessary antibiotics, which can lead to antibiotic resistance.
Despite not having an infectious cause, OHCA patients frequently receive antibiotics. This is often done due to concern for sepsis or pneumonia associated with cardiac arrest, even though there is limited evidence to support this practice. In fact, early administration of antibiotics has been associated with increased rates of mortality and morbidity. 

This study aims to test the hypothesis that OHCA patients with no underlying infection do not benefit from early administration of antibiotics. 

Objectives
=================
Primary outcome
-----------------
The primary outcome measure will be 28-day all-cause mortality in OHCA patients. This will be assessed by comparing the rate of mortality in patients who receive no antibiotics to those who receive early antibiotics. 
Secondary outcome
-----------------
The secondary outcome measures will be infective complications at 30 days, and at one year, the survival and neurological outcomes will be assessed.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The primary aim of this study is to evaluate whether the initiation of antibiotics for out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) patients without signs of infection at the outset impacts survival at hospital discharge. Therefore, in this observational study, adult OHCA patients with no previous history of trauma and no suspicion of infection at the outset, who were resuscitated by the Danish Emergency Medical Services (EMS) or the private ambulance service (PAS) will be included. Out-of-hospital cardiac arrest patients with infection as suspected cause of cardiac arrest or previous trauma within two days prior to cardiac arrest will not be included. Primary outcome is hospital discharge alive. Secondary outcomes may include: Survival for 30 days and 3 months Hospital length of stay, intensive care unit (ICU) length of stay, quality of life at 3 months after cardiac arrest ICU admission, need for mechanical ventilation, the use of vasopressors at 24 hours post-cardiac arrest, and time to cessation of mechanical ventilation and time to full neurological recovery. Quality of life at 3 months will be measured using the EuroQoL 5-dimension (EQ-5D) questionnaire. Data will be extracted from the Danish Cardiac Arrest Registry. Data handling and analysis The EMS and PAS crews in both regions will not be informed that the patient is included in the Danish Cardiac Arrest Registry. The regional EMS and PAS crews will receive a standardized 2-year training course to ensure appropriate and uniform administration of out-of-hospital cardiopulmonary resuscitation. Each year, all crewmembers at both EMS and PAS, involved in the resuscitations will receive a refresher course in basic life support. For the purpose of this study, the EMS and P

Sure, let's start with pain perception. It could be assessed using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS), a reliable and valid instrument commonly used in pain studies. The VAS is a simple, one-dimensional, 100 mm line that is used to assess the intensity of pain. Participants are asked to rate the level of pain by marking a point on the line between no pain (0 mm) and the worst pain (100 mm), and the distance from the left end of the line is then measured to obtain a score. Additionally, another method used to measure pain perception may be the numerical rating scale (NRS), which involves using a 0 to 10 Likert scale where 0 represents no pain and 10 represents the worst pain imaginable. It has proven to be a valid and reliable tool for assessing pain in numerous clinical studies.

Abstract:
Background: The world population is growing older, and the number of patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) awaiting kidney transplantation will increase. In these patients, kidney transplantation is the treatment of choice due to the reduced adverse events and decreased mortality. However, the acceptance of patients for kidney transplantation is a challenge in geriatric ESRD patients due to their increased morbidity and frailty syndrome. Comprehensive geriatric assessment (CGA), based on the evaluation of all dimensions of health including physical, mental, and sociocultural status, could be a feasible approach to identify frail patients and improve the outcomes of kidney transplantation in these older patients. Purpose: This observational cohort study aims to evaluate the acceptability rate of kidney transplantation and the outcomes of kidney transplantation in geriatric ESRD candidates and recipients with a focus on frailty syndrome, depression, functional status, acceptability rate for kidney transplantation, and graft survival. Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a prospective randomized study of subjects with chronic hepatitis B or chronic hepatitis C who will either get standard care therapy or the standard care therapy with the adjuvant therapy. In this study, the effect of ursodeoxycholic acid and S-adenosylmethionine on pancreatitis will be investigated.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Subjects with chronic hepatic C or B who met the inclusion and exclusion criteria will be randomly assigned to two arms. One arm will receive standard care therapy, while the other arm will receive standard care therapy plus the adjunctive therapy. Subjects will be followed for the duration of the study for disease-related markers.

Cervical cancer ranks 3rd among malignant tumors in female patients in China, which is mainly caused by the infection of human papillomavirus (HPV). HPV infection has become the most important factor of cervical cancer. However, patients infected with HPV showed no obvious clinical symptoms or obvious HPV‐related abnormal lesions, the HPV positive rate in cervical cancer patients is only about 85%. It is difficult to provide clinicians with specific diagnostic and treatment indicators based on high‐risk HPV alone. Detection of HPV infection and viral load has important significance for the accurate diagnosis and treatment of cervical cancer.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
A prospective single-institution, observational study where at least 100 patients with thoracic outlet syndrome(TOS) underwent decompression surgery at our institute (Hopitaux Universitaires de Strasbourg) were enrolled and followed up for 12 months regarding the pain severity and dysfunction of the involved upper limb in TOS. The aim of this study is to provide real-world data on the clinical efficacy of the upper extremity decompression for treatment of thoracic outlet syndrome. In this study, preoperative, early postoperative and final postoperative clinical pain and function of the upper limb were assessed by questionnaires and clinical examinations.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The main aim of this observational study was to provide real-world data on the clinical efficacy of the upper extremity decompression for treatment of thoracic outlet syndrome. We will evaluate the clinical efficacy in the preoperative, early postoperative and final postoperative. All the patients will be assessed with Visual analogue scale (VAS) and Constant-Murley score(CMS). The range of motion of the shoulder joint will be measured with the goniometer device and the maximum voluntary force will be measured with dynamometer.

Abstract:
Introduction: Transcutaneous oxygen pressure (TcpO2) is a non‐invasive method to evaluate the severity of venous or arterial insufficiency in the extremities. Venous compression is related to venous disease and arterial compression is related to arterial disease. Our purpose was to study the changes in TcpO2, using a Doppler probe with an attached probe to measure occlusive arterial flow, and the DROPmin value during compression of the upper limbs in patients with upper limb circulatory disorders. Abstract:
Purpose: TcpO2 (Transcutaneous Oxygen Pressure) monitoring has been suggested as a non‐invasive and inexpensive diagnostic test for thoracic outlet syndrome; however, it is still not clear whether TcpO2 monitoring is effective in diagnosing thoracic outlet syndrome. The aim of this study was to compare a newly proposed parameter, DROPmin, measured using TcpO2 monitoring during dynamic maneuvers, with the degree of arterial stenosis observed in diagnostic arteriography. Methods: This study included 98 patients who were referred for surgery between January 2012 and January 2014 at Mie Chuo Hospital and Saiseikai Mikawa Hospital in Japan. Arterial stenosis was diagnosed by diagnostic arteriography and classified into four stages according to the degree of stenosis: normal; mild stenosis (<70%); moderate stenosis (>70%<90%); and severe stenosis (>90%). TcpO2 monitoring was performed during simple hand grip exercise, active abduction of the upper limb, and a Valsalva maneuver before and after the surgery. The measurements were repeated in all patients every 2 years for 5 years postoperatively. We analyzed only the data for the initial assessment in this report. DROPmin was defined as the minimum value of oxygen pressure at the start of recovery after each dynamic maneuver. Results: DROPmin values were significantly lower in the mild, moderate, and severe stenosis groups than in the normal group during all three dynamic maneuvers (p<0.001). The area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve (AUC) of DROPmin in the mild, moderate, and severe stenosis groups was higher than that in the normal group during hand grip exercise, active abduction, and the Valsalva maneuver (all, p<0.001). Abstract:
The prognostic value of left ventricular (LV) diastolic function for outcome in aortic regurgitation (AR) is incompletely defined. We assessed the performance of echocardiography‐derived diastolic indices and the added value of diastolic dysfunction compared with established risk factors to predict outcome in AR. Ninety‐nine patients with mild (grade 1), moderate (grade 2), or severe (grade 3) AR were prospectively followed up for a median of 15 months. Primary outcome was time from randomization to clinical end points and death from all causes. Diastolic indices were categorized as normal (<13 mm Hg) or abnormal (13 mm Hg and higher). Diastolic dysfunction had prognostic value for event‐free survival, predicting a lower probability of composite end points or death from all causes; hazard ratios 2.37 and 8.73, respectively. The probability of a good outcome during follow‐up was 74% in patients with normal diastolic function, in contrast to 59 and 43%, respectively, with abnormal diastolic function. The role of the gut microbiome is crucial for immune homeostasis and metabolic health. It has been shown that the gut microbiome regulates immune homeostasis affecting different chronic inflammatory diseases such as psoriasis while its role on Axial SpondyloArthritis (axSpA) has not yet been established. Alterations in microbiome composition in inflammatory diseases were shown to be affected by diet as well as stressful and emotional processes. Studies linking GI disorders and stress have found that stress can alter bowel function. Furthermore, altered gut microbiome composition has been found in patients with axSpA and in response to stress and its alteration has been found to relieve inflammatory symptoms. A recent study reported that patients with axSpA, but not healthy controls, revealed differences in fecal microbiota composition during psychological and physical stress, suggesting that axSpA-specific effects of stress on the microbiome occur due to dysregulation of inflammation-related gut microbiota. However, studies linking psychological or emotional factors and microbiome composition in axSpA patients are lacking. Moreover, the role of gut microbiota in response to psychological or emotional factors and its therapeutic effects on patients with axSpA remains unknown. These studies are important in addressing the current lack of reliable and successful therapeutic strategies for axSpA management. This is because the current use of NSAIDs, TNF inhibitors, and biologic agents may cause serious adverse effects in the short- and long-term, and the psychological well-being of patients with this disease is often compromised. We hypothesize that psychological and emotional factors are associated with gut microbiome changes leading to disease relapse. Brief summary
=================
BACKGROUND: Axial spondyloarthritis (axSPA) is a joint disorder characterized by chronic inflammation, predominately in the sacroiliac and vertebral regions, with a substantial impact on quality of life. Adequate symptom control and improved health-related quality of life are important goals for patients with axSPA. Exercise therapy is a recommended treatment for axSPA management, and evidence suggests that yoga can be an effective tool in this regard, though the current guidelines lack specific recommendations on yoga's effectiveness.OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effectiveness of yoga therapy compared to physiotherapy in patients with moderate axSPA.METHODS: A single-blinded, multicenter, randomized controlled study. Seventy-six patients with moderate axSPA will be included and randomized to either a yoga therapy group (n = 38) or a physiotherapy group (n = 38). The yoga therapy group will receive support from a physiotherapist trained in yoga

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to compare post-void residual volume, as measured by ultrasound, between an anticholinergic + bladder training program and an anticholinergic only program in subjects with detrusor-external sphincter dyssynergia (DESD)

Detailed Description
-----------------
Approximately 1.2 million women in the US, ages 21 to 60 years, experience urinary incontinence (UI) that is stress or urgency incontinence (50%), or mixed UI (40%), and for the majority of these women, symptoms have been bothersome for more than three years. While OAB is a frequent disorder in women, often they seek medical care for urinary stress or urgency incontinence. In addition, many of these women present with mixed UI, consisting of urgency and stress components. These data suggest that OAB symptoms are under-diagnosed in women with UI, and in some cases, may actually be misdiagnosed as UI-stress or urgency (1,2). Urinary UI is recognized to result not only from a defect in the external urinary sphincter, but also from a defect in the detrusor contractions that cause significant leakage during the act of coughing and exertion. One proposed etiology of women's UI is a defect in detrusor contractility that over-responds to afferent innervation or increased bladder tone at low filling volumes, a dyssynergia between the detrusor muscle and the external sphincter muscle. The dysfunction could be at the neurologic level or the myogenic level. It is likely that the condition is not simple and that many factors act concomitantly to cause the urinary problems. In addition, it is not clear how many women have stress, urgency and mixed incontinence due to DESD versus other causes. The aim of this study is to compare 12 months of pharmacologic and behavioral treatment of women meeting our diagnosis

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
BACKGROUND: Atrial fibrillation is the most common cardiac arrhythmia seen in clinical practice with an overall prevalence of up to 2%. Atrial fibrillation is associated with structural abnormalities in the atria like left atrial enlargement. Larger left atrial volume is associated with more arrhythmia recurrences and increased risk of stroke and is a known predictor of worse clinical progression. The CASANOVA study has recently shown that left atrial volume decreases after two years of an aggressive rate-control strategy aiming to reduce the mean ventricular rate (MVR). However, there is currently no evidence on if MVR reduction can be successfully achieved by rate control with drugs. The aim of this study is to investigate the anti-arrhythmic effects of the diltiazem slow-release formulation (SR-DIL) in patients with drug-refractory atrial fibrillation and enlarged left atrium (>50ml/m2) by assessing changes in atrial fibrillation burden, atrial fibrillation terminations and rate control (decrease in MVR by 10bpm). Our hypotheses are that MVR reduction is greater after 12 weeks of SR-DIL therapy and that termination and relapse of atrial fibrillation will be less with SR-DIL compared to placebo. DESIGN/METHODS: The study is a prospective and randomized, open-label, parallel group trial, including 350 patients with non-ischemic drug-refractory persistent atrial fibrillation to be randomized to receive SR-DIL (up to 480mg/d) or placebo for 12 weeks. At baseline (BL) and at 12 weeks (T12), clinical record forms are used to collect demographic, clinical and ECG data, as well as to document the number of atrial fibrillation relapse and termination episodes.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
In a recent study (Rogers GJ & Hepworth D, JAMA 2022, 328:464-473), the authors conducted an open-label, randomized clinical trial in patients with hypertension. The authors compared the blood pressure (BP) values and ambulatory blood pressure (ABP) values between atenolol and valsartan.

Detailed Description
-----------------
In a recent study (Rogers GJ & Hepworth D, JAMA 2022, 328:464-473), the authors conducted an open-label, randomized clinical trial in patients with hypertension. The authors compared the blood pressure (BP) values and ambulatory blood pressure (ABP) values between atenolol and valsartan. They found no significant differences in BP reductions between the two groups. They also found that there were lower rates of cardiovascular events in the valsartan group but no difference in mortality. However, the sample size was small and the follow-up period was short. The authors suggested that larger, longer-term studies should be conducted to validate their findings. This is the protocol of a prospective, open-label, randomized, head-to-head study to further evaluate the efficacy and safety of these two drugs in the treatment of hypertension.

-----------------
Prospective, Open-label, Randomized Comparison Between Atenolol and Valsartan for the Treatment of Essential Hypertension

One other potential secondary outcome measure is to assess the relationship between hand skills and quality of life. We could use the Short Form 36 (SF-36) Questionnaire as a measure of quality of life. Abstract:
Background: Intractable moderate to severe pain is frequently observed during the first days following total hip arthroplasty (THA). This pain can be associated with several complications, such as delirium, stress ulcers and pulmonary disorders. In the current study, diclofenac and oxycodone, compared with ketorolac and diclofenac alone, were given as intramuscular rescue analgesia to patients with THA. Objectives: The primary objective was to compare the efferent analgesic effects between these two regimens. The secondary objective was to compare the adverse effects and the quality of sleep between these two groups. Methods: Forty‐two patients were divided into 2 groups randomly after total hip arthroplasty. All patients received routine doses of morphine intravenously or subcutaneously as a rescue analgesic for pain. Patients in group C (ketorolac and diclofenac) received ketorolac intramuscularly once every 12 hrs while patients in group D (diclofenac and oxycodone) received diclofenac intramuscularly twice daily and 5 mg oxycodone intramuscularly as the rescue analgesia for mild to moderate pain. Pain was evaluated at rest and during mobilization using the Brief Pain scale and quality of sleep was assessed during the first 72 hrs using the Quality of Sleep Indicator scale. Results: There was no significant difference in the level of pain between the two groups during the first 72 hrs after THA (p>0.05). The two regimen groups did not differ significantly in the quality of sleep, although group D reported a better quality of sleep the second and third nights after THA. Conclusions: In both groups, diclofenac, when used in combination with either ketorolac or oxycodone, showed a high degree of efficacy in post

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: To study the relationship between plasma homocysteine (tHcy) and bone mineral density (BMD) in Chinese patients with chronic renal failure (CRF).METHODS: Thirty‐one patients with CRF and 34 healthy controls were selected and divided into a study group (CRF patients) and a control group (healthy controls), respectively. For the study group, the Tc‐99m‐MDP whole bone scan and the dual‐energy X‐ray absorptiometry (DXA) were used to examine the bone mineral densities of the lumbar spine and femoral neck in both sides; the 24‐h urine was collected to measure the excretion of calcium (Ca), phosphorus (P), uric acid (UA) and tHcy. For the control group, plasma tHcy, 25‐OH vitamin D (Vit D) and the level of bone metabolism indicators were compared between the patients and the controls. The data of the 2 groups were analysed statistically.RESULTS: There was no statistically significant difference in the DXA BMD of lumbar spine, femoral neck and total Ca, P, UA and tHcy between the study and the control groups. There was no significant difference in Vit D levels between the 2 groups. In the group of patients, 24 h urinary Ca, P and UA correlated positively with plasma tHcy, but Vit D did not. 24 h urinary Ca correlated negatively with both BMD of the lumbar spine and femoral neck. In the control group, 24 h urinary Ca correlated positively with tHcy and Vit D levels.CONCLUSIONS: Plasma tHcy is associated with 24 h urinary Ca levels in patients with CRF, which may contribute to the decreased BMD in CRF patients, but Vit D level is not.

Abstract:
AIMS: Although a significant amount of evidence has established an association between hyperlipidemia and the risk of chronic kidney disease, there is a lack of studies evaluating the relationship between statin use and chronic kidney disease. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the association between statin use and chronic kidney disease in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and normolipidemia.METHODS AND RESULTS: A total number of 619 patients were randomly selected from 7,348 patients who were diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus between 1986 and 2015. The primary outcome was chronic kidney disease. Using a Cox proportional hazards model, the patients were divided into two groups based on whether they previously used statins. The relationship between statin use and the risk of chronic kidney disease was evaluated using the fully adjusted Cox proportional hazards models. The hazard ratio (HR) of chronic kidney disease was 92% lower in those patients who previously used statins compared to those without previous statin treatments. Additionally, after adjusting for the traditional risk factors, the HR of chronic kidney disease was significantly lower in those who received statin treatment (HR 0.57, 95% CI 0.34‐0.97, P=0.040).CONCLUSIONS: For patients with type 2 diabetes who have normolipidemia, prior statin use offers significant protection against the risk of chronic kidney disease.

Abstract:
This study investigated the relationship between the amount of water consumed and the time it takes for a 0.75% bupivacaine spinal block to take effect or to regress from the peak level of sensory block. Healthy adult female subjects received a 10 mg dose of bupivacaine 0.75% and then were randomly assigned to four treatment groups which consumed 0 ml, 150 ml, 300 ml, and 450 ml of water within 15 min following spinal injection. All subjects had serial measurements of the level of sensory block (S‐Bock scale). Using regression methods, we found no significant correlations between the amount of water consumed and S‐Bock level at 10, 30, 60, and 90 min after spinal injection. However, in women, more than 225 ml of water consumed within 15 min after spinal injection was associated with a more rapid sensory block onset (time to first S‐Bock measurement less than 30 minutes) and/or regression (time to first S‐Bock score less than 30 minutes after reaching maximum sensory block). Our results suggest that women who have consumed more than 225 ml of water 15 min after spinal injection are at greater risk of early sensory block onset or regression. Exclusion criteria: patients with a history of CAD or uncontrolled hypertension; patients with active cancer; pregnant women, or recent (within the last 6 months) breastfeeding. Brief Summary

The purpose of this study was to assess the implantation technique (pericapsular vs. extra-capsular technique) of the acetabular component in primary hip replacements. Patient-reported outcomes, functional measurements, and acetabular component range, migration, abductor status, wear, dislocation history, and polyethylene liner wear assessments will be compared.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Today's surgical approach for uncemented acetabular components may have impact on the long-term success of the procedure. The authors hypothesized that the pericapsular technique of acetabular component implantation would have equal implant survival to the extra-capsular approach with lower blood loss and less early functional post-operative limitations. Further, it has been reported that peri-operative complications, such as avascular necrosis of the proximal femur, could be reduced with the pericapsular technique, but no reports have documented functional outcomes at long-term status. This study will prospectively evaluate the early and midterm results of pericapsular and extra-capsular approaches for uncemented acetabular component fixation. Patients and Methods: From June 1993 to January 2001, a total of eighty patients underwent total hip replacement, involving a 40-degree abductor-splitting osteotomy and either an extra-capsular approach with acetabular reaming (40 patients) or a pericapsular approach without reaming (40 patients). 2. Stabilization (for any Medtronic eligible market-released device(s) used from the following product groups: Interbodies and Biologics, Other Spinal Hardware, Rods and Screws): Assessed up to 12 months through radiographic evidence.
3. Deformity correction (for specified Medtronic eligible market-released device(s) used from the Rods and Screws product group): Change of Cobb angle at the 12-month postoperative visit compared to baseline. Assessed up to 12 months.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study is being done to investigate whether the M72/AS01E-4 Mycobacterium tuberculosis vaccine can prevent tuberculosis (TB) infection in healthy, IGRA-positive individuals (individuals whose interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) test result is positive in a QuantiFERON®-TB Gold Plus test) age 18 years and older and also in healthy, IGRA-negative individuals (individuals whose IGRA test result is negative in a QuantiFERON®-TB Gold Plus test). 

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 3, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multicenter trial assessing two dose levels of M72/AS01E-4 Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) investigational vaccine, administered intramuscularly at 0, 3, and 12 months, in healthy individuals age 18 and older who have a positive IGRA test result at screening to assess vaccine efficacy, immunogenicity, and safety. Participants who have a negative IGRA test result at screening will also be eligible for enrollment in a separate part of this trial after screening. Both arms of the trial will be conducted simultaneously. The investigational vaccine will be delivered by a 4-armed syringe and contain 200 μg or 80 μg of M72/AS01E-4 Mtb investigational vaccine antigen: protein A2 adenylate kinase (Antigen A), ESAT-6, CFP-10, and 54-kDa Mycobacterium tuberculosis proteins combined with glucopyranosyl lipid A (Gla) to form immunostimulatory

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The goal of this research is to see if the combination of acitretin (a medicine often given to patients with psoriasis) and spironolactone (a medicine often given to patients with Cushing syndrome) is a safe and effective way to reduce the body's production of aldosterone.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This research will take place in three parts. Part 1 will look at the safety of combining acitretin with spironolactone. In the second part of the research, we will give everyone taking part in the research the medicine called spironolactone. In the third part of the research, we will give the people that took part in the second part only acitretin. Participants must take part in all three parts of the research in order to take part in the entire research study. Researchers will closely monitor the effects of the medicine, and will check for any side effects. If you take part in the research, you will not be able to have the type of skin surgery known as a curettage, which is used to treat certain types of skin cancers.

Official Title
-----------------
A Phase 2, Open-Label, Partitioned, Safety and Crossover Study of Combined Aldosterone Inhibition by Oral Acitretin and Spironolactone With Single Agent Acitretin in Patients With Active Psoriasis

Excellent! Now, let's move on to the secondary outcome measures. Based on the provided reasons for each outcome measure, I suggest the following secondary outcome measures:
1. Non-infectious complication rate during admission, stratified by type and severity using the Clavien-Dindo classification. This can be assessed 1 week after hospital discharge.
2. Days with need for antibiotics, indicating the duration of antibiotic treatment received by participants. This can be assessed 1 week after hospital discharge.
3. Length of stay, measuring the time from admission to discharge, which can be assessed up to 30 days after surgery.
4. Mortality rate at day 30, 90, and 180 after surgery to assess the ultimate outcome of patients.
5. Emergency readmission rate at day 30, 90, and 180 after surgery to evaluate the need for re-admission.
6. Post-discharge nutritional status, measured using the SNAQ screening tool and weight at day 30 and 90 after surgery.
7. Post-discharge weight status, measured at day 30 and 90 after surgery.
8. Routes of energy delivery (oral intake, enteral intake, parenteral intake, or a combination of the three), assessed up to two weeks after surgery.
9. Energy intake during admission, measured in calories, also assessed up to two weeks after surgery.
10. Protein intake during admission, measured in grams of protein, also assessed up to two weeks after surgery.

model_response: Absolutely! AUC represents the total amount of drug that is absorbed into the bloodstream over a given time period, while Cmax represents the peak plasma concentration of the drug. By comparing the AUC and Cmax values of the test and reference products, we can determine whether the two formulations are equivalent in terms of their bioavailability. These measures are important to ensure that the test formulation is as effective as the reference formulation in treating patients with cancer.

The measurement of the AUC and Cmax will be performed using blood samples obtained at pre-determined time points after the administration of the respective Lamotrigine tablets. These measures will be compared between the two formulations and evaluated for bioequivalence. Intervention Description:: [Participant information:] Volunteers who have undergone an initial screening will be informed on Day 3 through Day 7 of their scheduled test day and should fast from 10 PM the night before test day. [Fasting] Volunteers are required to fast from midnight to 8 AM on the day of their test dosing. No food or drink, with the exception of water, is allowed for 10 hours. Volunteers have to sign an informed consent form on Day 4 through Day 8. [Cohort selection]: 40 participants of 4 different age groups who satisfy the screening criteria will be recruited and assigned to four treatment cohorts (10 subjects/2 cohorts each): young, adult, elderly, and geriatric. To measure the AUC and Cmax, we will collect blood samples at various time points up to 72 hours after the administration of the drug. The sampling schedule will include pre-dose (0) and additional time points such as 0.25, 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2, 2.5, 3, 3.5, 4, 5, 6, 8, 12, 16, 24, 36, 48, and 72 hours post-dose.

For the AUC measure, we want to establish bioequivalence by ensuring that the calculated 90% confidence interval (CI) for the ratio of geometric means for AUC72 falls within the range of 80.00%-125.00%. Similarly, for the Cmax measure, the 90% CI for the ratio of geometric means should also fall within 80.00%-125.00%.

The dysbiosis index is a 5-scale index that measures the imbalance in gut microbiota composition. A DI above 2 indicates a microbiota profile that differs significantly from a normobiotic reference collection. Higher values on the index indicate more severe dysbiosis. Assessing the dysbiosis index at the 12-month mark after FMT would provide valuable insights into the impact of fecal microbiota transplantation on restoring a healthy gut microbiota composition in patients with IBS.

This report is the third in a 3 part series describing the development of clinical guidelines for the management of aortic dissection in the setting of a clinical emergency. Abstract:
Background: To evaluate the effects of preoperative colchicine on postoperative troponin I (TnI) and inflammatory factor concentrations in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery. Patients and Methods: A total of 161 patients undergoing noncardiac surgery were prospectively randomized to either 0.5 mg/day colchicine or no colchicine, starting 1 week prior to and continuing until 5 days after surgery. At baseline and just before the operation, as well as on postoperative days 1 and 10, the serum TnI and inflammatory marker concentrations were measured. Results: Postoperative peak TnI levels measured significantly lower (median 1.54 vs 1.77 µg/L, P = .03) and postoperative peak CRP levels measured significantly lower (median 26.1 vs 31.1 mg/L, P = .03) in the colchicine group compared with the no‐colchicine group. A higher proportion of the patients in the colchicine group demonstrated a troponin‐free postoperative course, despite no significant difference in absolute cardiac event numbers. The same observations applied to patients with ischemic heart disease. Multivariate analysis suggested that a greater preoperative body mass index had the greatest effect on postoperative peak TnI levels, followed by diabetes mellitus and low colchicine use. Conclusion: Preoperative colchicine reduced postoperative peak TnI and CRP levels and significantly increased the proportion of patients with a troponin‐free postoperative course, particularly in patients with ischemic heart disease. Copyright © 2017 American College of Cardiology Foundation.

4. Long-term cardiovascular outcome: Assess the proportion of patients developing MACE as a marker of long-term postoperative outcome. Time frame: until 1 year after surgery.

Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this study was to assess the pharmacokinetics (PK) of nicotine in daily NCP users after single (pouch for one use) use of a test prototype dry nicotine pouch (DNP), when tested as the only product use for at least 24 hours prior to the PK assessment. The test prototype DNP contains nicotine salt, and the investigational product will be administered using a standard dosing regimen (SDR). The SDR consists of two steps: Step 1: one IP inserted in the buccal pouch followed by intra-cheek-oral (ICO) placement; and Step 2: two additional IPs subsequently placed back in the buccal pouch between the gum and the cheek, with the gums and buccal mucosa pulled away from the cheek when inserting the second IP.

Excellent. Now, let's discuss the primary outcome measures for your study. Based on the information you've provided, there are several primary outcome measures. The first one is the AUC from timepoint 0 to infinity (AUCinf). This measure assesses the non-adjusted and baseline-adjusted PK parameters for nicotine, including the area under the curve from timepoint 0 to infinity. It will be evaluated at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Another primary outcome measure is the AUC from timepoint 0 to timepoint t (AUC0-t). This measure evaluates the non-adjusted and baseline-adjusted PK parameters for nicotine, including the area under the curve from timepoint 0 to a specific timepoint. Similar to the previous measure, it will be assessed at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Yes, there are a few more primary outcome measures we should consider. The AUC from timepoint 0 to 30 minutes (AUC0-30min) and AUC from timepoint 0 to 60 minutes (AUC0-60min) are important measures for assessing the early exposure and bioavailability of nicotine. They will be evaluated at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Both Cmax and Tmax are important primary outcome measures. Cmax assesses the maximum plasma concentration of nicotine achieved after IP use, while Tmax measures the time it takes to reach the maximum plasma concentration. These measures provide insights into the rate of absorption and the peak exposure of nicotine. They will be evaluated at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Certainly. The first secondary outcome measure is the in vivo extracted amount (mg/unit) of nicotine for each investigational product. This measure helps evaluate the efficiency of nicotine delivery and the consistency of nicotine content in the pouches. It will be assessed at visits 2 to 4.

Another secondary outcome measure is the in vivo extracted fraction (%) of nicotine for each investigational product. This measure provides information on the bioavailability and release characteristics of nicotine from the pouches. It will also be evaluated at visits 2 to 4.

Yes, there are a few more secondary outcome measures. We should assess the highest recorded increase (Emax) in pulse rate from baseline, which helps evaluate the acute physiological effects of nicotine on cardiovascular function. Additionally, we should measure the mean score for each palatability question 30 minutes after the start of IP use, which provides insights into taste, flavor, and overall user experience. We should also evaluate urge-to-use, product-liking, intent-to-use-again, and onset-of-effect after IP use to assess user satisfaction and behavioral responses. Finally, we should monitor the frequency, seriousness, and intensity of adverse events (AEs) to ensure participant safety throughout the study.

Background
-----------------
Insulin resistance and decreased insulin sensitivity have long been associated with the development of type 2 diabetes. Previous studies have also demonstrated that lifestyle interventions incorporating exercise training programs reduce the effects of aging on systemic glucose tolerance and insulin sensitivity. However, to date, no studies have examined the interplay between exercise training and diabetes control or its effects on glycemic control in the elderly. Methods
-----------------

Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a significant public health concern, affecting about 294 million people worldwide. Despite successful treatments such as pharmacological therapy, approximately 20-30% of patients fail to respond to these treatments. These patients are classified as treatment-resistant depression (TRD), and they are at a higher risk of developing complications such as suicidal ideation, anxiety disorders, and substance abuse. One approach to improving treatment outcomes in MDD is to incorporate neurobiofeedback therapy (NBF) into the treatment plan of patients. NBF is a technique that uses electroencephalography (EEG) to provide real-time feedback on brain activity. The goal of NBF is to train patients to regulate their brain activity in a way that improves symptoms of depression.
Previous studies have shown that NBF is an effective treatment for MDD. One study found that NBF led to significant reductions in depression symptoms compared to a waitlist control group. Another study found that NBF was associated with improvements in mood, cognitive function, and anxiety. However, there is still limited evidence to support the use of NBF in large clinical trials.
The objective of this study is to assess the efficacy and safety of NBF for the treatment of MDD, particularly in patients who have failed to respond to pharm

INTERVENTION/PROGRAM: An intervention of systematic pharmacy counsellor/physician interaction was implemented at the health centers in Uppsala County.MEASUREMENT AND RESULTS: There was a significant decline in potentially severe medication outcomes following the intervention (the rate of adverse outcomes was reduced by 12.7%, 95% confidence interval 5.1‐19.5%) compared with no change in an adjacent county in Sweden served by 41 health centers that had no intervention.CONCLUSION: The most effective means of reducing adverse prescription outcomes may be regular contact between the physician and a clinical pharmacist. Brief summary
=================
The purpose of this study is to determine the effects of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) on the cognitive function of patients with mild-to-moderate Alzheimer’s disease. Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) will be administered at the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex to patients diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease while they participate in a visual recognition task. Participants will be asked to learn novel word-object associations while receiving either real rTMS or sham (placebo) rTMS. The investigators hypothesize that the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex is critical for encoding and remembering novel word-object associations, and that rTMS will improve learning capabilities in patients with amnestic mild cognitive impairment or Alzheimer’s disease.
