Abstract:
A Phase 1, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled, crossover study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and PK of multiple oral doses of PF‐06974268 (12 days each, 220 mg QD) compared to placebo in healthy male subjects under fasted conditions. PK samples were collected for 22 days at each dosing interval and 41 days after dosing. The pharmacokinetics (PK) of PF‐06974268 in healthy male subjects (N=64) were investigated in each part of a study (Parts 1‐3) using an oral liquid solution formulation with a 14‐day washout between treatment courses. Study results showed that, following administration of a single dose of PF‐06974268, steady‐state plasma concentrations were achieved within a week, with a tmax of approximately 2 hours after a single oral dose. The PK profile of PF‐06974268 was stable after repeated dosing in healthy male subjects, and the main metabolic pathway (M1) was consistent with CYP3A4 and UGT1A9. PF‐06974268 showed good systemic bioavailability, with no signs of drug accumulation in the body after repeated administration. The safety profile of PF‐06974268 was similar to that of placebo in all Parts of the study.

Intervention
=================
This is a study to test whether acetazolamide in the fasting state can reduce the amount of carbon dioxide formed during breath-holding. The hypothesis is that by removing carbon dioxide, the threshold for symptomatic hypoxia will be increased. This will allow subjects to breathe fewer times (increased apnea time) per breath-hold, which should in turn reduce the development of lung disease (emphysema).  In patients with emphysema, lung disease is often characterized by a persistent loss of lung elasticity. Loss of elasticity makes it more difficult to empty (empty more slowly) lungs after an exhalation. In response to the loss of elasticity, a person takes small, shallow breaths and exhale before taking another breath (reduced tidal volume breathing). Small breaths have an important consequence in that they do not allow air to fully exit the lungs. As a result, breathing small breaths increases the amount of CO2 that is blown back into the system.

Abstract:
Background: This study seeks to evaluate the effectiveness of a program providing behavioral care coordinated with medical care, compared to care provided in the community, on self‐care behaviors in adult Latinos with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes. Methods: This randomized controlled parallel‐arm study will enroll 18 to 70 year old adults with poorly controlled diabetes (glycated hemoglobin A1c ≥ 8%) who attend a Federally Qualified Health Center (FQHC). 40 participants will be randomized to behavioral care integrated with medical care, 40 to a control condition (behavioral care provided in the community). Outcome assessment will be completed via electronic survey at baseline and at four months. The primary outcome measure is a change in glycemic control, as measured by the glycosylated hemoglobin A1c. Secondary outcome measures include changes in diabetes management behaviors at 4 months as assessed by the Diabetes Management Questionnaire (DMQ), a validated scale. Descriptive statistics (mean and standard deviations) will be generated for each condition (integrated versus community‐based). A one sample paired t‐test will be conducted to examine whether the integrated condition improves the glycosylated hemoglobin A1c (Δ), glycemic control, from baseline to the 4‐month assessment. Results of descriptive statistics will be used to examine the feasibility and acceptability of the approach. Discussion: In this presentation we will present data on the intervention feasibility and acceptability. We hypothesize that the approach of combining behavioral with medical services will lead to improvements in both glycemic control and diabetes self‐management. 800‐95‐7939. SPC/MH, 2018.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The purpose of this study was to determine the incidence of adductor pollicis triggering during an ulnar styloid fracture (USF) reduction.MATERIAL/METHODS: A prospective study of 76 patients undergoing reduction and internal fixation of USF was performed. The incidence of adductor triggering was assessed by comparing anesthesia records, post‐operative complaints, and digital radiographs (DRs).RESULTS: The true incidence of adductor triggering is expected to be higher than expected as only 35% of patients sought medical attention after the initial trauma, while nearly 50% had documented adductor triggering. We were unable to determine in the literature whether ulnar styloid fractures caused the adductor triggering or was secondary, as many patients sought medical attention within the immediate post‐injury period due to other associated injuries, and many individuals suffer from the symptoms of adductor triggering, but delay seeking treatment.CONCLUSION: Ulnar styloid fractures can cause adductor triggering, and the adductor triggering is usually not recognized for months or years following the initial trauma. Therefore, it is important for physicians to be aware of this possibility when evaluating patients for ulnar styloid fracture and adductor triggering. Level of evidence: Therapeutic Level III.

Abstract:
Background: Snoring is a common complaint in adults, affecting approximately 50% of the population. Retropalatal narrowing and collapse are known to contribute to snoring. Myofunctional therapy (MFT) is a behavioral approach that improves muscle tonus but is of limited efficacy in people with OSA. We present the study protocol for a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy of MTF exercise in reducing snoring in patients with sleep‐disordered breathing (SDB). Methods: This study is currently recruiting. Individuals with an STOP‐Bang score of 3 or more, who are overweight, and have pharyngeal collapse in the retropalatal area will be randomly allocated to either the control group (standard of care) or the intervention group (MFT exercise). The group and therapist are blinded throughout study. The intervention group will receive 6 weeks of rehabilitative treatment, which will involve MFT exercise therapy to improve muscle tonus and retention of the tongue, mouth, and lips, along with sleep hygiene education. Participants will be evaluated at baseline and after 6 weeks of intervention. The outcome measures include retropalatal narrowing and collapse, daytime sleepiness, severity of snoring, and body mass index. Data analysis will be performed using independent‐samples t‐test. Discussion: This study aims to provide preliminary data on the effectiveness of MFT exercise in treating retropalatal pharyngeal collapse as an innovative, non‐invasive therapeutic approach for SDB. If successful in showing a reduction in snoring, this promising intervention may promote self‐management and alleviate the burden of SDB on patients. Trial registration: This study was registered on 16 December 2022 with a registration number of P3D3QW.

Abstract:
Background: Surgical treatment is the definitive option for the management of thyroid nodules, with or without cancer. The traditional ligation of the thyroid arteries has been suggested to reduce excessive intraoperative bleeding or complications during neck dissection, even though there is no clear evidence. However, it is difficult to select patients with increased vascular supply for the ligation procedure. Purpose: The present study aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the preoperative use of superparamagnetic iron oxide nanoparticles (SPIO‐MPs) in detecting vascular patterns and selecting patients that may benefit from surgical control of the thyroid vascular system. Material and Methods: 55 patients (35 females and 20 males, mean age 48 years) were included in the study. Patients were treated before and after surgery with an oral dose of 7.5–10.0 mg of SPIO‐MPs. MRI images were acquired immediately before and after MR contrast administration at three different times: preoperative, intraoperative, and postoperative. On MRI, the vascular patterns were categorized as: (1) normal, (2) hypovascular, or (3) hypervascular. An independent surgeon performed the revisions, and SPIO‐MPs were used to assess the vascular patterns during surgery. Intraoperative and postoperative complications (temporary or permanent vocal cord paralysis, damage to the recurrent laryngeal nerve, and hypoparathyroidism) were also recorded. Results: The rate of vascular patterns during surgery (i.e., hypovascular or hypervascular) correlated significantly with the preoperative assessments (P = .001). Among the 55 cases, 79.3% were classified as hypovascular, whereas only 20.7% were classified as hypervascular preoperatively. No intraoperative or postoperative complications were

Methods: Between Nov 2014 and July 2018, 88 men and women with ACC were treated at UCLA with 25‐40 Gy and 5‐week chemotherapy consisting of capecitabine 825 mg/m2 twice daily or infusional 5‐FU 225‐400 mg/m2 bolus and 2000‐3000 mg/m2 continuous. Outcomes, including 1‐, 2‐, and 3‐month quality of life (QoL) data using the ECOG QLQ CR29 form and incidence of grade 3+ toxicity, were assessed up to 3 months after CRT completion. The Wilcoxon rank‐sum test was used to analyze continuous variables, and the Fisher exact test was used to evaluate categorical variables between 2 groups. Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: The goal of this study was to measure the effectiveness of a multisite home‐based pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) program in patients who recently completed a supervised hospital‐based PR program for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).BACKGROUND: PR is a cost‐effective treatment of moderate‐to‐very‐severe COPD, with numerous benefits for exercise tolerance, quality of life, and respiratory symptoms; however, the program often terminates shortly after hospital discharge. The ability to assess pulmonary function outcomes from the patient's home has the potential to promote the prolonged benefits of PR.METHODS: In this multisite randomized controlled trial, patients who had completed hospital‐based PR were randomized to either a weekly PR telemonitoring program or to receive supportive care for at least 3 months (control group). The PR telemonitoring program included an individualized PR prescription, weekly phone call contact, and tele‐assessment of exercise capacity over a period of 16 weeks. The primary outcome measure and aim were the physical component scale (PCS) score of the Medical Outcomes Short‐Form 36 Health Survey Questionnaire. The secondary outcome measures were PCS scores at 6 and 12 months, other domains of the SF‐36, health care utilization, days off work, quality of life, anxiety, and depression levels, the level of dyspnea, and the number of participants completing the intervention.RESULTS: Overall, 302 participants were enrolled. The PCS score at 3 months did not differ significantly between the two groups. However, the number of participants who returned for a telephone call at least once a month was higher in the control group (82% vs 69%; P < .001). Secondary analyses of PCS scores at 6 and 12 months, and of SF‐36 domains, demonstrated statistically significant differences in favor of the telemonitoring program.CONCLUSIONS: Home‐based PR telemonitoring did not lead to additional pulmonary benefits after hospital‐based PR in terms of the PCS score at 3 months. However, this telemonitoring program should be more carefully examined as the potential benefits might include improvement in SF‐36 domains, particularly in physical activity.

Study of Aminoquinolines for Rare Syndromic Neurological Diseases

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This clinical study represents a unique and highly innovative approach to the exploration of a novel family of anticonvulsant therapies with a high probability of success. To date, the clinical development process for new compounds begins only after the discovery of a lead molecule. However, these studies do not provide information to inform decisions as to which lead molecule should progress into clinical phase I studies, and often these lead molecules progress into clinical trials without ever establishing a linkage to an actionable genetic target. The novel approach of exploring the efficacy and safety profile of a family of small molecules in a subset of patients with SLC25A13 mutations can identify both efficacious compounds as well as actionable genetic targets for future development.

Detailed Description
-----------------
S-adenosyll-L-methionine synthase (AdoMet-Synthase) is the first enzyme in the methionine cycle. The key downstream functions of the adenosylmethionine cycle are to provide an activated methyl donor for the synthesis of proteins and lipids. Disruption of the methionine cycle can lead to severe metabolic defects associated with neurologically impairing disease. One enzyme in the methionine cycle, AdoMet-Synthase, requires adenosylcobalamin to function. Adenosylcobalamin (vitamin B12) is a coenzyme found only in the diet, which requires two enzymes for absorption. SLC25A13 is responsible for the first step in the uptake of adenosylcobalamin. Mutations in SLC25A13 impair this function and lead to a variety of neurological defects characterized by neurological impairment, encephalopathy, and seizures. Title
=================
To Evaluate the Immersive Effects of a Sensory-rich VR Environment as a Means of Distraction from Pain During Intravenous Insertion by Novice Nurses in the Postoperative Setting

Scientific title
=================
A randomized controlled pilot study evaluating the immersive effects of a sensory-rich virtual reality (VR) environment compared to standard care as pain-control methods during intravenous (IV) insertion in adult and pediatric patients in the postoperative setting.

Plain English Summary
=================
Background and study aimsSometimes hospitals provide medical treatment without pain control methods because it is important for them to move as quickly as possible with the limited support resources and manpower available. This may make patients or their families feel uncomfortable about getting medical treatment. This study aims to investigate two different pain control methods during IV insertion: immersive VR and standard care. Immersive VR is a type of virtual reality that uses special technology to create the illusion of being in a virtual environment. We want to compare the two approaches in terms of patient acceptance, satisfaction and pain.Who can participate?Adults aged 20 and over undergoing abdominal elective surgeries and patients aged 3 and over undergoing major surgeries requiring IV insertion and their families.What does the study involve?In this study, we aim to recruit 78 adult and pediatric patients from a tertiary referral center. All patients will undergo abdominal surgery. Patients with pre-existing anemia (Hb < 8.5 g/dL), patients with chronic psychiatric disorders such as dementia and schizophrenia, and patients with epilepsy or a history of seizures are excluded.The patients will be randomized into four groups, each consisting of 20 participants:Group 1 will receive standard careGroup 2 will receive VR with immobilizationGroup 3 will receive VR without immobilizationGroup 4 will receive VR immersion with immobilizationDuring the IV insertion process, patients will use VR with or without immobilization by randomization, and the pain and satisfaction scores of patients and family members, as well as the acceptance of the IV insertion by the patients, will be evaluated.What are the possible benefits and risks of participating

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The investigators planned to assess the immunogenicity and safety of the inactivated rotavirus vaccine and investigate the possible difference of immunogenicity and safety between adults and children.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The investigators planned to recruit 240 adults and 60 children as the study population. The participants would receive 3 doses of the inactivated rotavirus vaccine at Day 0, 28 and 56 respectively and all the participants would be followed up for one year. The primary objective was to evaluate the immunogenicity of the inactivated rotavirus vaccine in adults and children, focusing on the GMTs (Geometric Mean Titer) and seroconversion rates of anti-RV serum antibodies and Vero cell neutralizing antibodies at baseline and one month after the final dose. The secondary objective was to assess the safety and tolerability of the inactivated rotavirus vaccine in adults and children. The investigators planned to compare the immunogenicity and safety of the inactivated rotavirus vaccine between adults and children.

Official Title
-----------------
An Open-label, Single-center, Phase II Exploratory Clinical Trial for the Safety and Immunogenicity of Inactivated Rotavirus Vaccine and Comparison Study Between Adults and Children

Conditions

Rotavirus Infection

Intervention / Treatment

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The main purpose of the study is to assess the safety of the vaccine when administered alone or in combination with diphtheria, tetanus and co-administered pertussis- Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)- and hepatitis B (HepB) or diphtheria, tetanus- pertussis (DTP). For the primary endpoint, the percentage of vaccinated participants reporting at least one solicited adverse event in the 30 minutes period after the first dose will be estimated, including grade 3 or higher local (erythema, swelling) and systemic reactions (febrile (>=38oC) or afebrile convulsion). For the secondary endpoints, the percentages of the vaccinated participants reporting at least one unsolicited adverse event will be evaluated within 7 days after each dose and overall within 28 days after each dose. Also, the percentage of the vaccinated participants reporting any solicited local reaction will be estimated within 7 days after each dose, and the percentage of the vaccinated participants reporting at least one solicited systemic reaction will be assessed within 7 days after each dose. The occurrence of serious adverse events, medically confirmed adverse events of special interest (AESI), and concurrent adverse events not medically confirmed will be evaluated. Lastly, blood samples and nasal swabs will be collected for laboratory analyses.

Perfect! We now have a comprehensive set of primary and secondary outcome measures for your clinical trial on the inactivated rotavirus vaccine. Here they are:

Primary Outcome Measures:
1. Immunogenicity index-geometric mean titer (GMT) of neutralizing antibody: Measure the GMT of neutralizing antibodies 28 days after the final dose.
2. Immunogenicity index-geometric mean increase (GMI) of neutralizing antibody: Assess the increase in neutralizing antibodies from baseline to 28 days after the final dose.
3. Immunogenicity index-seroconversion rates of neutralizing antibody: Determine the proportion of participants who develop a seropositive response between baseline and 28 days after the final dose.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Safety index-incidence of adverse reactions/events: Monitor the incidence of adverse reactions/events within 30 minutes after each dose.
2. Safety index-incidence of solicited adverse reactions/events: Assess the incidence of solicited adverse reactions/events within 7 days after each dose.
3. Safety index-incidence of unsolicited adverse reactions/events: Evaluate the incidence of unsolicited adverse reactions/events within 28/30 days after each dose.
4. Safety index-incidence of serious adverse events: Track the occurrence of serious adverse reactions/events from the beginning of vaccination up to 6 months after the final dose.

model_response:
Ctrough is a measure of the amount of a drug in the blood when it reaches its lowest level after a single administration. It's used to evaluate the pharmacokinetic properties of a drug and its adverse effects.

For instance, let's say the drug is administered as an intravenous (IV) infusion at a fixed dose and time and the plasma concentration is measured just before the next dose at a specific time, such as 24 hours. Ctrough can be calculated as the observed plasma concentration at the pre-dose time divided by the drug exposure.

It's a crucial parameter for dose adjustment and therapy prediction because it can provide important insights into the drug's kinetics and dose-response relationship. 

However, the interpretation of Ctrough must be taken in the context of other pharmacokinetic properties such as peak drug concentration, time to drug maximum concentration, area under the drug concentration curve, and etc.

We would measure the minimum serum drug concentration at least 24 hours after administration of QL1706H. It is important to allow enough time for the drug to be fully absorbed and metabolized in the body.

As we mentioned, one of the secondary outcome measures is the objective response rate (ORR) based on RECIST 1.1 criteria. This measure will be assessed every 6 weeks, starting from the date of first administration of QL1706H until disease progression or withdrawal from the trial. The ORR is the proportion of patients who experience a complete or partial response based on RECIST 1.1 criteria. It represents the efficacy of the drug in treating advanced solid tumors. 

We would also like to assess the duration of response (DOR) and the disease control rate (DCR). DOR is the length of time from the first observation of objective response to the initial documented objective tumor progression or death from any cause, whichever occurs first. DCR is the proportion of patients who achieve a best overall response of complete response (CR), partial response (PR), or stable disease (SD) according to RECIST 1.1 criteria. 

Moreover, the presence or absence of peripheral neurologic toxicity will also be monitored throughout the study. This can help us evaluate the safety and tolerability of QL1706H. Furthermore, we intend to monitor serum albumin levels as a surrogate measure for the drug's efficacy and safety. Serum albumin is an indicator of health, and its levels can decline in cancer patients. A decrease in serum albumin levels could indicate that the drug has a direct effect on tumor cells.

The measure description for assessing safety and tolerability through the rate of treatment-related adverse events would be the evaluation of any adverse events experienced by the participants as a result of receiving the drug QL1706H. This measure allows us to monitor potential side effects and ensure that the drug is well-tolerated by the participants. As the safety and tolerability of the drug are paramount, this measure will be an integral part of the trial.
